{"uri": "2024-05-345541636", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "11:09:53", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T11:09:53Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T10:50:10Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8039215803146362, "url": "https://www.republicworld.com/world-news/australia-new-zealand/australia-police-shoot-16-year-old-boy-after-he-stabs-a-man-in-perth", "title": "Australia: Police Shoot 16-Year-Old Boy After He Stabs a Man in Perth", "body": "The Perth parking lot where the 16-year-old boy was shot dead. | Image:AP\n\nMelbourne: A 16-year-old boy armed with a knife was shot dead by police after he stabbed a man in the Australian west coast city of Perth, officials said Sunday. The incident occurred in the parking lot of a hardware store in suburban Willetton on Saturday night.\n\nThe teen attacked the man and then rushed at police officers before he was shot, Western Australian Premier Roger Cook told reporters on Sunday.\n\n\"There are indications he had been radicalised online,\" Cook told a news conference.\n\n\"But I want to reassure the community at this stage it appears that he acted solely and alone,\" Cook added.\n\nA man in his 30s was found at the scene with a stab wound to his back. He was taken to a hospital in serious but stable condition, a police statement said.\n\nPolice and Australian Security Intelligence Organization agents have been conducting a counterterrorism investigation in the east coast city of Sydney since another 16-year-old boy stabbed an Assyrian Orthodox bishop and priest in a church on April 15.\n\nThat boy has been charged with committing a terrorist act. Six of his alleged associates have also been charged with a range of offenses, including conspiring to engage in or planning a terrorist act. All remain in custody.\n\n'No ongoing threat to the community'\n\nPrime Minister Anthony Albanese said he had been briefed on the latest stabbing in Perth by Australian Federal Police Commissioner Reece Kershaw and ASIO Director-General Mike Burgess, who heads the nation's main domestic spy agency.\n\n\"I'm advised there is no ongoing threat to the community on the information available,\" Albanese said.\n\n\"We are a peace-loving nation and there is no place for violent extremism in Australia,\" he added.\n\nPolice received an emergency phone call after 22:00 from a teenager saying he was going to commit acts of violence, Western Australian Police Commissioner Col Blanch said.\n\nThe boy had been participating in a programme for young people at risk of radicalisation, Blanch added.\n\n\"I don't want to say he has been radicalised or is radicalised because I think that forms part of the investigation,\" he said.\n\nPolice said they were later alerted by a phone call from a member of the public that a knife attack was underway in the parking lot. Three police officers responded, one armed with a gun and two with conducted energy devices.\n\nPolice deployed both conducted energy devices but they failed to incapacitate the boy before he was killed by a single gunshot, Blanch said.\n\nBlanch said members of the local Muslim community had raised concerns with police about the boy's behaviour before he was killed on Saturday.\n\nThe Imam of Perth's largest mosque, the Nasir Mosque, condemned the stabbing.\n\n\"There is no place for violence in Islam,\" Imam Syed Wadood Janud said in a statement.\n\n\"We appreciate the effort of the police to keep our communities safe. I also want to commend the local Muslim community who had flagged the individual prior with the police,\" Wadood added.\n\nSome Muslim leaders have criticised Australian police for declaring last month's church stabbing a terrorist act but not a rampage two days earlier in a Sydney shopping mall in which six people were killed and a dozen wounded.\n\nThe 40-year-old attacker in the mall attack was shot dead by police. Police have yet to reveal the man's motive.\n\nThe church attack is only the third to be classified by Australian authorities as a terrorist act since 2018.\n\nIn December 2022, three Christian fundamentalists shot dead two police officers and a bystander in an ambush near the community of Wieambilla in Queensland state. The shooters were later killed by police.\n\nIn November 2018, a Somalia-born Muslim stabbed three pedestrians in downtown Melbourne, killing one, before police shot him dead.", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "2024-05-345321376", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "09:32:06", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T09:32:06Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T09:27:47Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8039215803146362, "url": "https://www.timesofisrael.com/australian-police-shoot-teen-dead-after-stabbing-with-hallmarks-of-terrorism/", "title": "Australian police shoot teen dead after stabbing with 'hallmarks' of terrorism", "body": "SYDNEY -- Australian police said on Sunday they had shot dead a boy after he stabbed a man in Western Australia's capital Perth, in an attack authorities said indicated terrorism.\n\nThere were signs the 16-year-old, armed with a kitchen knife, had been radicalized online, state authorities said, adding they received calls from concerned members of the local Muslim community before the attack, which occurred late on Saturday night.\n\nThe attack, in the suburb of Willetton, had \"hallmarks\" of terrorism but was yet to be declared a terrorist act, police said.\n\nThe incident occurred in the parking lot of a hardware store in suburban Willetton on Saturday night.\n\nA man in his 30s was found at the scene with a stab wound to his back. He was taken to a hospital in serious but stable condition, a police statement said.\n\nThe teen attacked the man and then rushed at police officers before he was shot, Western Australian Premier Roger Cook told reporters on Sunday.\n\n\"At this stage, it appears that he acted solely and alone,\" Cook told a televised press conference in the state capital Perth, regarding the attacker.\n\nPrime Minister Anthony Albanese said he had been briefed on the incident by police and intelligence agencies, which advised there was no ongoing threat.\n\n\"We are a peace-loving nation and there is no place for violent extremism in Australia,\" Albanese said on social media platform X.\n\nPolice received an emergency phone call after 10 p.m. from a teenager saying he was going to commit acts of violence, Western Australian Police Commissioner Col Blanch said.\n\nThe boy had been participating in a program for young people at risk of radicalization, Blanch added.\n\n\"I don't want to say he has been radicalized or is radicalized because I think that forms part of the investigation,\" he said.\n\nPolice body camera images showed the teenager refused officers' demands that he put down the knife, the police chief said.\n\nThe weapon was a 30-centimeter (one-foot) kitchen knife, believed to be from the attacker's home, Blanch said.\n\nOfficers fired two Tasers at him but \"both of them did not have the full desired effect,\" he said.\n\n\"The male continued to advance on the third officer with a firearm who fired a single shot and fatally wounded the male.\"\n\nThe teenager died in the hospital later in the night, he said.\n\nPolice believe the teenager sent \"relevant messages\" to some members of the Muslim community who immediately called police, Blanch said, without giving details of the messages.\n\nThe boy had \"mental issues but also online radicalization issues,\" the police chief said.\n\nIn the past two years, the attacker had been part of a \"countering violence extremism program\" for people who show signs of \"religious or issues-motivated\" concerns, he said.\n\n\"It is not a criminal-based approach but it is a program to help individuals who are expressing ideologies that are of concern in our community. But they may not be committing any crimes.\"\n\nPolice said they did not know what had triggered the attack.\n\nThe imam of Perth's largest mosque, the Nasir Mosque, condemned the stabbing.\n\n\"There is no place for violence in Islam,\" Imam Syed Wadood Janud said in a statement.\n\n\"We appreciate the effort of the police to keep our communities safe. I also want to commend the local Muslim community who had flagged the individual prior with the police,\" Wadood added.\n\nThe incident comes after New South Wales police last month charged several boys with terrorism-related offenses in investigations following the stabbing of an Assyrian Christian bishop while he was giving a live-streamed sermon in Sydney, on April 15.\n\nThe attack on the bishop came only days after a stabbing spree killed six in the Sydney beachside suburb of Bondi.\n\nGun and knife crime is rare in Australia, which consistently ranks among the safest countries in the {"uri": "8111969054", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "06:42:39", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T06:42:39Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T06:42:12Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7921568751335144, "url": "https://www.shropshirestar.com/news/world-news/2024/05/05/police-shoot-dead-radicalised-teenager-after-he-stabbed-man/", "title": "Police shoot dead 'radicalised' teenager after he stabbed man", "body": "The 16-year-old was killed in the western city of Perth on Saturday night.\n\nA 16-year-old boy armed with a knife was shot dead by police after he stabbed a man in the Australian west coast city of Perth.\n\nThe incident occurred in the car park of a hardware store in suburban Willetton on Saturday night.\n\nThe teenager attacked the man and then rushed at police officers before he was shot, Western Australian premier Roger Cook told reporters on Sunday.\n\n\"There are indications he had been radicalised online,\" Mr Cook told a news conference.\n\n\"But I want to reassure the community at this stage it appears that he acted solely and alone,\" he added.\n\nA man in his 30s was found at the scene with a stab wound to his back. He was taken to a hospital in a serious but stable condition, a police statement said.\n\nPolice and Australian Security Intelligence Organisation (ASIO) agents have been conducting a counterterrorism investigation in the east coast city of Sydney since another 16-year-old boy stabbed an Assyrian Orthodox bishop and priest in a church on April 15.\n\nThat boy has been charged with committing a terrorist act. Six of his alleged associates have also been charged with a range of offences, including conspiring to engage in or planning a terrorist act. All remain in custody.\n\nPrime Minister Anthony Albanese said he had been briefed on the latest stabbing in Perth by Australian federal police commissioner Reece Kershaw and ASIO director-general Mike Burgess, who heads the nation's main domestic spy agency.\n\n\"I'm advised there is no ongoing threat to the community on the information available,\" Mr Albanese said.\n\n\"We are a peace-loving nation and there is no place for violent extremism in Australia,\" he added.\n\nPolice received an emergency phone call after 10pm from a teenager saying he was going to commit acts of violence, Western Australian police commissioner Col Blanch said.\n\nThe boy had been participating in a programme for young people at risk of radicalisation, Mr Blanch added.\n\n\"I don't want to say he has been radicalised or is radicalised because I think that forms part of the investigation,\" he said.\n\nPolice said they were later alerted by a phone call from a member of the public that a knife attack was underway in the parking lot.\n\nThree police officers responded, one armed with a gun and two with tasers.\n\nPolice deployed both tasers but they failed to incapacitate the boy before he was killed by a single gunshot, Mr Blanch said.\n\nMr Blanch said members of the local Muslim community had raised concerns with police about the boy's behaviour before he was killed on Saturday.\n\nThe Imam of Perth's largest mosque, the Nasir Mosque, condemned the stabbing.\n\n\"There is no place for violence in Islam,\" Imam Syed Wadood Janud said in a statement.\n\n\"We appreciate the effort of the police to keep our communities safe. I also want to commend the local Muslim community who had flagged the individual prior with the police,\" Mr Wadood added.\n\nSome Muslim leaders have criticised Australian police for declaring last month's church stabbing a terrorist act but not a rampage two days earlier in a Sydney shopping mall in which six people were killed and a dozen wounded.\n\nThe 40-year-old attacker in the mall attack was shot dead by police. Police have yet to reveal the man's motive.\n\nThe church attack is only the third to be classified by Australian authorities as a terrorist act since 2018.\n\nIn December 2022, three Christian fundamentalists shot dead two police officers and a bystander in an ambush near the community of Wieambilla in Queensland state. The attackers were later killed by police.\n\nIn November 2018, a Somalia-born Muslim stabbed three pedestrians in downtown Melbourne, killing one, before police shot him dead.", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "8112311324", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "12:15:27", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T12:15:27Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T12:14:55Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7882353067398071, "url": "https://www.cbsnews.com/news/australian-police-shoot-armed-teenager-after-stabbing-attack-hallmarks-of-terror/", "title": "Australian police shoot armed teenager after stabbing attack that that had \"hallmarks\" of terror", "body": "Australian police shot and killed a 16-year-old boy armed with a knife after he stabbed a man in an attack that had the \"hallmarks\" of terror, officials said Sunday.\n\nThe incident occurred in the parking lot of a hardware store in Willetton, a suburb in the west coast city of Perth, on Saturday night.\n\nPolice said they received an emergency phone call after 10 p.m. from a teenager saying he was going to commit acts of violence, Western Australian Police Commission Col Blanch said in a news conference Sunday.\n\nPolice said they were later alerted by a phone call from a member of the public that a knife attack was underway in the parking lot. Three police officers responded, one armed with a gun and two with conducted energy devices.\n\nThe teen, who was only described as a 16-year-old Caucasian male, attacked the man and then rushed at police officers before he was shot.\n\nPolice deployed both conducted energy devices but they failed to incapacitate the boy before he was killed by a single gunshot, Blanch said.\n\nA man in his 30s was found at the scene with a stab wound to his back. He was taken to a hospital in serious but stable condition, a police statement said.\n\nBlanch said the incident had the \"hallmarks\" of a terrorist attack, adding that it \"meets the criteria or at least definition\" of this type of crime.\n\nHe said members of the local Muslim community had raised concerns with police about the boy's behavior before he was killed on Saturday.\n\nThe teenager had been participating in a program for young people at risk of radicalization, Blanch added.\n\n\"There are indications he had been radicalized online,\" said Western Australian Premier Roger Cook during a news conference.\n\n\"But I want to reassure the community at this stage it appears that he acted solely and alone,\" Cook added.\n\nPolice and Australian Security Intelligence Organization agents have been conducting a counterterrorism investigation in the east coast city of Sydney since another 16-year-old boy stabbed an Assyrian Orthodox bishop and priest in a church on April 15.\n\nThat boy has been charged with committing a terrorist act. Six of his alleged associates have also been charged with a range of offenses, including conspiring to engage in or planning a terrorist act. All remain in custody.\n\nPrime Minister Anthony Albanese said in a post on X, formerly known as Twitter, that he had been briefed on the latest stabbing in Perth by Australian Federal Police Commissioner Reece Kershaw and ASIO Director-General Mike Burgess, who heads the nation's main domestic spy agency.\n\n\"I'm advised there is no ongoing threat to the community on the information available,\" Albanese said.\n\n\"We are a peace-loving nation and there is no place for violent extremism in Australia,\" he added.\n\nThe Imam of Perth's largest mosque, the Nasir Mosque, condemned the stabbing.\n\n\"There is no place for violence in Islam,\" Imam Syed Wadood Janud said in a statement.\n\n\"We appreciate the effort of the police to keep our communities safe. I also want to commend the local Muslim community who had flagged the individual prior with the police,\" Wadood added.\n\nSome Muslim leaders have criticized Australian police for declaring last month's church stabbing a terrorist act but not a rampage two days earlier in a Sydney shopping mall in which six people were killed and a dozen wounded. The 40-year-old attacker in the mall attack was shot dead by police. Police have yet to reveal the man's motive.\n\nThe church attack is only the third to be classified by Australian authorities as a terrorist act since 2018.\n\nIn December 2022, three Christian fundamentalists shot dead two police officers and a bystander in an ambush near the community of Wieambilla in Queensland state. The shooters were later killed by police.\n\nIn November 2018, a Somalia-born Muslim stabbed three pedestrians in downtown Melbourne, killing one, before police shot him dead.", "source": {"uri": He was taken to a hospital in a serious but stable condition, a police statement said.\n\nPolice and Australian Security Intelligence Organisation (ASIO) agents have been conducting a counterterrorism investigation in the east coast city of Sydney since another 16-year-old boy stabbed an Assyrian Orthodox bishop and priest in a church on April 15.\n\nThat boy has been charged with committing a terrorist act. Six of his alleged associates have also been charged with a range of offences, including conspiring to engage in or planning a terrorist act. All remain in custody.\n\nPrime Minister Anthony Albanese said he had been briefed on the latest stabbing in Perth by Australian federal police commissioner Reece Kershaw and ASIO director-general Mike Burgess, who heads the nation's main domestic spy agency.\n\n\"I'm advised there is no ongoing threat to the community on the information available,\" Mr Albanese said.\n\n\"We are a peace-loving nation and there is no place for violent extremism in Australia,\" he added.\n\nPolice received an emergency phone call after 10pm from a teenager saying he was going to commit acts of violence, Western Australian police commissioner Col Blanch said.\n\nThe boy had been participating in a programme for young people at risk of radicalisation, Mr Blanch added.\n\n\"I don't want to say he has been radicalised or is radicalised because I think that forms part of the investigation,\" he said.\n\nPolice said they were later alerted by a phone call from a member of the public that a knife attack was underway in the parking lot.\n\nThree police officers responded, one armed with a gun and two with tasers.\n\nPolice deployed both tasers but they failed to incapacitate the boy before he was killed by a single gunshot, Mr Blanch said.\n\nMr Blanch said members of the local Muslim community had raised concerns with police about the boy's behaviour before he was killed on Saturday.\n\nThe Imam of Perth's largest mosque, the Nasir Mosque, condemned the stabbing.\n\n\"There is no place for violence in Islam,\" Imam Syed Wadood Janud said in a statement.\n\n\"We appreciate the effort of the police to keep our communities safe. AP\n\nThat boy has been charged with committing a terrorist act. {"uri": "8111986291", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "07:01:42", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T07:01:42Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T07:01:15Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7843137383460999, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/wires/pa/article-13384263/Police-shoot-dead-radicalised-teenager-stabbed-man.html", "title": "Police shoot dead 'radicalised\u00b4 teenager after he stabbed man", "body": "A 16-year-old boy armed with a knife was shot dead by police after he stabbed a man in the Australian west coast city of Perth.\n\nThe incident occurred in the car park of a hardware store in suburban Willetton on Saturday night.\n\nThe teenager attacked the man and then rushed at police officers before he was shot, Western Australian premier Roger Cook told reporters on Sunday.\n\n\"There are indications he had been radicalised online,\" Mr Cook told a news conference.\n\nWestern Australian premier Roger Cook said there indications the boy had been radicalised (Australian Broadcasting Corporation via AP)\n\n\"But I want to reassure the community at this stage it appears that he acted solely and alone,\" he added.\n\nA man in his 30s was found at the scene with a stab wound to his back. He was taken to a hospital in a serious but stable condition, a police statement said.\n\nPolice and Australian Security Intelligence Organisation (ASIO) agents have been conducting a counterterrorism investigation in the east coast city of Sydney since another 16-year-old boy stabbed an Assyrian Orthodox bishop and priest in a church on April 15.\n\nThat boy has been charged with committing a terrorist act. Six of his alleged associates have also been charged with a range of offences, including conspiring to engage in or planning a terrorist act. All remain in custody.\n\nWestern Australian police commissioner Col Blanch said the boy was involved in a programme for young people at risk of radicalisation (Australian Broadcasting Corporation via AP)\n\nPrime Minister Anthony Albanese said he had been briefed on the latest stabbing in Perth by Australian federal police commissioner Reece Kershaw and ASIO director-general Mike Burgess, who heads the nation's main domestic spy agency.\n\n\"I'm advised there is no ongoing threat to the community on the information available,\" Mr Albanese said.\n\n\"We are a peace-loving nation and there is no place for violent extremism in Australia,\" he added.\n\nPolice received an emergency phone call after 10pm from a teenager saying he was going to commit acts of violence, Western Australian police commissioner Col Blanch said.\n\nThe boy had been participating in a programme for young people at risk of radicalisation, Mr Blanch added.\n\n\"I don't want to say he has been radicalised or is radicalised because I think that forms part of the investigation,\" he said.\n\nPolice said they were later alerted by a phone call from a member of the public that a knife attack was underway in the parking lot.\n\nThree police officers responded, one armed with a gun and two with tasers.\n\nPolice deployed both tasers but they failed to incapacitate the boy before he was killed by a single gunshot, Mr Blanch said.\n\nMr Blanch said members of the local Muslim community had raised concerns with police about the boy's behaviour before he was killed on Saturday.\n\nThe Imam of Perth's largest mosque, the Nasir Mosque, condemned the stabbing.\n\n\"There is no place for violence in Islam,\" Imam Syed Wadood Janud said in a statement.\n\n\"We appreciate the effort of the police to keep our communities safe. I also want to commend the local Muslim community who had flagged the individual prior with the police,\" Mr Wadood added.\n\nSome Muslim leaders have criticised Australian police for declaring last month's church stabbing a terrorist act but not a rampage two days earlier in a Sydney shopping mall in which six people were killed and a dozen wounded.\n\nThe 40-year-old attacker in the mall attack was shot dead by police. Police have yet to reveal the man's motive.\n\nThe church attack is only the third to be classified by Australian authorities as a terrorist act since 2018.\n\nIn December 2022, three Christian fundamentalists shot dead two police officers and a bystander in an ambush near the community of Wieambilla in Queensland state. The attackers were later killed by police.\n\nIn November 2018, a Somalia-born Muslim stabbed three pedestrians in downtown Melbourne, killing one, before police shot him dead.", "source": {"uri": He was taken to a hospital in a serious but stable condition, a police statement said.\n\nPolice and Australian Security Intelligence Organisation (ASIO) agents have been conducting a counterterrorism investigation in the east coast city of Sydney since another 16-year-old boy stabbed an Assyrian Orthodox bishop and priest in a church on April 15.\n\nThat boy has been charged with committing a terrorist act. He was taken to a hospital in a serious but stable condition, a police statement said.\n\nPolice and Australian Security Intelligence Organisation (ASIO) agents have been conducting a counterterrorism investigation in the east coast city of Sydney since another 16-year-old boy stabbed an Assyrian Orthodox bishop and priest in a church on April 15.\n\nThat boy has been charged with committing a terrorist act. Six of his alleged associates have also been charged with a range of offences, including conspiring to engage in or planning a terrorist act. All remain in custody.\n\nPrime Minister Anthony Albanese said he had been briefed on the latest stabbing in Perth by Australian federal police commissioner Reece Kershaw and ASIO director-general Mike Burgess, who heads the nation's main domestic spy agency.\n\n\"I'm advised there is no ongoing threat to the community on the information available,\" Mr Albanese said.\n\n\"We are a peace-loving nation and there is no place for violent extremism in Australia,\" he added.\n\nPolice received an emergency phone call after 10pm from a teenager saying he was going to commit acts of violence, Western Australian police commissioner Col Blanch said.\n\nThe boy had been participating in a programme for young people at risk of radicalisation, Mr Blanch added.\n\n\"I don't want to say he has been radicalised or is radicalised because I think that forms part of the investigation,\" he said.\n\nPolice said they were later alerted by a phone call from a member of the public that a knife attack was underway in the parking lot.\n\nThree police officers responded, one armed with a gun and two with tasers.\n\nPolice deployed both tasers but they failed to incapacitate the boy before he was killed by a single gunshot, Mr Blanch said.\n\nMr Blanch said members of the local Muslim community had raised concerns with police about the boy's behaviour before he was killed on Saturday.\n\nThe Imam of Perth's largest mosque, the Nasir Mosque, condemned the stabbing.\n\n\"There is no place for violence in Islam,\" Imam Syed Wadood Janud said in a statement.\n\n\"We appreciate the effort of the police to keep our communities safe. I also want to commend the local Muslim community who had flagged the individual prior with the police,\" Mr Wadood added.\n\nSome Muslim leaders have criticised Australian police for declaring last month's church stabbing a terrorist act but not a rampage two days earlier in a Sydney shopping mall in which six people were killed and a dozen wounded.\n\nThe 40-year-old attacker in the mall attack was shot dead by police. Police have yet to reveal the man's motive.\n\nThe church attack is only the third to be classified by Australian authorities as a terrorist act since 2018.\n\nIn December 2022, three Christian fundamentalists shot dead two police officers and a bystander in an ambush near the community of Wieambilla in Queensland state. The attackers were later killed by police.\n\nIn November 2018, a Somalia-born Muslim stabbed three pedestrians in downtown Melbourne, killing one, before police shot him dead.", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "2024-05-345317416", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "09:32:36", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T09:32:36Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-04T22:59:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7803921699523926, "url": "https://www.usnews.com/news/world/articles/2024-05-05/australian-police-shoot-dead-a-boy-16-armed-with-a-knife-after-he-stabbed-a-man-in-perth", "title": "Australian Police Shoot Dead a Boy, 16, Armed With a Knife After He Stabbed a Man in Perth", "body": "In this image from a video, Western Australian Premier Roger Cook speaks at a press conference in Perth, Australia Sunday, May 5, 2024. A 16-year-old boy armed with a knife was shot dead by police after he stabbed a man in the Australian west coast city of Perth, officials said Sunday. (Australian Broadcasting Corporation via AP)\n\nMELBOURNE, Australia (AP) -- A 16-year-old boy armed with a knife was shot dead by police after he stabbed a man in the Australian west coast city of Perth, officials said Sunday.\n\nThe incident occurred in the parking lot of a hardware store in suburban Willetton on Saturday night.\n\nThe teen attacked the man and then rushed at police officers before he was shot, Western Australian Premier Roger Cook told reporters on Sunday.\n\n\"There are indications he had been radicalized online,\" Cook told a news conference.\n\n\"But I want to reassure the community at this stage it appears that he acted solely and alone,\" Cook added.\n\nA man in his 30s was found at the scene with a stab wound to his back. He was taken to a hospital in serious but stable condition, a police statement said.\n\nPolice and Australian Security Intelligence Organization agents have been conducting a counterterrorism investigation in the east coast city of Sydney since another 16-year-old boy stabbed an Assyrian Orthodox bishop and priest in a church on April 15.\n\nThat boy has been charged with committing a terrorist act. Six of his alleged associates have also been charged with a range of offenses, including conspiring to engage in or planning a terrorist act. All remain in custody.\n\nPrime Minister Anthony Albanese said he had been briefed on the latest stabbing in Perth by Australian Federal Police Commissioner Reece Kershaw and ASIO Director-General Mike Burgess, who heads the nation's main domestic spy agency.\n\n\"I'm advised there is no ongoing threat to the community on the information available,\" Albanese said.\n\n\"We are a peace-loving nation and there is no place for violent extremism in Australia,\" he added.\n\nPolice received an emergency phone call after 10 p.m. from a teenager saying he was going to commit acts of violence, Western Australian Police Commissioner Col Blanch said.\n\nThe boy had been participating in a program for young people at risk of radicalization, Blanch added.\n\n\"I don't want to say he has been radicalized or is radicalized because I think that forms part of the investigation,\" he said.\n\nPolice said they were later alerted by a phone call from a member of the public that a knife attack was underway in the parking lot. Three police officers responded, one armed with a gun and two with conducted energy devices.\n\nPolice deployed both conducted energy devices but they failed to incapacitate the boy before he was killed by a single gunshot, Blanch said.\n\nBlanch said members of the local Muslim community had raised concerns with police about the boy's behavior before he was killed on Saturday.\n\nThe Imam of Perth's largest mosque, the Nasir Mosque, condemned the stabbing.\n\n\"There is no place for violence in Islam,\" Imam Syed Wadood Janud said in a statement.\n\n\"We appreciate the effort of the police to keep our communities safe. I also want to commend the local Muslim community who had flagged the individual prior with the police,\" Wadood added.\n\nSome Muslim leaders have criticized Australian police for declaring last month's church stabbing a terrorist act but not a rampage two days earlier in a Sydney shopping mall in which six people were killed and a dozen wounded. The 40-year-old attacker in the mall attack was shot dead by police. Police have yet to reveal the man's motive.\n\nThe church attack is only the third to be classified by Australian authorities as a terrorist act since 2018.\n\nIn December 2022, three Christian fundamentalists shot dead two police officers and a bystander in an ambush near the community of Wieambilla in Queensland state. The shooters were later killed by police.\n\nIn November 2018, a Somalia-born Muslim stabbed three pedestrians in downtown Melbourne, killing one, before police shot him dead.\n\nCopyright 2024 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. {"uri": "8112619383", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "17:23:59", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T17:23:59Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T17:22:24Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.772549033164978, "url": "https://www.newagebd.net/post/oceania/234428/16-year-old-shot-dead-by-police-in-australia", "title": "16-year-old shot dead by police in Australia", "body": "Western Australian police shot and killed a 'radicalised' 16-year-old boy with a knife who had stabbed a man in a Perth car park, police and the state premier said on Sunday.\n\nThe teenager 'rushed' at police who responded by shooting him twice with Tasers before firing a single fatal shot, they said.\n\n'There are indications he had been radicalised online. But I want to reassure the community at this stage it appears he acted solely and alone,' Premier Roger Cook said.\n\nPolice received a call late on Saturday from a male warning that he was going to commit 'acts of violence' but without giving his name or location, the state's police commissioner, Col Blanch, told reporters.\n\nWithin minutes, another emergency call alerted police that a 'male with a knife was running around the car park' in Willetton, a southern suburb of Perth, he said.\n\nPolice body camera images showed the teenager refused officers' demands that he put down the knife, the police chief said.\n\nThe weapon was a 30-centimetre kitchen knife, believed to be from the attacker's home, he said.\n\nOfficers fired two Tasers at him but 'both of them did not have the full desired effect,' he said.\n\n'The male continued to advance on the third officer with a firearm who fired a single shot and fatally wounded the male.'\n\nThe teenager died in hospital later in the night, he said.\n\nThe 'middle-aged' man who had been stabbed was in a 'serious' but stable condition and appeared to be doing well, the police commissioner said.\n\nThe man had suffered a single, 'possibly' two centimetre stab wound that may have punctured a lung, he said.\n\nPolice believe the teenager sent 'relevant messages' to some members of the Muslim community who immediately called police, he said, without giving details of the messages.\n\nThe boy had 'mental issues but also online radicalisation issues', the police chief said.\n\nIn the past two years, the attacker had been part of a 'countering violence extremism programme' for people who show signs of 'religious or issues-motivated' concerns, he said.\n\n'It is not a criminal based approach but it is a programme to help individuals who are expressing ideologies that are of concern in our community. But they may not be committing any crimes.'\n\nPolice said they did not know what had triggered the attack.\n\nBlanch said it had the 'hallmarks' of a terrorist incident but he was not making an official declaration right now as he had no concerns about a wider network being involved.\n\nAustralian prime minister Anthony Albanese said he had been briefed by police and intelligence services who had advised there was no 'on-going threat'.\n\n'We are a peace-loving nation and there is no place for violent extremism in Australia,' he said in a message on social media.\n\nDespite the rarity of such violent crimes in Australia, the Perth attack comes less than a month after a knife-wielding assailant killed six people in a shopping mall in Sydney.\n\nThe mentally ill knifeman, 40-year-old Joel Cauchi, was tracked down, shot and killed by a police inspector.\n\nCauchi's parents say he was diagnosed with schizophrenia at 17 but stopped taking medication, later leaving their Queensland home and dropping out of treatment.\n\nTwo days after the mall attack an Assyrian Christian bishop was brutally stabbed during a live streamed service in western Sydney.\n\nThe bishop has since But I want to reassure the community at this stage it appears he acted solely and alone,\" Premier Roger Cook said.\n\nPolice received a call late on Saturday from a male warning that he was going to commit \"acts of violence\" but without giving his name or location, the state's police commissioner, Col Blanch, told reporters.\n\nWithin minutes, another emergency call alerted police that a \"male with a knife was running around the car park\" in Willetton, a southern suburb of Perth, he said.\n\nPolice body camera images showed the teenager refused officers' demands that he put down the knife, the police chief said.\n\nThe weapon was a 30-centimetre (one-foot) kitchen knife, believed to be from the attacker's home, he said.\n\nOfficers fired two Tasers at him but \"both of them did not have the full desired effect,\" he said.\n\n\"The male continued to advance on the third officer with a firearm who fired a single shot and fatally wounded the male.\"\n\nThe teenager died in hospital later in the night, he said.\n\n'Online radicalisation'\n\nThe \"middle-aged\" man who had been stabbed was in a \"serious\" but stable condition and appeared to be doing well, the police commissioner said.\n\nThe man had suffered a single, \"possibly\" two centimetre stab wound that may have punctured a lung, he said.\n\nThe boy had \"mental issues but also online radicalisation issues\", the police chief said.\n\nIn the past two years, the attacker had been part of a \"countering violence extremism programme\" for people who show signs of \"religious or issues-motivated\" concerns, he said.\n\n\"It is not a criminal based approach but it is a programme to help individuals who are expressing ideologies that are of concern in our community. But they may not be committing any crimes.\"\n\nPolice said they did not know what had triggered the attack.\n\nBlanch said it had the \"hallmarks\" of a terrorist incident but he was not making an official declaration right now as he had no concerns about a wider network being involved.\n\nAustralian Prime Minister Anthony Albanese said he had been briefed by police and intelligence services who had advised there was no \"ongoing threat\".\n\n\"We are a peace-loving nation and there is no place for violent extremism in Australia,\" he said in a message on social media.\n\nRecent knife attacks\n\nDespite the rarity of such violent crimes in Australia, the Perth attack comes less than a month after a knife-wielding assailant killed six people in a shopping mall in Sydney.\n\nThe mentally ill knifeman, 40-year-old Joel Cauchi, was tracked down, shot and killed by a police inspector.\n\nCauchi's parents say he was diagnosed with schizophrenia at 17 but stopped taking medication, later leaving their Queensland home and dropping out of treatment.\n\nTwo days after the mall attack an Assyrian Christian bishop was brutally stabbed during a live streamed service in {"uri": "2024-05-345303552", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "09:27:37", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T09:27:37Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T03:14:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7686274647712708, "url": "https://www.channelnewsasia.com/world/australia-perth-stabbing-16-year-old-boy-radicalised-4314036", "title": "'Radicalised' teenager shot dead by Perth police after stabbing incident", "body": "Australian police said on Sunday (May 5) they shot dead a 16-year-old boy, after a man was stabbed in a Perth suburb, in an attack authorities said indicated terrorism.\n\nThe \"middle-aged\" victim, stabbed in the back, was stable in hospital, authorities said.\n\nThe 16-year-old boy, described as \"Caucasian\", was known to the police. Col Blanch, the police commissioner of the state of Western Australia, said the boy had mental health issues and had been part of a police deradicalisation programme.\n\nSpeaking at a news conference, state premier Roger Cook said: \"There are indications he had been radicalised online. But I want to reassure the community at this stage it appears he acted solely and alone.\"\n\nThe boy was holding a large kitchen knife when police arrived at a car park in the suburb of Willetton after 10pm on Saturday night.\n\nCommissioner Blanch said the boy had called the police and told them he had planned to commit \"acts of violence\".\n\nTwo officers initially shot him with their Tasers but neither had \"the full desired effect\", Blanch told reporters. A third officer then shot the boy with his firearm. The teenager died in hospital later in the night, he said.\n\nPolice body camera images showed the teenager refused officers' demands that he put down the knife, the police chief said.\n\nNOT \"TERRORIST ATTACK\" AT THIS STAGE\n\nPolice have confirmed the boy had been part of an online programme for the last few years aimed at young people \"exhibiting behaviours that are it might be religious or issues motivated concerns\".\n\n\"It is not a criminal-based approach,\" said Blanch. \"But it is a programme to help individuals who are expressing ideologies that are of concern in our community. But they may not be committing any crimes.\"\n\nPolice said they did not know what had triggered the attack.\n\nHowever, Blanch said the incident was not being labelled as a terrorist attack at this stage, while at the same time conceding that the stabbing \"certainly has the hallmarks of being one\". The boy was believed to be acting alone.\n\nAuthorities added they had received calls from concerned members of the local Muslim community before the attack.\n\nAustralian Prime Minister Anthony Albanese said he had been briefed by police and intelligence services who had advised there was no \"ongoing threat\".\n\n\"We are a peace-loving nation and there is no place for violent extremism in Australia,\" he said in a message on social media.\n\nThe incident comes after New South Wales police last month charged several boys with terrorism-related offences in investigations following the stabbing of an Assyrian Christian bishop while he was giving a live-streamed sermon in Sydney, on April 15.\n\nThe attack on the bishop came only days after a deadly mass stabbing in the Sydney beachside suburb of Bondi that claimed the lives of six people.\n\nGun and knife crime is rare in Australia, which consistently ranks among the safest countries in the world, according to the federal But I want to reassure the community at this stage it appears he acted solely and alone.\u201d\n\nPolice had received a call late on Saturday from a male warning that he was going to commit \u201cacts of violence\u201d but without giving his name or location, the state\u2019s police commissioner, Col Blanch, told reporters.\n\nWithin minutes another emergency call alerted police that a \u201cmale with a knife was running around the car park\u201d in Willetton, a southern suburb of Perth, he said.\u2018You are my son, I love you\u2019: stabbed Sydney bishop forgives attacker\n\nPolice body camera images showed the teenager refused officers\u2019 demands that he put down the knife, the police chief said.\n\nOfficers fired two tasers at him but \u201cboth of them did not have the full {"uri": "8111966998", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "06:40:25", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T06:40:25Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T06:39:51Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7647058963775635, "url": "https://jerseyeveningpost.com/morenews/worldnews/2024/05/05/police-shoot-dead-radicalised-teenager-after-he-stabbed-man/", "title": "Police shoot dead 'radicalised' teenager after he stabbed man", "body": "A 16-year-old boy armed with a knife was shot dead by police after he stabbed a man in the Australian west coast city of Perth.\n\nThe incident occurred in the car park of a hardware store in suburban Willetton on Saturday night.\n\nThe teenager attacked the man and then rushed at police officers before he was shot, Western Australian premier Roger Cook told reporters on Sunday.\n\n\"There are indications he had been radicalised online,\" Mr Cook told a news conference.\n\nA man in his 30s was found at the scene with a stab wound to his back. He was taken to a hospital in a serious but stable condition, a police statement said.\n\nPolice and Australian Security Intelligence Organisation (ASIO) agents have been conducting a counterterrorism investigation in the east coast city of Sydney since another 16-year-old boy stabbed an Assyrian Orthodox bishop and priest in a church on April 15.\n\nThat boy has been charged with committing a terrorist act. Six of his alleged associates have also been charged with a range of offences, including conspiring to engage in or planning a terrorist act. All remain in custody.\n\n\"I'm advised there is no ongoing threat to the community on the information available,\" Mr Albanese said.\n\n\"We are a peace-loving nation and there is no place for violent extremism in Australia,\" he added.\n\nPolice received an emergency phone call after 10pm from a teenager saying he was going to commit acts of violence, Western Australian police commissioner Col Blanch said.\n\nThe boy had been participating in a programme for young people at risk of radicalisation, Mr Blanch added.\n\n\"I don't want to say he has been radicalised or is radicalised because I think that forms part of the investigation,\" he said.\n\nPolice said they were later alerted by a phone call from a member of the public that a knife attack was underway in the parking lot.\n\nThree police officers responded, one armed with a gun and two with tasers.\n\nPolice deployed both tasers but they failed to incapacitate the boy before he was killed by a single gunshot, Mr Blanch said.\n\nMr Blanch said members of the local Muslim community had raised concerns with police about the boy's behaviour before he was killed on Saturday.\n\nThe Imam of Perth's largest mosque, the Nasir Mosque, condemned the stabbing.\n\n\"There is no place for violence in Islam,\" Imam Syed Wadood Janud said in a statement.\n\n\"We appreciate the effort of the police to keep our communities safe. I also want to commend the local Muslim community who had flagged the individual prior with the police,\" Mr Wadood added.\n\nSome Muslim leaders have criticised Australian police for declaring last month's church stabbing a terrorist act but not a rampage two days earlier in a Sydney shopping mall in which six people were killed and a dozen wounded.\n\nThe 40-year-old attacker in the mall attack was shot dead by police. Police have yet to reveal the man's motive.\n\nThe church attack is only the third to be classified by Australian authorities as a terrorist act since 2018.\n\nIn December 2022, three Christian fundamentalists shot dead two police officers and a bystander in an ambush near the community of Wieambilla in Queensland state. The attackers were later killed by police.\n\nIn November 2018, a Somalia-born Muslim stabbed three pedestrians in downtown Melbourne, killing one, before police shot him dead.", "source": {"uri": He was taken to a hospital in serious but stable condition, a police statement said.\n\nPolice received an emergency phone call after 10pm (local time) from a teenager saying he was going to commit acts of violence, Western Australian police commissioner Col Blanch said.\n\nThe boy had been participating in a programme for young people at risk of radicalisation, he added.\n\n\"I don't want to say he has been radicalised or is radicalised because I think that forms part of the investigation,\" he said.\n\nPolice said they were later alerted by a phone call from a member of the public that a knife attack was underway in the parking lot. Three police officers responded, one armed with a gun and two with conducted energy devices.\n\nMr Blanch said members of the local Muslim community had raised concerns with police about the teen's behaviour.\n\nPrime minister Anthony Albanese said he had been briefed on the latest stabbing in Perth. \"I'm advised there is no ongoing threat to the community on the information available,\" Mr Albanese said.\n\n\"We are a peace-loving nation and there is no place for violent extremism in Australia,\" he added.\n\nThe Imam of Perth's largest mosque, the Nasir Mosque, condemned the stabbing. \"There is no place for violence in Islam,\" Imam Syed Wadood Janud said.\n\n\"We appreciate the effort of the police to keep our communities safe. {"uri": "8112155430", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "09:48:34", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T09:48:34Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T09:47:28Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7647058963775635, "url": "https://www.cbc.ca/news/world/16-year-old-australian-stabbing-attack-shot-by-police-1.7194621", "title": "Australian police say 16-year-old shot after Perth stabbing may have been 'radicalized' online | CBC News", "body": "A 16-year-old boy armed with a knife was shot dead by police after he stabbed a man in the Australian west coast city of Perth, officials said Sunday.\n\nThe incident occurred in the parking lot of a hardware store in suburban Willetton on Saturday night.\n\nThe teen attacked the man and then rushed at police officers before he was shot, Western Australian Premier Roger Cook told reporters on Sunday.\n\n\"There are indications he had been radicalized online,\" Cook told a news conference.\n\n\"But I want to reassure the community at this stage it appears that he acted solely and alone,\" Cook added.\n\nA man in his 30s was found at the scene with a stab wound to his back. He was taken to a hospital in serious but stable condition, a police statement said.\n\nIt comes after Australian police said the attacker who fatally stabbed six people at a busy shopping centre in Sydney's beach suburb of Bondi may have targeted women.\n\nPolice and Australian Security Intelligence Organization agents have also been conducting a counterterrorism investigation in the east coast city of Sydney since another 16-year-old boy stabbed an Assyrian Orthodox bishop and priest in a church on April 15.\n\nThat boy has been charged with committing a terrorist act. Six of his alleged associates have also been charged with a range of offences, including conspiring to engage in or planning a terrorist act. All remain in custody.\n\nPrime Minister Anthony Albanese said he had been briefed on the latest stabbing in Perth by Australian Federal Police commissioner Reece Kershaw and ASIO director general Mike Burgess, who heads the nation's main domestic spy agency.\n\n\"I'm advised there is no ongoing threat to the community on the information available,\" Albanese said.\n\n\"We are a peace-loving nation and there is no place for violent extremism in Australia,\" he added.\n\nPolice received an emergency phone call after 10 p.m. from a teenager saying he was going to commit acts of violence, Western Australian police commissioner Col Blanch said.\n\nThe boy had been participating in a program for young people at risk of radicalization, Blanch added.\n\n\"I don't want to say he has been radicalized or is radicalized because I think that forms part of the investigation,\" he said.\n\nPolice said they were later alerted by a phone call from a member of the public that a knife attack was underway in the parking lot. Three police officers responded, one armed with a gun and two with conducted energy devices.\n\nPolice deployed both conducted energy devices but they failed to incapacitate the boy before he was killed by a single gunshot, Blanch said.\n\nBlanch said members of the local Muslim community had raised concerns with police about the boy's behaviour before he was killed on Saturday.\n\nThe imam of Perth's largest mosque, the Nasir Mosque, condemned the stabbing.\n\n\"There is no place for violence in Islam,\" Imam Syed Wadood Janud said in a statement.\n\n\"We appreciate the effort of the police to keep our communities safe. I also want to commend the local Muslim community who had flagged the individual prior with the police,\" Wadood added.\n\nSome Muslim leaders have criticized Australian police for declaring last month's church stabbing a terrorist act but not a rampage two days earlier in a Sydney shopping mall in which six people were killed and a dozen wounded. The 40-year-old attacker in the mall attack was shot dead by police. Police have yet to reveal the man's motive.\n\nThe church attack was the third to be classified by Australian authorities as a terrorist act since 2018.\n\nIn December 2022, three Christian fundamentalists shot dead two police officers and a bystander in an ambush near the community of Wieambilla in Queensland state. The shooters were later killed by police.\n\nIn November 2018, a Somalia-born Muslim stabbed three pedestrians in downtown Melbourne, killing one, before police shot him dead.", "source": {"uri": According to Australian Broadcasting Corp., he was taken to a hospital in serious but stable condition.\n\nOn April 15, a 16-year-old boy stabbed Bishop Mar Mari Emmanuel of the Christ The Good Shepherd Church in the Sydney suburb of Wakefield while giving a live-streamed sermon.\n\nAustralian police later said the boy and six of his alleged associates had been charged with terrorism-related offences following the stabbing of the Assyrian Christian bishop.\n\nPrime Minister Anthony Albanese said he had been briefed on the latest stabbing in Perth by Australian Federal Police Commissioner Reece Kershaw and ASIO Director-General Mike Burgess, who heads the nation's main domestic spy agency.\n\n\"I'm advised there is no ongoing threat to the community on the information available,\" Albanese said.\n\n\"We are a peace-loving nation and there is no place for violent extremism in Australia,\" he added.\n\nPolice received an emergency phone call after 10 p.m. from a teenager saying he was going to commit acts of violence, Western Australian Police Commissioner Col Blanch said.\n\nThe boy had been participating in a program for young people at risk of radicalization, Blanch added.\n\n\"I don't want to say he has been radicalized or is radicalized because I think that forms part of the investigation,\" he said.\n\nPolice said they were later alerted by a phone call from a member of the public that a knife attack was underway in the parking lot. {"uri": "2024-05-345453984", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "09:48:59", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T09:48:59Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T03:00:05Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7568627595901489, "url": "https://www.seattletimes.com/nation-world/australian-police-shoot-dead-a-16-year-old-boy-armed-with-a-knife-in-perth/", "title": "Australian police shoot dead a boy, 16, armed with a knife after he stabbed a man in Perth", "body": "MELBOURNE, Australia (AP) -- A 16-year-old boy armed with a knife was shot dead by police after he stabbed a man in the Australian west coast city of Perth, officials said Sunday.\n\nThe incident occurred in the parking lot of a hardware store in suburban Willetton on Saturday night.\n\nThe teen attacked the man and then rushed at police officers before he was shot, Western Australian Premier Roger Cook told reporters on Sunday.\n\n\"There are indications he had been radicalized online,\" Cook told a news conference.\n\n\"But I want to reassure the community at this stage it appears that he acted solely and alone,\" Cook added.\n\nA man in his 30s was found at the scene with a stab wound to his back. He was taken to a hospital in serious but stable condition, a police statement said.\n\nPolice and Australian Security Intelligence Organization agents have been conducting a counterterrorism investigation in the east coast city of Sydney since another 16-year-old boy stabbed an Assyrian Orthodox bishop and priest in a church on April 15.\n\nThat boy has been charged with committing a terrorist act. Six of his alleged associates have also been charged with a range of offenses, including conspiring to engage in or planning a terrorist act. All remain in custody.\n\nPrime Minister Anthony Albanese said he had been briefed on the latest stabbing in Perth by Australian Federal Police Commissioner Reece Kershaw and ASIO Director-General Mike Burgess, who heads the nation's main domestic spy agency.\n\n\"I'm advised there is no ongoing threat to the community on the information available,\" Albanese said.\n\n\"We are a peace-loving nation and there is no place for violent extremism in Australia,\" he added.\n\nPolice received an emergency phone call after 10 p.m. from a teenager saying he was going to commit acts of violence, Western Australian Police Commissioner Col Blanch said.\n\nThe boy had been participating in a program for young people at risk of radicalization, Blanch added.\n\n\"I don't want to say he has been radicalized or is radicalized because I think that forms part of the investigation,\" he said.\n\nPolice said they were later alerted by a phone call from a member of the public that a knife attack was underway in the parking lot. Three police officers responded, one armed with a gun and two with conducted energy devices.\n\nPolice deployed both conducted energy devices but they failed to incapacitate the boy before he was killed by a single gunshot, Blanch said.\n\nBlanch said members of the local Muslim community had raised concerns with police about the boy's behavior before he was killed on Saturday.\n\nThe Imam of Perth's largest mosque, the Nasir Mosque, condemned the stabbing.\n\n\"There is no place for violence in Islam,\" Imam Syed Wadood Janud said in a statement.\n\n\"We appreciate the effort of the police to keep our communities safe. I also want to commend the local Muslim community who had flagged the individual prior with the police,\" Wadood added.\n\nSome Muslim leaders have criticized Australian police for declaring last month's church stabbing a terrorist act but not a rampage two days earlier in a Sydney shopping mall in which six people were killed and a dozen wounded. The 40-year-old attacker in the mall attack was shot dead by police. Police have yet to reveal the man's motive.\n\nThe church attack is only the third to be classified by Australian authorities as a terrorist act since 2018.\n\nIn December 2022, three Christian fundamentalists shot dead two police officers and a bystander in an ambush near the community of Wieambilla in Queensland state. The shooters were later killed by police.\n\nIn November 2018, a Somalia-born Muslim stabbed three pedestrians in downtown Melbourne, killing one, before police shot him dead.", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "8111975250", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "06:49:40", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T06:49:40Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T06:49:05Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7568627595901489, "url": "https://www.irishexaminer.com/world/arid-41388709.html", "title": "Police shoot dead 'radicalised' teenager after he stabbed man", "body": "The incident occurred in the car park of a hardware store in suburban Willetton on Saturday night.\n\nThe teenager attacked the man and then rushed at police officers before he was shot, Western Australian premier Roger Cook told reporters on Sunday.\n\n\"There are indications he had been radicalised online,\" Mr Cook told a news conference.\n\n\"But I want to reassure the community at this stage it appears that he acted solely and alone,\" he added.\n\nA man in his 30s was found at the scene with a stab wound to his back. He was taken to a hospital in a serious but stable condition, a police statement said.\n\nPolice and Australian Security Intelligence Organisation (ASIO) agents have been conducting a counterterrorism investigation in the east coast city of Sydney since another 16-year-old boy stabbed an Assyrian Orthodox bishop and priest in a church on April 15.\n\nThat boy has been charged with committing a terrorist act. Six of his alleged associates have also been charged with a range of offences, including conspiring to engage in or planning a terrorist act. All remain in custody.\n\nPrime Minister Anthony Albanese said he had been briefed on the latest stabbing in Perth by Australian federal police commissioner Reece Kershaw and ASIO director-general Mike Burgess, who heads the nation's main domestic spy agency.\n\n\"I'm advised there is no ongoing threat to the community on the information available,\" Mr Albanese said.\n\n\"We are a peace-loving nation and there is no place for violent extremism in Australia,\" he added.\n\nPolice received an emergency phone call after 10pm from a teenager saying he was going to commit acts of violence, Western Australian police commissioner Col Blanch said.\n\nThe boy had been participating in a programme for young people at risk of radicalisation, Mr Blanch added.\n\n\"I don't want to say he has been radicalised or is radicalised because I think that forms part of the investigation,\" he said.\n\nPolice said they were later alerted by a phone call from a member of the public that a knife attack was underway in the parking lot.\n\nThree police officers responded, one armed with a gun and two with tasers.\n\nPolice deployed both tasers but they failed to incapacitate the boy before he was killed by a single gunshot, Mr Blanch said.\n\nMr Blanch said members of the local Muslim community had raised concerns with police about the boy's behaviour before he was killed on Saturday.\n\nThe Imam of Perth's largest mosque, the Nasir Mosque, condemned the stabbing.\n\n\"There is no place for violence in Islam,\" Imam Syed Wadood Janud said in a statement.\n\n\"We appreciate the effort of the police to keep our communities safe. I also want to commend the local Muslim community who had flagged the individual prior with the police,\" Mr Wadood added.\n\nSome Muslim leaders have criticised Australian police for declaring last month's church stabbing a terrorist act but not a rampage two days earlier in a Sydney shopping mall in which six people were killed and a dozen wounded.\n\nThe 40-year-old attacker in the mall attack was shot dead by police. Police have yet to reveal the man's motive.\n\nThe church attack is only the third to be classified by Australian authorities as a terrorist act since 2018.\n\nIn December 2022, three Christian fundamentalists shot dead two police officers and a bystander in an ambush near the community of Wieambilla in Queensland state. The attackers were later killed by police.\n\nIn November 2018, a Somalia-born Muslim stabbed three pedestrians in downtown Melbourne, killing one, before police shot him dead.", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "8112101072", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "08:56:41", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T08:56:41Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T08:56:04Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7568627595901489, "url": "http://www.naharnet.com/stories/en/305011", "title": "'Radicalized' 16-year-old attacker shot dead by police in Australia", "body": "Western Australian police shot and killed a \"radicalized\" 16-year-old boy with a knife who had stabbed a man in a Perth car park, police and the state premier said Sunday.\n\nThe teenager \"rushed\" at police who responded by shooting him twice with Tasers before firing a single fatal shot, they said.\n\n\"There are indications he had been radicalized online. But I want to reassure the community at this stage it appears he acted solely and alone,\" Premier Roger Cook said.\n\nPolice received a call late on Saturday from a male warning that he was going to commit \"acts of violence\" but without giving his name or location, the state's police commissioner, Col Blanch, told reporters.\n\nWithin minutes, another emergency call alerted police that a \"male with a knife was running around the car park\" in Willetton, a southern suburb of Perth, he said.\n\nPolice body camera images showed the teenager refused officers' demands that he put down the knife, the police chief said.\n\nThe weapon was a 30-centimeter kitchen knife, believed to be from the attacker's home, he said.\n\nOfficers fired two Tasers at him but \"both of them did not have the full desired effect,\" he said.\n\n\"The male continued to advance on the third officer with a firearm who fired a single shot and fatally wounded the male.\"\n\nThe teenager died in hospital later in the night, he said.\n\n- 'Online radicalization' -\n\nThe \"middle-aged\" man who had been stabbed was in a \"serious\" but stable condition and appeared to be doing well, the police commissioner said.\n\nThe man had suffered a single, \"possibly\" two centimetre stab wound that may have punctured a lung, he said.\n\nPolice believe the teenager sent \"relevant messages\" to some members of the Muslim community who immediately called police, he said, without giving details of the messages.\n\nThe boy had \"mental issues but also online radicalization issues,\" the police chief said.\n\nIn the past two years, the attacker had been part of a \"countering violence extremism program\" for people who show signs of \"religious or issues-motivated\" concerns, he said.\n\n\"It is not a criminal based approach but it is a programme to help individuals who are expressing ideologies that are of concern in our community. But they may not be committing any crimes.\"\n\nPolice said they did not know what had triggered the attack.\n\nBlanch said it had the \"hallmarks\" of a terrorist incident but he was not making an official declaration right now as he had no concerns about a wider network being involved.\n\nAustralian Prime Minister Anthony Albanese said he had been briefed by police and intelligence services who had advised there was no \"ongoing threat\".\n\n\"We are a peace-loving nation and there is no place for violent extremism in Australia,\" he said in a message on social media.\n\n- Recent knife attacks -\n\nDespite the rarity of such violent crimes in Australia, the Perth attack comes less than a month after a knife-wielding assailant killed six people in a shopping mall in Sydney.\n\nThe mentally ill knifeman, 40-year-old Joel Cauchi, was tracked down, shot and killed by a police inspector.\n\nCauchi's parents say he was diagnosed with schizophrenia at 17 but stopped taking medication, later leaving their Queensland home and dropping out of treatment.\n\nTwo days after the mall attack an Assyrian Christian bishop was brutally stabbed during a live streamed service in western Sydney.\n\nThe bishop has since recovered and a 16-year-old suspect has been charged with committing \"a terrorist act.\"", "source": {"uri": "naharnet.com", "dataType": "news", "title": {"uri": "8111922907", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "05:54:19", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T05:54:19Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T05:51:11Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7568627595901489, "url": "https://kion546.com/ap-national/2024/05/04/australian-police-shoot-dead-a-16-year-old-boy-armed-with-a-knife-in-perth/", "title": "Australian police shoot dead a boy, 16, armed with a knife after he stabbed a man in Perth - KION546", "body": "MELBOURNE, Australia (AP) -- A 16-year-old boy armed with a knife was shot dead by police after he stabbed a man in the Australian west coast city of Perth, officials said Sunday.\n\nThe incident occurred in the parking lot of a hardware store in suburban Willetton on Saturday night.\n\nThe teen attacked the man and then rushed at police officers before he was shot, Western Australian Premier Roger Cook told reporters on Sunday.\n\n\"There are indications he had been radicalized online,\" Cook told a news conference.\n\n\"But I want to reassure the community at this stage it appears that he acted solely and alone,\" Cook added.\n\nA man in his 30s was found at the scene with a stab wound to his back. He was taken to a hospital in serious but stable condition, a police statement said.\n\nPolice and Australian Security Intelligence Organization agents have been conducting a counterterrorism investigation in the east coast city of Sydney since another 16-year-old boy stabbed an Assyrian Orthodox bishop and priest in a church on April 15.\n\nThat boy has been charged with committing a terrorist act. Six of his alleged associates have also been charged with a range of offenses, including conspiring to engage in or planning a terrorist act. All remain in custody.\n\nPrime Minister Anthony Albanese said he had been briefed on the latest stabbing in Perth by Australian Federal Police Commissioner Reece Kershaw and ASIO Director-General Mike Burgess, who heads the nation's main domestic spy agency.\n\n\"I'm advised there is no ongoing threat to the community on the information available,\" Albanese said.\n\n\"We are a peace-loving nation and there is no place for violent extremism in Australia,\" he added.\n\nPolice received an emergency phone call after 10 p.m. from a teenager saying he was going to commit acts of violence, Western Australian Police Commissioner Col Blanch said.\n\nThe boy had been participating in a program for young people at risk of radicalization, Blanch added.\n\n\"I don't want to say he has been radicalized or is radicalized because I think that forms part of the investigation,\" he said.\n\nPolice said they were later alerted by a phone call from a member of the public that a knife attack was underway in the parking lot. Three police officers responded, one armed with a gun and two with conducted energy devices.\n\nPolice deployed both conducted energy devices but they failed to incapacitate the boy before he was killed by a single gunshot, Blanch said.\n\nBlanch said members of the local Muslim community had raised concerns with police about the boy's behavior before he was killed on Saturday.\n\nThe Imam of Perth's largest mosque, the Nasir Mosque, condemned the stabbing.\n\n\"There is no place for violence in Islam,\" Imam Syed Wadood Janud said in a statement.\n\n\"We appreciate the effort of the police to keep our communities safe. I also want to commend the local Muslim community who had flagged the individual prior with the police,\" Wadood added.\n\nSome Muslim leaders have criticized Australian police for declaring last month's church stabbing a terrorist act but not a rampage two days earlier in a Sydney shopping mall in which six people were killed and a dozen wounded. The 40-year-old attacker in the mall attack was shot dead by police. Police have yet to reveal the man's motive.\n\nThe church attack is only the third to be classified by Australian authorities as a terrorist act since 2018.\n\nIn December 2022, three Christian fundamentalists shot dead two police officers and a bystander in an ambush near the community of Wieambilla in Queensland state. The shooters were later killed by police.\n\nIn November 2018, a Somalia-born Muslim stabbed three pedestrians in downtown Melbourne, killing one, before police shot him dead.", "source": {"uri": He was taken to a hospital in serious but stable condition, Australian Broadcasting Corp. reported.\n\nPolice and Australian Security Intelligence Organization agents have been conducting a counterterrorism investigation in the east coast city of Sydney since another 16-year-old boy stabbed an Assyrian Orthodox bishop and priest in a church on April 15.\n\nThat boy has been charged with committing a terrorist act. {"uri": "8111963157", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "06:35:58", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T06:35:58Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T06:35:33Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7490196228027344, "url": "https://www.thejournal.ie/teen-shot-dead-by-police-in-perth-austrailia-6372111-May2024/", "title": "'Radicalised' 16-year-old boy who stabbed man in car park shot dead by police in Australia", "body": "Police received a call late on Saturday from a male warning that he was going to commit \"acts of violence\" but without giving his name or location.\n\nWESTERN AUSTRALIAN POLICE shot and killed a \"radicalised\" 16-year-old boy with a knife who had stabbed a man in a Perth car park, police said Sunday.\n\nThe teenager \"rushed\" at police who responded by shooting him twice with Tasers before firing a single fatal shot, they said.\n\n\"There are indications he had been radicalised online. But I want to reassure the community at this stage it appears he acted solely and alone,\" Premier Roger Cook said.\n\nPolice received a call late on Saturday from a male warning that he was going to commit \"acts of violence\" but without giving his name or location, the state's police commissioner, Col Blanch, told reporters.\n\nWithin minutes, another emergency call alerted police that a \"male with a knife was running around the car park\" in Willetton, a southern suburb of Perth, he said.\n\nPolice body camera images showed the teenager refused officers' demands that he put down the knife, the police chief said.\n\nThe weapon was a 30-centimetre (one-foot) kitchen knife, believed to be from the attacker's home, he said.\n\nOfficers fired two Tasers at him but \"both of them did not have the full desired effect,\" he said.\n\n\"The male continued to advance on the third officer with a firearm who fired a single shot and fatally wounded the male.\"\n\nThe teenager died in hospital later in the night, he said.\n\n'Online radicalisation'\n\nThe \"middle-aged\" man who had been stabbed was in a \"serious\" but stable condition and appeared to be doing well, the police commissioner said.\n\nThe man had suffered a single, \"possibly\" two centimetre stab wound that may have punctured a lung, he said.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nPolice believe the teenager sent \"relevant messages\" to some members of the Muslim community who immediately called police, he said, without giving details of the messages.\n\nThe boy had \"mental issues but also online radicalisation issues\", the police chief said.\n\nIn the past two years, the attacker had been part of a \"countering violence extremism programme\" for people who show signs of \"religious or issues-motivated\" concerns, he said.\n\n\"It is not a criminal based approach but it is a programme to help individuals who are expressing ideologies that are of concern in our community. But they may not be committing any crimes.\"\n\nPolice said they did not know what had triggered the attack.\n\nBlanch said it had the \"hallmarks\" of a terrorist incident but he was not making an official declaration right now as he had no concerns about a wider network being involved.\n\nAustralian Prime Minister Anthony Albanese said he had been briefed by police and intelligence services who had advised there was no \"ongoing threat\".\n\n\"We are a peace-loving nation and there is no place for violent extremism in Australia,\" he said in a message on social media.\n\nRecent knife attacks\n\nDespite the rarity of such violent crimes in Australia, the Perth attack comes less than a month after a knife-wielding assailant killed six people in a shopping mall in Sydney.\n\nThe mentally ill knifeman, 40-year-old Joel Cauchi, was tracked down, shot and killed by a police inspector.\n\nCauchi's parents say he was diagnosed with schizophrenia at 17 but stopped taking medication, later leaving their Queensland home and dropping out of treatment.\n\nTwo days after the mall attack an Assyrian Christian bishop was brutally stabbed during a live streamed service in western Sydney.\n\nThe bishop has since recovered and a 16-year-old suspect has been charged with committing \"a terrorist act\".\n\n\u00a9 Agence France-Presse", "source": {"uri": "thejournal.ie", {"uri": "8111996228", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "07:11:25", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T07:11:25Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T07:10:36Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7450980544090271, "url": "https://manilastandard.net/news/314443365/radicalized-teen-shot-dead-by-police-in-australia.html", "title": "'Radicalized' teen shot dead by police in Australia - Manila Standard", "body": "Sydney, Australia -- Western Australian police shot and killed a \"radicalized\" 16-year-old boy with a knife, who had stabbed a man in a Perth car park, police and the state premier said Sunday.\n\nThe teenager \"rushed\" at police who responded by shooting him twice with Tasers before firing a single fatal shot, they said.\n\n\"There are indications he had been radicalized online. But I want to reassure the community at this stage it appears he acted solely and alone,\" Premier Roger Cook said.\n\nPolice received a call late on Saturday from a male warning that he was going to commit \"acts of violence,\" but without giving his name or location, the state's police commissioner, Col Blanch, told reporters.\n\nWithin minutes, another emergency call alerted police that a \"male with a knife was running around the car park\" in Willetton, a southern suburb of Perth, he said.\n\nPolice body camera images showed the teenager refused officers' demands that he put down the knife, the police chief said.\n\nThe weapon was a 30-centimeter (one-foot) kitchen knife, believed to be from the attacker's home, he said.\n\nOfficers fired two Tasers at him, but \"both of them did not have the full desired effect,\" he said.\n\n\"The male continued to advance on the third officer with a firearm who fired a single shot and fatally wounded the male.\"\n\nThe teenager died in hospital later in the night, he said.\n\n'Online radicalization'\n\nThe \"middle-aged\" man who had been stabbed was in a \"serious\" but stable condition and appeared to be doing well, the police commissioner said.\n\nThe man had suffered a single, \"possibly\" two-centimeter stab wound that may have punctured a lung, he said.\n\nPolice believe the teenager sent \"relevant messages\" to some members of the Muslim community, who immediately called police, he said, without giving details of the messages.\n\nThe boy had \"mental issues but also online radicalization issues,\" the police chief said.\n\nIn the past two years, the attacker had been part of a \"countering violence extremism program\" for people who show signs of \"religious or issues-motivated\" concerns, he said.\n\n\"It is not a criminal based approach, but it is a program to help individuals who are expressing ideologies that are of concern in our community. But they may not be committing any crimes.\"\n\nPolice said they did not know what had triggered the attack.\n\nBlanch said it had the \"hallmarks\" of a terrorist incident, but he was not making an official declaration right now as he had no concerns about a wider network being involved.\n\nAustralian Prime Minister Anthony Albanese said he had been briefed by police and intelligence services
