"body": "Police in Western Australia have shot dead a boy after he stabbed a man in Perth, in an attack authorities said indicated terrorism.\n\nThere were signs the 16-year-old, armed with a kitchen knife, had been radicalised online, state authorities said, adding they received calls from concerned members of the local Muslim community before the attack, which occurred late on Saturday night.\n\nThe apparently random attack, in the car park of a hardware store in the suburb of Willetton, had \"hallmarks\" of terrorism but was yet to be declared a terrorist act, police said.\n\nState Police Commissioner Col Blanch said when police were called to the car park, the youth lunged at officers with the knife and was shot.\n\n\"At this stage it appears that he acted solely and alone,\" Western Australia Premier Roger Cook told a televised press conference in Perth, regarding the attacker.\n\nThe victim, stabbed in the back, was stable in hospital, authorities said.\n\nPrime Minister Anthony Albanese said he had been briefed on the incident by police and intelligence agencies, which advised there was no ongoing threat.\n\n\"We are a peace-loving nation and there is no place for {"uri": "8111818577", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "03:35:18", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T03:35:18Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T03:34:30Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7372549176216125, "url": "https://economictimes.indiatimes.com/news/international/world-news/radicalised-16-year-old-shot-dead-by-police-in-australia/articleshow/109851073.cms", "title": "'Radicalised' 16-year-old shot dead by police in Australia", "body": "The teenager \"rushed\" at police who responded by shooting him twice with Tasers before firing a single fatal shot, said police. \"There are indications he had been radicalised online. But I want to reassure the community at this stage it appears he acted solely and alone,\" Premier Roger Cook said.Sydney:Western Australian police shot and killed a \"radicalised\" 16-year-old boy with a knife who had stabbed a man in a Perth car park, police and the state premier said Sunday.\n\nThe teenager \"rushed\" at police who responded by shooting him twice with Tasers before firing a single fatal shot, they said.\n\n\"There are indications he had been radicalised online. But I want to reassure the community at this stage it appears he acted solely and alone,\" Premier Roger Cook said.\n\nPolice received a call late on Saturday from a male warning that he was going to commit \"acts of violence\" but without giving his name or location, the state's police commissioner, Col Blanch, told reporters.\n\nWithin minutes, another emergency call alerted police that a \"male with a knife was running around the car park\" in Willetton, a southern suburb of Perth, he said.\n\nPolice body camera images showed the teenager refused officers' demands that he put down the knife, the police chief said.\n\nOfficers fired two Tasers at him but \"both of them did not have the full desired effect,\" he said.\n\n\"The male continued to advance on the third officer with a firearm who fired a single shot and fatally wounded the male.\"\n\nThe teenager died in hospital later in the night, he said.\n\n'Online radicalisation'\n\nThe \"middle-aged\" man who was stabbed was in a \"serious\" but stable condition and appeared to be doing well, the police commissioner said.\n\nThe boy had \"mental issues but also online radicalisation issues\", he said.\n\nThe attacker had for the past couple of years been part of a \"countering violence extremism programme\" for people who show signs of \"religious or issues-motivated\" concerns, he said.\n\n\"It is not a criminal based approach but it is a programme to help individuals who are expressing ideologies that are of concern in our community. But they may not be committing any crimes.\"\n\nPolice said they did not know what had triggered the attack.\n\nDespite the rarity of such violent crimes in Australia, the Perth attack comes less than a month after a knife-wielding assailant killed six people in a shopping mall in Sydney.\n\nThe mentally ill knifeman, 40-year-old Joel Cauchi, was tracked down, shot and killed by a police inspector.\n\nCauchi's parents say he was diagnosed with schizophrenia at 17 but stopped taking medication, later leaving their Queensland home and dropping out of treatment.\n\nTwo days after the mall attack an Assyrian Christian bishop was brutally stabbed during a live streamed service in western Sydney.\n\nThe bishop has since recovered and a 16-year-old suspect has been charged with {"uri": "8112006572", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "07:22:25", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T07:22:25Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T07:20:50Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7372549176216125, "url": "https://www.thescottishsun.co.uk/news/12619276/radicalised-boy-shot-dead-knife-australia/", "title": "'Radicalised' boy, 16, is shot dead by cops after he stabs victim with knife", "body": "COPS shot and killed a \"radicalised\" 16-year-old boy who stabbed a man, 30, in a car park.\n\nThe teenager \"rushed\" at police in Perth, Australia who responded by shooting him twice with Tasers before firing a single fatal shot last night.\n\n\"There are indications he had been radicalised online. But I want to reassure the community at this stage it appears he acted solely and alone,\" Premier Roger Cook said.\n\nPolice received a call late on Saturday from a male warning that he was going to commit \"acts of violence\" but without giving his name or location, the state's police commissioner, Col Blanch, said.\n\nWithin minutes, another emergency call alerted police that a \"male with a knife was running around the car park\" in Willetton, a southern suburb of Perth, he said.\n\nPolice body camera images showed the teenager refused officers' demands that he put down the knife, the police chief said.\n\nThe weapon was a one foot kitchen knife, believed to be from the attacker's home, he said.\n\nOfficers fired two Tasers at him but \"both of them did not have the full desired effect,\" he said.\n\n\"The male continued to advance on the third officer with a firearm who fired a single shot and fatally wounded the male.\"\n\nThe teenager died in hospital later in the night, he said.\n\nThe victim who had been stabbed was in a \"serious\" but stable condition and appeared to be doing well, the police commissioner said.\n\nThe man had suffered a single, \"possibly\" two centimetre stab wound that may have punctured a lung, he said.\n\nPolice believe the teenager sent \"relevant messages\" to some members of the Muslim community who immediately called police, he said, without giving details of the messages.\n\nThe boy had \"mental issues but also online radicalisation issues\", the police chief said.\n\nIn the past two years, the attacker had been part of a \"countering violence extremism programme\" for people who show signs of \"religious or issues-motivated\" concerns, he said.\n\n\"It is not a criminal based approach but it is a programme to help individuals who are expressing ideologies that are of concern in our community. But they may not be committing any crimes.\"\n\nPolice said they did not know what had triggered the attack.\n\nBlanch said it had the \"hallmarks\" of a terrorist incident but he was not making an official declaration right now as he had no concerns about a wider network being involved.\n\nAustralian Prime Minister Anthony Albanese said he had been briefed by police and intelligence services who had advised there was no \"ongoing threat\".\n\n\"We are a peace-loving nation and there is no place for violent extremism in Australia,\" he said in a message on social media.\n\nMore to follow... But I want to reassure the community at this stage it appears he acted solely and alone,\" Premier Roger Cook said.\n\nPolice received a call late on Saturday from a male warning that he was going to commit \"acts of violence\" but without giving his name or location, the state's police commissioner, Col Blanch, told reporters.\n\nWithin minutes, another emergency call alerted police that a \"male with a knife was running around the car park\" in Willetton, a southern suburb of Perth, he said.\n\nPolice body camera images showed the teenager refused officers' demands that he put down the knife, the police chief said.\n\nOfficers fired two Tasers at him but \"both of them did not have the full desired effect,\" he said.\n\n\"The male continued to advance on the third officer with a firearm who fired a single shot and fatally wounded the male.\"\n\nThe teenager died in hospital later in the night, he said.\n\nThe \"middle-aged\" man who was stabbed was in a \"serious\" but stable condition and appeared to be doing well, the police commissioner said.\n\nThe boy had \"mental issues but also online radicalisation issues\", he said.\n\nThe attacker had for the past couple of years been part of a \"countering violence extremism programme\" for people who show signs of \"religious or issues-motivated\" concerns, he said.\n\n\"It is not a criminal based approach but it is a programme to help individuals who are expressing ideologies that are of concern in our community. But they may not be committing any crimes.\"\n\nPolice said they did not know what had triggered the attack.\n\nDespite the rarity of such violent crimes in Australia, the Perth attack comes less than a month after a knife-wielding assailant killed six people in a shopping mall in Sydney.\n\nThe mentally ill knifeman, 40-year-old Joel Cauchi, was tracked down, shot and killed by a police inspector.\n\nCauchi's parents say he was diagnosed with schizophrenia at 17 but stopped taking medication, later leaving their Queensland home and dropping out of treatment.\n\nTwo days after the mall attack an Assyrian Christian bishop was brutally stabbed during a live streamed service in western Sydney.\n\nThe bishop has since recovered and a 16-year-old suspect has been charged with {"uri": "8112543213", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "16:07:37", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T16:07:37Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T16:04:22Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7372549176216125, "url": "https://www.taipeitimes.com/News/world/archives/2024/05/06/2003817458", "title": "Police shoot teen after attack in Perth - Taipei Times", "body": "UNDER INVESTIGATION: Members of the local Muslim community had raised concerns with the police about the boy, who officials said might have been radicalized online\n\nA 16-year-old boy armed with a knife was shot dead by police after he stabbed a man in the Australian west coast city of Perth, officials said yesterday.\n\nThe incident occurred in the parking lot of a hardware store in suburban Willetton on Saturday night.\n\nThe teen attacked the man and then rushed at police officers before he was shot, Western Australian Premier Roger Cook told reporters.\n\n\"There are indications he had been radicalized online,\" Cook told a news conference, adding that it appeared he acted alone.\n\nA man in his 30s was found at the scene with a stab wound to his back. He was taken to hospital in serious, but stable, condition, a police statement said.\n\nPolice and Australian Security Intelligence Organisation (ASIO) agents have been conducting a counterterrorism investigation in the east coast city of Sydney after another 16-year-old boy stabbed an Assyrian Orthodox bishop and priest in a church on April 15.\n\nThat boy has been charged with committing a terrorist act. Six of his alleged associates have also been charged with a range of offenses, including conspiring to engage in or planning a terrorist act. All remain in custody.\n\nAustralian Prime Minister Anthony Albanese said he had been briefed on the latest stabbing in Perth by Australian Federal Police Commissioner Reece Kershaw and ASIO Director-General Mike Burgess, who heads the nation's main domestic spy agency.\n\n\"I'm advised there is no ongoing threat to the community on the information available,\" Albanese said.\n\n\"We are a peace-loving nation and there is no place for violent extremism in Australia,\" he added.\n\nPolice received an emergency telephone call after 10pm from a teenager saying he was going to commit acts of violence, Western Australian Police Commissioner Col Blanch said.\n\nThe boy had been participating in a program for young people at risk of radicalization, Blanch added.\n\n\"I don't want to say he has been radicalized or is radicalized, because I think that forms part of the investigation,\" he said.\n\nPolice said they were later alerted by a phone call from a member of the public that a knife attack was under way in the parking lot. Three police officers responded, one armed with a gun and two with conducted energy devices.\n\nPolice deployed the conducted energy devices, but failed to incapacitate the boy before he was killed by a single gunshot, Blanch said.\n\nMembers of the local Muslim community had raised concerns with police about the boy's behavior before he was killed on Saturday, he said.\n\nThe Imam of Perth's largest mosque, the Nasir Mosque, condemned the stabbing.\n\n\"There is no place for violence in Islam,\" Imam Syed Wadood Janud said in a statement.\n\n\"We appreciate the effort of the police to keep our communities safe. I also want to commend the local Muslim community who had flagged the individual prior with the police,\" Wadood added.\n\nSome Muslim leaders have criticized Australian police for declaring last month's church stabbing a terrorist act, but not a rampage two days earlier in a Sydney shopping mall in which six people were killed and a dozen wounded.\n\nThe 40-year-old attacker in the mall attack was shot dead by police. Police have yet to reveal the man's motive.\n\nThe church attack is only the third to be classified by Australian authorities as a terrorist act since 2018.", "source": {"uri": "taipeitimes.com", {"uri": "8111980047", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "06:56:15", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T06:56:15Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T06:54:29Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.729411780834198, "url": "https://today.rtl.lu/news/world/a/2192573.html", "title": "Southern suburb of Perth: 'Radicalised' 16-year-old shot dead by police in Australia", "body": "The teenager \"rushed\" at police who responded by shooting him twice with Tasers before firing a single fatal shot, they said.\n\n\"There are indications he had been radicalised online. But I want to reassure the community at this stage it appears he acted solely and alone,\" Premier Roger Cook said.\n\nPolice received a call late on Saturday from a male warning that he was going to commit \"acts of violence\" but without giving his name or location, the state's police commissioner, Col Blanch, told reporters.\n\nWithin minutes, another emergency call alerted police that a \"male with a knife was running around the car park\" in Willetton, a southern suburb of Perth, he said.\n\nPolice body camera images showed the teenager refused officers' demands that he put down the knife, the police chief said.\n\nThe weapon was a 30-centimetre (one-foot) kitchen knife, believed to be from the attacker's home, he said.\n\nOfficers fired two Tasers at him but \"both of them did not have the full desired effect,\" he said.\n\n\"The male continued to advance on the third officer with a firearm who fired a single shot and fatally wounded the male.\"\n\nThe teenager died in hospital later in the night, he said.\n\nThe \"middle-aged\" man who had been stabbed was in a \"serious\" but stable condition and appeared to be doing well, the police commissioner said.\n\nThe man had suffered a single, \"possibly\" two centimetre stab wound that may have punctured a lung, he said.\n\nPolice believe the teenager sent \"relevant messages\" to some members of the Muslim community who immediately called police, he said, without giving details of the messages.\n\nThe boy had \"mental issues but also online radicalisation issues\", the police chief said.\n\nIn the past two years, the attacker had been part of a \"countering violence extremism programme\" for people who show signs of \"religious or issues-motivated\" concerns, he said.\n\n\"It is not a criminal based approach but it is a programme to help individuals who are expressing ideologies that are of concern in our community. But they may not be committing any crimes.\"\n\nPolice said they did not know what had triggered the attack.\n\nBlanch said it had the \"hallmarks\" of a terrorist incident but he was not making an official declaration right now as he had no concerns about a wider network being involved.\n\nAustralian Prime Minister Anthony Albanese said he had been briefed by police and intelligence services who had advised there was no \"ongoing threat\".\n\n\"We are a peace-loving nation and there is no place for violent extremism in Australia,\" he said in a message on social media.\n\nDespite the rarity of such violent crimes in Australia, the Perth attack comes less than a month after a knife-wielding assailant killed six people in a shopping mall in Sydney.\n\nThe mentally ill knifeman, 40-year-old Joel Cauchi, was tracked down, shot and killed by a police inspector.\n\nCauchi's parents say he was diagnosed with schizophrenia at 17 but stopped taking medication, later leaving their Queensland home and dropping out of treatment.\n\nTwo days after the mall attack an Assyrian Christian bishop was brutally stabbed during a live streamed service in western Sydney.\n\nThe bishop has since recovered and a 16-year-old suspect has been charged with committing \"a terrorist act\".", "source": {"uri": "today.rtl.lu", "dataType": "news", "title": "RTL Today"}, "authors": [], {"uri": "8111827203", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "03:51:26", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T03:51:26Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T03:47:26Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.729411780834198, "url": "https://www.odt.co.nz/news/world/radicalised-teen-armed-knife-shot-dead-perth", "title": "'Radicalised' teen armed with knife shot dead in Perth", "body": "You are not permitted to download, save or email this image. Visit image gallery to purchase the image.\n\nAuthorities say there is no ongoing threat to the public after an allegedly radicalised teenager armed with a large kitchen knife was shot dead by police in Western Australia.\n\nThe 16-year-old stabbed a man in the back at a Bunnings carpark at Willetton, in Perth's south, on Saturday night then rushed at officers, WA Police Commissioner Col Blanch told reporters on Sunday.\n\nHe said bodyworn footage of the incident shows the teen approaching police who deployed their Tasers but that did not have the \"desired effect\".\n\nThe teen then moved towards a constable who fired a single shot, Mr Blanch said.\n\nWhen officers arrived at the scene they did not know a man had been stabbed in the back in the carpark.\n\nThe victim, whose age has not been made public, is in a serious but stable condition in hospital.\n\nMr Blanch said the injured man was not connected to the teen and just happened to be in the area when he was attacked.\n\nThe police commissioner said several emergency calls triple were made about the incident, including from the teenager himself and multiple ones from members of the state's Muslim community concerned about his behaviour.\n\n\"We believe he sent relevant messages to some of those members who immediately responded by calling police,\" Mr Blanch said.\n\n\"Again, I do want to thank members of the Muslim community who did that, because that enabled us to identify rapidly who this individual was and respond quickly.\"\n\nHe described the teen involved as a Caucasian male with mental health issues who was known to police.\n\nThe boy had been part of an anti-radicalisation support programme since 2022 but police do not have concerns he is part of a wider network.\n\nOfficers have been in contact with his family.\n\n\"I think the family really do understand the situation that police were in, they are being very forthcoming with police,\" Mr Blanch said.\n\nWA Premier Roger Cook said there was \"indications he had been radicalised online.\"\n\n\"I want to reassure the community at this stage it appears that he acted solely and alone,\" Mr Cook said.\n\n\"Members of the WA Muslim community, who were concerned by his behaviour, contacted police prior to the incident and I thank them for their help.\n\n\"Our police responded within minutes, they encountered a very confronting situation but their rapid and professional response kept our community safe.\"\n\nMr Blanch said the constable who fired the shot and his colleagues were \"hurting\" but stressed they had done their job.\n\nThe ASIO Director-General and Australian Federal Police Commissioner have briefed Prime Minister Anthony Albanese on the incident.\n\n\"I'm advised there is no ongoing threat to the community on the information available,\" Mr Albanese said on social media.\n\n\"We are a peace-loving nation and there is no place for violent extremism in Australia.\"\n\nAn investigation will examine the shooting and events leading up to the incident.\n\nThe Imam of the Mahmood Mosque in Adelaide, who previously served in Perth, condemned the attack \"in the strongest terms\".\n\n\"We are once again saddened to learn of another knife attack in which innocent civilians were harmed, this time in Perth,\" Imam Kamran Tahir said in a statement.\n\n\"It should be made very clear that there is no justification for such acts in Islam.\"\n\nThe incident comes after New South Wales police last month charged several boys with terrorism-related offences in investigations following the stabbing of an Assyrian Christian bishop while he was giving a live-streamed sermon in Sydney on April 15 this year.\n\nThe attack on the bishop came only days after a stabbing spree killed six at a busy shopping mall in the Sydney beachside suburb of Bondi.\n\nGun and knife crime is rare in Australia, which consistently ranks among the safest countries in the world, according to the federal government.", "source": He was taken to a hospital in serious but stable condition, a police statement said.\n\nPolice and Australian Security Intelligence Organization agents have been conducting a counterterrorism investigation in the east coast city of Sydney since another 16-year-old boy stabbed an Assyrian Orthodox bishop and priest in a church on April 15.\n\nThat boy has been charged with committing a terrorist act. Six of his alleged associates have also been charged with a range of offenses, including conspiring to engage in or planning a terrorist act. All remain in custody.\n\nPrime Minister Anthony Albanese said he had been briefed on the latest stabbing in Perth by Australian Federal Police Commissioner Reece Kershaw and ASIO Director-General Mike Burgess, who heads the nation's main domestic spy agency.\n\n\"I'm advised there is no ongoing threat to the community on the information available,\" Albanese said.\n\n\"We are a peace-loving nation and there is no place for violent extremism in Australia,\" he added.\n\nPolice received an emergency phone call after 10 p.m. from a teenager saying he was going to commit acts of violence, But I want to reassure the community at this stage it appears he acted solely and alone,\" Premier Roger Cook said.\n\nPolice received a call late on Saturday from a male warning that he was going to commit \"acts of violence\" but without giving his name or location, the state's police commissioner, Col Blanch, told reporters.\n\nWithin minutes, another emergency call alerted police that a \"male with a knife was running around the car park\" in Willetton, a southern suburb of Perth, he said.\n\nPolice body camera images showed the teenager refused officers' demands that he put down the knife, the police chief said.\n\nThe weapon was a 30-centimeter (one-foot) kitchen knife, believed to be from the attacker's home, he said.\n\nOfficers fired two Tasers at him but \"both of them did not have the full desired effect,\" he said.\n\n\"The male continued to advance on the third officer with a firearm who fired a single shot and fatally wounded the male.\"\n\nThe teenager died in hospital later in the night, he said.\n\n'Online radicalization'\n\nThe \"middle-aged\" man who had been stabbed was in a \"serious\" but stable condition and appeared to be doing well, the police commissioner said.\n\nThe man had suffered a single, \"possibly\" two centimeter stab wound that may have punctured a lung, he said.\n\nPolice believe the teenager sent \"relevant messages\" to some members of the Muslim community who immediately called police, he said, without giving details of the messages.\n\nThe boy had \"mental issues but also online radicalization issues,\" the police chief said.\n\nIn the past two years, the attacker had been part of a \"countering violence extremism program\" for people who show signs of \"religious or issues-motivated\" concerns, he said.\n\n\"It is not a criminal based approach but it is a program to help individuals who are expressing ideologies that are of concern in our community. {"uri": "8113004451", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "02:05:40", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T02:05:40Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T02:02:57Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7215686440467834, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/wires/ap/article-13385985/Boy-shot-dead-Perth-stabbing-deradicalization-program-no-ties-seen-Sydney-teens.html", "title": "Boy shot dead after Perth stabbing was in deradicalization program,...", "body": "MELBOURNE, Australia (AP) - A 16-year-old boy who was shot dead by police after stabbing a man in the Australian west coast city of Perth had been in a deradicalization program but had no links to an alleged network of teen extremists in the east coast city of Sydney, authorities said.\n\nThe boy had participated in the federally funded Countering Violent Extremism program for two years but had no criminal record, Western Australia Police Minister Paul Papalia said Monday.\n\n\"The challenge we confront with people like the 16-year-old in this incident is that he\u00b4s known to hold views that are dangerous and potentially he could be radicalized,\" Papalia told Australian Broadcasting Corp. \"... but the problem with individuals like this is they can act at short notice without warning and be very dangerous.\"\n\nOn the potential for the boy to have been radicalized, Prime Minister Anthony Albanese said he was concerned by social media pushing extreme positions.\n\n\"It\u00b4s a dynamic that isn\u00b4t just an issue for government. It\u00b4s an issue for our entire society, whether it be violent extremism, misogyny and violence against women. It is an issue that of course I\u00b4m concerned about,\" Albanese told reporters.\n\nWestern Australia Police Commissioner Col Blanch said the boy had phoned police late Saturday saying he was about to commit \"acts of violence\" but did not say where. Minutes later, a member of the public reported to police seeing the boy with a knife in a hardware store parking lot.\n\nIn this image from a video, Western Australian Police Commissioner Col Blanch speaks at a press conference in Perth, Australia Sunday, May 5, 2024. A 16-year-old boy armed with a knife was shot dead by police after he stabbed a man in the Australian west coast city of Perth, officials said Sunday. (Australian Broadcasting Corporation via AP)\n\nThree police officers responded, one armed with a gun and two with stun guns. Police deployed both stun guns but they failed to incapacitate the boy before he was killed by a single gunshot, Blanch said.\n\nThe stabbing victim is a man in his 30s who was wounded in his back. He was in serious but stable condition at a Perth hospital, police said.\n\nBlanch said members of the local Muslim community had raised concerns with police about the boy\u00b4s behavior before he was killed on Saturday.\n\nPolice said the stabbing had the hallmarks of a terrorist attack but have not declared it as such. Factors that can influence that decision include whether state police need federal resources, including the Australian Security Intelligence Organization domestic spy agency.\n\nBlanch said the Western Australia Police Force investigation did not need additional federal resources and he was confidence the situation was different from the one in Sydney.\n\n\"We are dealing with complex issues, both mental health issues but also online radicalization issues,\" Blanch said Sunday. \"But we believe he very much is acting alone and we do not have concerns at this time that there is an ongoing network or other concerns that might have been seen over in Sydney.\"\n\nNew South Wales Police Commissioner Karen Webb had declared the stabbings of an Assyrian Orthodox bishop and priest in a Sydney church on April 15 as a terrorist act within hours. The boy arrested was later charged with committing a terrorist act. In the subsequent investigation, six more teenagers were charged with terror-related offenses.\n\nPolice alleged all seven were part of a network that \"adhered to a religiously motivated, violent extremist ideology.\"\n\nSome Muslim leaders have criticized Australian police for declaring last month\u00b4s church stabbing a terrorist act but not a rampage two days earlier in a Sydney shopping mall in which six people were killed and a dozen wounded. The 40-year-old attacker was shot dead by police.\n\nThe man had a history of schizophrenia and most of the victims he targeted were women. Police have yet to reveal the man\u00b4s motive.\n\nThe church attack is only the third to be classified by Australian authorities as a terrorist act since 2018.\n\nIn December 2022, three Christian fundamentalists shot dead two police officers and a bystander in an ambush near the community of Wieambilla in Queensland state. The shooters were later killed by police.\n\nIn November 2018, a Somalia-born Muslim stabbed three pedestrians in downtown Melbourne, killing one, before police shot him dead.\n\nThis image from a video, shows a parking lot where an incident occurred in Perth, Australia Sunday, May 5, 2024. A 16-year-old boy armed with a knife was shot dead by police after he stabbed a man in the Australian west coast city of Perth, officials said Sunday. (Australian Broadcasting Corporation via AP)\n\nIn this image from a video, Western Australian Premier Roger Cook speaks at a press conference in Perth, Australia Sunday, May 5, 2024. A 16-year-old boy armed with a knife was shot dead by police after he stabbed a man in the Australian west coast city of Perth, officials said Sunday. But I want to assure people that at this point it appears that he acted alone,\" Cook said.\n\nPolice received a call Saturday night from a man warning that he was going to commit \"acts of violence,\" but without giving his name or location, state police official Col Blanch told reporters.\n\nMinutes later, he added, police received an emergency call warning them that \"a man with a knife was running\" in a car park in Willetton, a suburb south of Perth.\n\nThe individual was armed with a 12-inch-long kitchen knife, and based on police body camera footage, the teen refused to put it down as police had ordered, Blanch said.\n\nThe agents fired two electric pulse guns but \"none of them had the desired effect,\" he said.\n\n\"The man continued to advance toward (an officer) with a gun, who fired a single shot and fatally wounded\" the individual, the police officer said. The teenager died in the hospital that same night.\n\nThe \"mature\" man injured by a single stab wound during the attack is in \"serious\" but stable condition, the police official said.\n\nPolice believe the teen sent messages to members of the Muslim community, who immediately notified police, they said without revealing information about their content.\n\nThe teenager had \"mental health problems but also online radicalization problems,\" according to the same source.\n\nIn recent years, the attacker was followed as part of a program to combat violence and extremism.\n\n\"This is not a crime-based approach, it is a program aimed at helping people who express ideologies that concern our community,\" Mr. Blanch explained.\n\nAustralian Prime Minister Anthony Albanese explained that the police and intelligence services had kept him informed of the events, according to which there was no \"ongoing threat.\"\n\n\"We are a nation committed to peace and there is no place for violent extremism in Australia,\" Albanese wrote on social media.\n\nViolent crime is rare in Australia, but this incident comes less than a month after another stabbing that left six dead in a Sydney shopping center (southeast).\n\nThe perpetrator of this attack, Joel Cauchi, a 40-year-old man who suffered from mental illness, was shot dead by police. His parents said his son was diagnosed with schizophrenia when he was 17, then he left his home in Queensland (northeast) and abandoned treatment.\n\nTwo days after this shopping center attack, a bishop of an Assyrian church was also stabbed during a live-streamed sermon at a Sydney church. The victim survived his injuries. Authorities said they received calls from concerned members of the local Muslim community before the attack. The man was stable in a hospital, authorities said.\n\n\"At this stage it appears that he acted solely and alone,\" Cook told a televised news conference in Perth.\n\nPrime Minister Anthony Albanese said he had been briefed on the incident by police and intelligence agencies, which advised there was no ongoing threat.\n\n\"We are a peace-loving nation and there is no place for violent extremism in Australia,\" Albanese said on X.\n\nPolice said members of the local Muslim community had made complaints about the boy's behaviour just before the attack, helping to quickly identify him.\n\nOn Saturday night, the teenager appeared to have placed a call to the police, saying he was going to commit \"acts of violence\". Police said they were later alerted by a phone call from a member of the public that a knife attack was under way in the car park.\n\nThree police officers responded, one armed with a gun and two with tasers. The tasers failed to subdue the boy before he was killed by a single gunshot.\n\nSyed Wadood Janud, the imam of Perth's largest mosque, the Nasir Mosque, condemned the stabbing in a statement.\n\n\"There is no place for violence in Islam,\" he said. \"We appreciate the effort of the police to keep our communities safe. I also want to commend the local Muslim community who had flagged the individual prior with the police.\"\n\nSaturday's incident is the latest in a series of knife attacks in Australia in recent weeks.\n\nLast month, New South Wales police charged several boys with terrorism-related offences in investigations following the stabbing of an Assyrian Christian bishop while he was giving a livestreamed sermon in Sydney.\n\nThe attack on the bishop came only days after a stabbing spree killed six in the Sydney beachside suburb of Bondi.\n\nGun and knife crime is rare in Australia, which that he acted solely and alone,\" Western Australia Premier Roger Cook said.\n\nPolice in Western Australia said they received a call late on Saturday from the teenager who had warned them he intended to commit \"acts of violence\".\n\nPolice commissioner Col Branch told a press conference that within minutes another emergency call was received alerting officers that a \"male with a knife was running around the car park\" in Willetton, a southern suburb of Perth.\n\nThree officers arrived and found a 16-year-old armed with a long kitchen knife.\n\nThe first two officers fired their Tasers but when the teenager continued to approach, the third officer fired a single shot which killed the 16-year-old, the commissioner said.\n\nThe teenager was described as a person with \"complex {"uri": "8111895904", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "05:18:51", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T05:18:51Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T05:18:17Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7098039388656616, "url": "https://www.abc.net.au/news/2024-05-05/willetton-knife-attack-police-shooting-perth/103806436", "title": "Police shoot dead 'radicalised' 16yo armed with a knife in WA", "body": "Police have shot dead a 16-year-old boy who stabbed another man with a kitchen knife in Perth, saying the teenager was \"radicalised\" online.\n\nWA Police said they received an emergency call just after 10pm on Saturday from a teen saying he was going to commit acts of violence.\n\nA second triple-0 call was made a short time later after reports a man had been stabbed in the car park of a Bunnings store in Willetton, in Perth's southern suburbs.\n\nPolice Commissioner Col Blanch said when they arrived, they found a 16-year-old armed with a large kitchen knife.\n\nCommissioner Blanch said the boy lunged at officers with the knife and was shot.\n\nHe died a short time later in hospital.\n\nThe police commissioner and WA Premier Roger Cook held a press conference on Sunday morning and described the incident as \"extremely confronting\".\n\nThey said the boy was \"running around a car park, armed with a knife\" before stabbing another man not known to him in the back, in what appeared to be a random attack.\n\n\"They [WA police] exited their vehicle and were confronted with a male alone with a large kitchen knife,\" Commissioner Blanch said.\n\n\"Two officers drew their tasers and one of the officers drew his firearm.\n\n\"They challenged the male to put down the knife, which he did not.\"\n\nCommissioner Blanch said the body-cam footage he watched showed the 16-year-old rushing one of the officers with the knife before both officers deployed their tasers.\n\n\"Both of them didn't have the full desired effect, and the male continued to advance on the third officer with the firearm, who fired a single shot and fatally wounded the male.\"\n\nA pool of blood on the car park bitumen on Sunday morning was the only remaining clue something had happened overnight, as business continued as usual.\n\nMr Cook said there were indications the boy had been radicalised online.\n\n\"But I want to reassure the community at this stage it appears that he acted solely and alone,\" Mr Cook said.\n\n\"Members of the WA Muslim community, who were concerned by his behaviour, contacted police prior to the incident and I thank them for their help.\"\n\nIt was also said the boy's family was cooperating with police.\n\nCommissioner Blanch said the incident was not being labelled as a terrorist attack at this stage.\n\n\"It certainly has the hallmarks of one [but] the reason why I would declare it as a terrorist act going forward -- it's about timing,\" Commissioner Blanch said.\n\n\"If I need extra capability, particularly from the Commonwealth, sometimes you'll see terrorist acts being declared very early.\n\n\"I believe this is a person acting alone ... I don't need additional capability at this time, whilst it meets the criteria, or at least the definition.\n\n\"That's something that we can work towards as we find out more information from the motivations behind this.\"\n\nCommissioner Blanch said the teen was known to police and was part of a program designed to help individuals at risk of being radicalised.\n\nHe said it was a support program focused on individuals who expressed ideologies that were of concern to the community but \"they may not be committing any crimes\".\n\n\"[The program is] for those that are exhibiting behaviours that might be religious or issues motivated.\n\n\"This 16-year-old Caucasian male was part of that program.\"\n\nPrime Minister Anthony Albanese thanked police for acting swiftly to contain the situation.\n\n\"I have also received a briefing on the situation by the ASIO Director-General and the AFP Commissioner, and I'm advised there is no ongoing threat to the community on the information available,\" Mr Albanese said in a statement.\n\nThe man who was stabbed by the boy, aged in his 30s, was recovering in Royal Perth Hospital in a serious but stable condition.\n\nIt is believed he sustained a two-centimetre stab wound to the back that may have punctured a lung.\n\nAn urgent meeting of community faith leaders and authorities is set to be held on Sunday afternoon in {"uri": "8111873834", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "04:51:05", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T04:51:05Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T04:50:32Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7019608020782471, "url": "https://www.firstpost.com/world/australia-police-kills-radicalised-teen-armed-with-a-knife-after-he-stabbed-a-man-in-perth-13767247.html", "title": "Australia: Police kills 'radicalised' teen, armed with a knife after he stabbed a man in Perth", "body": "Despite the rarity of such violent crimes in Australia, the Perth attack comes less than a month after a knife-wielding assailant killed six people in a shopping mall in Sydney read more\n\nWestern Australian police shot and killed a \"radicalised\" 16-year-old boy with a knife who had stabbed a man in a Perth car park, police and the state premier said Sunday.\n\nThe teenager \"rushed\" at police who responded by shooting him twice with Tasers before firing a single fatal shot, they said.\n\n\"There are indications he had been radicalised online. But I want to reassure the community at this stage it appears he acted solely and alone,\" Premier Roger Cook said.\n\nPolice received a call late on Saturday from a male warning that he was going to commit \"acts of violence\" but without giving his name or location, the state's police commissioner, Col Blanch, told reporters.\n\nWithin minutes, another emergency call alerted police that a \"male with a knife was running around the car park\" in Willetton, a southern suburb of Perth, he said.\n\nPolice body camera images showed the teenager refused officers' demands that he put down the knife, the police chief said.\n\nOfficers fired two Tasers at him but \"both of them did not have the full desired effect,\" he said.\n\n\"The male continued to advance on the third officer with a firearm who fired a single shot and fatally wounded the male.\"\n\nThe teenager died in hospital later in the night, he said.\n\n'Online radicalisation'\n\nThe \"middle-aged\" man who was stabbed was in a \"serious\" but stable condition and appeared to be doing well, the police commissioner said.\n\nThe boy had \"mental issues but also online radicalisation issues\", he said.\n\nThe attacker had for the past couple of years been part of a \"countering violence extremism programme\" for people who show signs of \"religious or issues-motivated\" concerns, he said.\n\n\"It is not a criminal based approach but it is a programme to help individuals who are expressing ideologies that are of concern in our community. But they may not be committing any crimes.\"\n\nPolice said they did not know what had triggered the attack.\n\nDespite the rarity of such violent crimes in Australia, the Perth attack comes less than a month after a knife-wielding assailant killed six people in a shopping mall in Sydney.\n\nThe mentally ill knifeman, 40-year-old Joel Cauchi, was tracked down, shot and killed by a police inspector.\n\nCauchi's parents say he was diagnosed with schizophrenia at 17 but stopped taking medication, later leaving their Queensland home and dropping out of treatment.\n\nTwo days after the full desired effect, and the male continued to advance on the third officer with the firearm, who fired a single shot and fatally wounded the male.\"\n\nA pool of blood on the car park bitumen on Australian police said on Sunday they had shot dead a boy after he stabbed a man in Western Australia's capital Perth, in an attack authorities said indicated terrorism.\n\nThere were signs the 16-year-old, armed with a kitchen knife, had been radicalised online, state authorities said, adding they received calls from concerned members of the local Muslim community before the attack, which occurred late on Saturday night.\n\nThe attack, in the suburb of Willetton, had \"hallmarks\" of terrorism but was yet to be declared a terrorist act, police said.\n\n\"At this stage it appears that he acted solely and alone,\" Western Australia Premier Roger Cook told a televised press conference in the state capital Perth, regarding the attacker.\n\nThe victim, stabbed in the back, was stable in hospital, authorities said.\n\nPrime Minister Anthony Albanese said he had been briefed on the incident by police and intelligence agencies, which advised there was no ongoing threat.\n\n\"We are a peace-loving nation and there is no place for violent extremism in Australia,\" Albanese said on social media platform X.\n\nThe incident comes after New South Wales police last month charged several boys with terrorism-related offences in investigations following the stabbing of an Assyrian Christian bishop while he was giving a live-streamed sermon in Sydney, on April 15.\n\nThe attack on the bishop came only days after a stabbing spree killed six in the Sydney beachside suburb of Bondi.\n\nGun and knife crime is rare in Australia, which consistently ranks among the safest countries in the world, according to the federal government. {"uri": "2024-05-345503711", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "10:16:08", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T10:16:08Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T03:42:28Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6901960968971252, "url": "https://www.1news.co.nz/2024/05/05/teen-shot-dead-by-police-after-knife-attack-outside-perth-bunnings/", "title": "Teen shot dead by police after knife attack outside Perth Bunnings", "body": "Authorities say there is no ongoing threat to the public after an allegedly radicalised teenager armed with a large kitchen knife was shot dead by police in Western Australia.\n\nThe 16-year-old stabbed a man in the back at a Bunnings carpark at Willetton in Perth's south on Saturday night then rushed at officers, WA Police Commissioner Col Blanch told reporters on Sunday.\n\nHe said bodyworn footage of the incident shows the teen approaching police who deployed their Tasers but that did not have the \"desired effect\".\n\nThe teen then moved towards a constable who fired a single shot, Mr Blanch said.\n\nWhen officers arrived at the scene they did not know a man had been stabbed in the back in the carpark.\n\nThe stabbed man, whose age has not been made public, is in a serious but stable condition in hospital.\n\nBlanch said the injured man was not connected to the teen and just happened to be in the area when he was attacked.\n\nThe police commissioner said several triple zero calls were made about the incident, including from the teenager himself and multiple ones from members of the state's Muslim community concerned about his behaviour.\n\n\"We believe he sent relevant messages to some of those members who immediately responded by calling police,\" Blanch said.\n\n\"Again, I do want to thank members of the Muslim community who did that, because that enabled us to identify rapidly who this individual was and respond quickly.\"\n\nHe described the teen involved as a Caucasian male with mental health issues who was known to police.\n\nThe boy had been part of an anti-radicalisation support program since 2022 but police do not have concerns he is part of a wider network.\n\nOfficers have been in contact with the teenager's family.\n\n\"I think the family really do understand the situation that police were in, they are being very forthcoming with police,\" Blanch said.\n\nWA Premier Roger Cook said there was \"indications he had been radicalised online.\"\n\n\"I want to reassure the community at this stage it appears that he acted solely and alone,\" Cook said.\n\n\"Members of the WA Muslim community, who were concerned by his behaviour, contacted police prior to the incident and I thank them for their help,\" he said.\n\n\"Our police responded within minutes, they encountered a very confronting situation but their rapid and professional response kept our community safe.\"\n\nBlanch said the constable who fired the shot and his colleagues were \"hurting\" but stressed they had done their job.\n\nThe ASIO Director-General and Australian Federal Police Commissioner have briefed Prime Minister Anthony Albanese on the incident.\n\n\"I'm advised there is no ongoing threat to the community on the information available,\" Albanese said on social media.\n\n\"We are a peace-loving nation and there is no place for violent extremism in Australia.\"\n\nAn investigation will examine the shooting and events leading up to the incident.\n\nThe Imam of the Mahmood Mosque in Adelaide, who previously served in Perth, condemned the attack \"in the strongest terms\".\n\n\"We are once again saddened to learn of another knife attack in which innocent civilians were harmed, this time in Perth,\" Imam Kamran Tahir said in a statement.\n\n\"It should be made very clear that there is no Six of his alleged associates have also been charged with a range of offenses, including conspiring to engage in or planning a terrorist act. All remain in custody.\n\nPrime Minister Anthony Albanese said he had been briefed on the latest stabbing in Perth by Australia Federal Police Commissioner Reece Kershaw and ASIO Director-General Mike Burgess, who heads the nation's main domestic spy agency.\n\n\"I'm advised there is no ongoing threat to the community on the information available,\" Albanese said in a statement.\n\n\"We are a peace-loving nation and there is no place for violent extremism in Australia,\" Albanese added.\n\nPolice received an emergency phone call after 10 p.m. from a teenager saying he was going to commit acts of violence, Australian Broadcasting Corp. reported.\n\nA man was found at the scene with stab wounds to his back, ABC reported. They were later alerted by a phone call from a member of the public that a knife attack was underway in the parking lot.\n\nThree officers were deployed to the scene, with one armed with a gun and two armed with Tasers. He was later killed by a single gunshot wound after failing to comply.\n\nPrime Minister Anthony Albanese said he had been briefed on the latest stabbing in Perth and said: \"I'm advised there is no ongoing threat to the community on the information available.\n\n\"We are a peace-loving nation and there is no place for violent extremism in Australia.\"\n\nThe Imam of Perth's largest mosque, the Nasir Mosque, condemned the stabbing.\n\n\"There is no place for violence in Islam,\" Imam Syed Wadood Janud said in a statement.\n\n\"We appreciate the effort of the police to keep our communities safe. I also want to commend the local Muslim community who had flagged the individual prior with the police,\" Wadood added.\n\nSome Muslim leaders have criticized Australian police for declaring last month's church stabbing a terrorist act but not a rampage two days earlier in a Sydney shopping mall in which six people were killed and a dozen wounded. The 40-year-old attacker in the mall attack was shot dead by police. Police have yet to reveal the man's motive.\n\nThe church attack is only the third to be classified by Australian authorities as a terrorist act since 2018.\n\nIn December 2022, three Christian fundamentalists shot dead two police officers and a bystander in an ambush near the community of Wieambilla in Queensland state. The shooters were later killed by police.\n\nIn November 2018, a Somalia-born Muslim stabbed three pedestrians in downtown Melbourne, killing one, before police shot him dead.", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "2024-05-345957637", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "06:54:14", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T06:54:14Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T21:47:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.686274528503418, "url": "https://www.usnews.com/news/world/articles/2024-05-06/boy-shot-dead-after-perth-stabbing-was-in-deradicalization-program-but-no-ties-seen-to-sydney-teens", "title": "Boy Shot Dead After Perth Stabbing Was in Deradicalization Program, but No Ties Seen to Sydney Teens", "body": "In this image from a video, Western Australian Police Commissioner Col Blanch speaks at a press conference in Perth, Australia Sunday, May 5, 2024. A 16-year-old boy armed with a knife was shot dead by police after he stabbed a man in the Australian west coast city of Perth, officials said Sunday. (Australian Broadcasting Corporation via AP)\n\nMELBOURNE, Australia (AP) -- A 16-year-old boy who was shot dead by police after stabbing a man in the Australian west coast city of Perth had been in a deradicalization program but had no links to an alleged network of teen extremists in the east coast city of Sydney, authorities said.\n\nThe boy had participated in the federally funded Countering Violent Extremism program for two years but had no criminal record, Western Australia Police Minister Paul Papalia said Monday.\n\n\"The challenge we confront with people like the 16-year-old in this incident is that he's known to hold views that are dangerous and potentially he could be radicalized,\" Papalia said. \"But the problem with individuals like this is they can act at short notice without warning and be very dangerous.\"\n\nOn the potential for the boy to have been radicalized, Prime Minister Anthony Albanese said he was concerned by social media pushing extreme positions.\n\n\"It's a dynamic that isn't just an issue for government. It's an issue for our entire society, whether it be violent extremism, misogyny and violence against women. It is an issue that of course I'm concerned about,\" Albanese told reporters.\n\nWestern Australia Police Commissioner Col Blanch said the boy had phoned police late Saturday saying he was about to commit \"acts of violence\" but did not say where. Minutes later, a member of the public reported to police seeing the boy with a knife in a hardware store parking lot.\n\nThree police officers responded, one armed with a gun and two with stun guns. Police deployed both stun guns but they failed to incapacitate the boy before he was killed by a single gunshot, Blanch said.\n\nThe stabbing victim is a man in his 30s who was wounded in his back. He was in serious but stable condition at a Perth hospital, police said.\n\nBlanch said members of the local Muslim community had raised concerns with police about the boy's behavior before he was killed on Saturday.\n\nThe boy had said in a text message to associates, \"I am going on the path of jihad tonight for the sake of Allah,\" Australian Associated Press reported, prompting several to alert police.\n\nPolice said the stabbing had the hallmarks of a terrorist attack but have not declared it as such. Factors that can influence that decision include whether state police need federal resources, including the Australian Security Intelligence Organization domestic spy agency.\n\nBlanch said the Western Australia Police Force investigation did not need additional federal resources and he was confidence the situation was different from the one in Sydney.\n\n\"We are dealing with complex issues, both mental health issues but also online radicalization issues,\" Blanch said Sunday. \"But we believe he very much is acting alone and we do not have concerns at this time that there is an ongoing network or other concerns that might have been seen over in Sydney.\"\n\nWestern Australia Premier Roger Cook said his government and the state education department had been aware of concerns at the boy's school about his behavior. Cook didn't directly respond to reports that several boys at Rossmoyne Senior High School, the prestigious government school he attended, were attempting to radicalize classmates.\n\n\"I'll leave that up the the Education Department to clarify,\" Cook told reporters. \"This young man was harboring some extremist thoughts, which is the reason why he was part of the Countering Violent Extremism program.\"\n\nAmanda Spencer-Teo, a parent of a Rossmoyne student, said multiple \"red flags\" had been raised about the behavior of some students.\n\n\"Parents have been raising this with the school for some time,\" Spencer-Teo, who will be an opposition party candidate at state elections next year, told The Australian newspaper. \"The school and the department have failed to provide information to those concerned parents.\"\n\nIn the stabbings at a Sydney church on April 15, New South Wales Police Commissioner Karen Webb declared the stabbings of an Assyrian Orthodox bishop and priest as a terrorist act within hours. The boy arrested was later charged with committing a terrorist act. In the subsequent investigation, six more teenagers were charged with terror-related offenses.\n\nPolice alleged all seven were part of a network that \"adhered to a religiously motivated, violent extremist ideology.\"\n\nSome Muslim leaders have criticized Australian police for declaring the church stabbing a terrorist act but not a rampage two days earlier in a Sydney shopping mall in which six people were killed and a dozen wounded.\n\nThe 40-year-old attacker, who was shot dead by police, had a history of schizophrenia and most of the victims he targeted were women. Police have yet to reveal the man's motive.\n\nCopyright 2024 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. The incident occurred in suburban Willetton and involved the boy allegedly attacking the man and then rushing at police officers before being shot. Western Australian Premier Roger Cook confirmed that the boy had been radicalized online. Police and Australian Security Intelligence Organization agents have been conducting a counterterrorism investigation in Sydney since a 16-year-old boy stabbed an Assyrian Orthodox bishop and priest in a church on April 15.A 16-year-old boy armed with a knife was shot dead by police after stabbing a man in the Australian west coast city of Perth, officials said Sunday.\n\nThe incident occurred in the parking lot of a hardware store in suburban Willetton on Saturday night.\n\nThe teen allegedly attacked the man and then rushed at police officers before he was shot, Western Australian Premier Roger Cook told reporters on Sunday.\n\n\"There are indications he had been radicalized online,\" Cook told a news conference.\n\n\"But I want to reassure the community at this stage it appears that he acted solely and alone,\" Cook added.\n\nPolice and Australian Security Intelligence Organization agents have been conducting a counterterrorism investigation in the east coast city of Sydney since a 16-year-old boy stabbed an Assyrian Orthodox bishop and priest in a church on April 15.\n\nThe boy has been charged committing a terrorist act. Six of his alleged associates have also been charged with a range of offenses, including conspiring to engage in or planning a terrorist act. All remain in custody.\n\nPrime Minister Anthony Albanese said he had been briefed on the latest stabbing in Perth by Australia Federal Police Commissioner Reece Kershaw and ASIO Director-General Mike Burgess, who heads the nation's main domestic spy agency.\n\n\"I'm advised there is no ongoing threat to the community on the information available,\" Albanese said in a statement.\n\n\"We are a peace-loving nation and there is no place for violent extremism in Australia,\" Albanese added.\n\nPolice received an emergency phone call after 10 p.m. from a teenager saying he was going to commit acts of violence, Australian Broadcasting Corp. reported.\n\nA man was found at the scene with stab wounds to his back, ABC reported. {"uri": "8111826857", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "03:47:49", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T03:47:49Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T03:46:52Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6823529601097107, "url": "https://www.thestar.com.my/aseanplus/aseanplus-news/2024/05/05/police-shoot-dead-16-year-old-after-knife-attack-in-perth", "title": "Police shoot dead 16-year-old after knife attack in Perth", "body": "PERTH (The Straits Times/ANN): An investigation is under way in Western Australia after police shot dead a teenager who reportedly stabbed a member of the public.\n\nThe community of Willetton in Perth's south was shaken after reports surfaced on local news platforms. The incident reportedly took place along High Street before 11.30pm local time on May 4.\n\nAccording to reports from WAMN News on May 5, a police operation was mobilised. Witnesses described a chaotic scene where a man wielding a long knife chased individuals on the street.\n\nNews.com.au reported that the 16-year-old suspect is a Caucasian armed with what is believed to be a 30cm-long kitchen knife. He called the police to the carpark outside Bunnings Willeton on May 4 around 10pm after stabbing a man in the back, the police said. Authorities said the victim, who was stabbed in the back, was in the hospital and in stable condition.\n\nPolice Commissioner Col Blanch said the officers instructed him to put the knife down. When he refused to do so and lunged at them with his weapon, two officers tasered him while a third shot him.\n\nImages from police body camera showed the teenager refused officers' demands that he put down the knife, the police chief said.\n\nThe teenager died in hospital later in the night, he said.\n\nCommissioner Blanch said the boy, who had \"mental health issues\", was known to the police. He also appeared to be a part of a programme about \"online radicalisation\".\n\nEarlier, Western Australia Premier Roger Cook had said: \"There are indications he had been radicalised online.\"\n\n\"But I want to reassure the community at this stage it appears that he acted solely and alone,\" he added.\n\n\"Members of the WA Muslim community, who were concerned by his behaviour, contacted police prior to the incident and I thank them for their help. Our police responded within minutes.\"\n\nAt about 10pm on May 4, the police received a call from a male who said he was going to commit \"acts of violence\", ABC News reported.\n\nIn a press conference on May 5, Prime Minister Anthony Albanese thanked the Western Australian police for their swift action to contain the incident and said his \"thoughts are with those who have been affected by the incident\".\n\nHe said: \"We are a peace-loving nation and there is no place for violent extremism in Australia.\"\n\nA family member of a witness, who was not named, recounted the harrowing experience to WAMN News. Her brother-in-law was chased by a man with a long knife, she said.\n\n\"After working out, he waited at the door for his friends, and then a man approached him with a knife,\" she added. The attacker reportedly shouted religious phrases before pursuing her brother-in-law, who managed to escape. The assailant then turned his attention to another group of people, attacking one of them.\n\nThe Perth attack comes weeks after a stabbing spree in a Sydney mall on April 13 which left six people dead and a knife attack in a church two days later which left at least four people, including a bishop, wounded.\n\nThe suspect in the mall attack was shot and killed by a lone female police officer, who happened to be nearby.\n\nA 16-year-old boy was charged with a terrorism offence for the knifing of Assyrian Bishop Mar Mari Emmanuel during a live-streamed church service on April 15. {"uri": "8111813034", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "03:26:31", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T03:26:31Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T03:25:55Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6823529601097107, "url": "https://www.aap.com.au/news/radicalised-teen-armed-with-knife-shot-dead-by-police/", "title": "'Radicalised' teen armed with knife shot dead by police", "body": "Authorities say there is no ongoing threat to the public after an allegedly radicalised teenager armed with a large kitchen knife was shot dead by police in Western Australia.\n\nThe 16-year-old stabbed a man in the back at a Bunnings carpark at Willetton in Perth's south on Saturday night then rushed at officers, WA Police Commissioner Col Blanch told reporters on Sunday.\n\nHe said bodyworn footage of the incident shows the teen approaching police who deployed their Tasers but that did not have the \"desired effect\".\n\nThe teen then moved towards a constable who fired a single shot, Mr Blanch said.\n\nWhen officers arrived at the scene they did not know a man had been stabbed in the back in the carpark.\n\nThe stabbed man, whose age has not been made public, is in a serious but stable condition in hospital.\n\nMr Blanch said the injured man was not connected to the teen and just happened to be in the area when he was attacked.\n\nThe police commissioner said several triple zero calls were made about the incident, including from the teenager himself and multiple ones from members of the state's Muslim community concerned about his behaviour.\n\n\"We believe he sent relevant messages to some of those members who immediately responded by calling police,\" Mr Blanch said.\n\n\"Again, I do want to thank members of the Muslim community who did that, because that enabled us to identify rapidly who this individual was and respond quickly.\"\n\nHe described the teen involved as a Caucasian male with mental health issues who was known to police.\n\nThe boy had been part of an anti-radicalisation support program since 2022 but police do not have concerns he is part of a wider network.\n\nOfficers have been in contact with the teenager's family.\n\n\"I think the family really do understand the situation that police were in, they are being very forthcoming with police,\" Mr Blanch said.\n\nWA Premier Roger Cook said there was \"indications he had been radicalised online.\"\n\n\"I want to reassure the community at this stage it appears that he acted solely and alone,\" Mr Cook said.\n\n\"Members of the WA Muslim community, who were concerned by his behaviour, contacted police prior to the incident and I thank them for their help,\" he said.\n\n\"Our police responded within minutes, they encountered a very confronting situation but their rapid and professional response kept our community safe.\"\n\nMr Blanch said the constable who fired the shot and his colleagues were \"hurting\" but stressed they had done their job.\n\nThe ASIO Director-General and Australian Federal Police Commissioner have briefed Prime Minister Anthony Albanese on the incident.\n\n\"I'm advised there is no ongoing threat to the community on the information available,\" Mr Albanese said on social media.\n\n\"We are a peace-loving nation and there is no place for violent extremism in Australia.\"\n\nAn investigation will examine the shooting and events leading up to the incident.\n\nThe Imam of the Mahmood Mosque in Adelaide, who previously served in Perth, condemned the attack \"in the strongest terms\".\n\n\"We are once again saddened to learn of another knife attack in which innocent civilians were harmed, this time in Perth,\" Imam Kamran Tahir said in a statement.\n\n\"It should be made very clear that there is no justification It's an issue for our entire society, whether it be violent extremism, misogyny and violence against women. It is an issue that of course I'm concerned about.\"\n\nWestern Australia Police Commissioner Col Blanch said the boy had phoned police late on Saturday saying he was about to commit \"acts of violence\" but did not say where. Minutes later, a member of the public reported to police seeing the boy with a knife in a hardware store car park.\n\nThree police officers responded, one armed with a gun and two with stun guns. Police deployed both stun guns but they failed to incapacitate the boy before he was killed by a single gunshot, Mr Blanch said.\n\nA 16-year-old boy was shot dead by police after a stabbing incident in Perth (Australian Broadcasting Corporation via AP)\n\nThe stabbing victim is a man in his 30s who was wounded in the back. He was taken to a hospital in serious but stable condition, Australian Broadcasting Corp. reported.\n\nPolice and Australian Security Intelligence Organization agents have been conducting a counterterrorism investigation in the east coast city of Sydney since another 16-year-old boy stabbed an Assyrian Orthodox bishop and priest in a church on April 15.\n\nThat boy has been charged with committing a terrorist act. {"uri": "8113346479", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "07:39:22", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T07:39:22Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T07:38:57Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6705882549285889, "url": "https://english.aawsat.com/node/5002526", "title": "Russia Says to Practice Tactical Nuclear Weapon Scenario to Deter West", "body": "A 16-year-old boy who was shot dead by police after stabbing a man in the Australian west coast city of Perth had been in a deradicalization program but had no links to an alleged network of teen extremists in the east coast city of Sydney, authorities said.\n\nThe boy had participated in the federally funded Countering Violent Extremism program for two years but had no criminal record, Western Australia Police Minister Paul Papalia said Monday.\n\n\"The challenge we confront with people like the 16-year-old in this incident is that he's known to hold views that are dangerous and potentially he could be radicalized,\" Papalia told Australian Broadcasting Corp. \"... but the problem with individuals like this is they can act at short notice without warning and be very dangerous.\"\n\nOn the potential for the boy to have been radicalized, Prime Minister Anthony Albanese said he was concerned by social media pushing extreme positions, The AP reported.\n\n\"It's a dynamic that isn't just an issue for government. It's an issue for our entire society, whether it be violent extremism, misogyny and violence against women. It is an issue that of course I'm concerned about,\" Albanese told reporters.\n\nWestern Australia Police Commissioner Col Blanch said the boy had phoned police late Saturday saying he was about to commit \"acts of violence\" but did not say where. Minutes later, a member of the public reported to police seeing the boy with a knife in a hardware store parking lot.\n\nThree police officers responded, one armed with a gun and two with stun guns. Police deployed both stun guns but they failed to incapacitate the boy before he was killed by a single gunshot, Blanch said.\n\nThe stabbing victim is a man in his 30s who was wounded in his back. He was in serious but stable condition at a Perth hospital, police said.\n\nBlanch said members of the local Muslim community had raised concerns with police about the boy's behavior before he was killed on Saturday.\n\nPolice said the stabbing had the hallmarks of a terrorist attack but have not declared it as such. Factors that can influence that decision include whether state police need federal resources, including the Australian Security Intelligence Organization domestic spy agency.\n\nBlanch said the Western Australia Police Force investigation did not need additional federal resources and he was confidence the situation was different from the one in Sydney.\n\n\"We are dealing with complex issues, both mental health issues but also online radicalization issues,\" Blanch said Sunday. \"But we believe he very much is acting alone and we do not have concerns at this time that there is an ongoing network or other concerns that might have been seen over in Sydney.\"\n\nNew South Wales Police Commissioner Karen Webb had declared the stabbings of an Assyrian Orthodox bishop and priest in a Sydney church on April 15 as a terrorist act within hours. The boy arrested was later charged with committing a terrorist act. In the subsequent investigation, six more teenagers were charged with terror-related offenses.\n\nPolice alleged all seven were part of a network that \"adhered to a religiously motivated, violent extremist ideology.\"\n\nSome Muslim leaders have criticized Australian police for declaring last month's church stabbing a terrorist act but not a rampage two days earlier in a Sydney shopping mall in which six people were killed and a dozen wounded. The 40-year-old attacker was shot dead by police.\n\nThe man had a history of schizophrenia and most of the victims he targeted were women. Police have yet to reveal the man's motive.\n\nThe church attack is only the third to be classified by Australian authorities as a terrorist act since 2018.\n\nIn December 2022, three Christian fundamentalists shot dead two police officers and a bystander in an ambush near the community of Wieambilla in Queensland state. capital Perth, in an attack authorities said indicated terrorism.\n\nThere were signs the 16-year-old, armed with a kitchen knife, had been radicalised online, state authorities said, adding they received calls from concerned members of the local Muslim community before the attack, which occurred late on Saturday night.\n\nThe attack, in the suburb of Willetton, had \"hallmarks\" of terrorism but was yet to be declared a terrorist act, police said.\n\n\"At this stage it appears that he acted solely and alone,\" Western Australia Premier Roger Cook told a televised press conference in the state capital Perth, regarding the attacker.\n\nThe victim, stabbed in the back, was stable in hospital, authorities said.\n\nPrime Minister Anthony Albanese said he had been briefed on the incident by police and intelligence agencies, which advised there was no ongoing threat.\n\n\"We are a peace-loving nation and there is no place for violent extremism in Australia,\" Albanese said on social media platform X.\n\nThe incident comes after New South Wales police last month charged several boys with terrorism-related offences in investigations following the stabbing of an Assyrian Christian bishop while he was giving a live-streamed sermon in Sydney, on April 15.\n\nThe attack on the bishop came only days after a stabbing spree killed six in the Sydney beachside suburb of Bondi.\n\nGun and knife crime is rare in Australia, which consistently ranks among the safest countries in the world, according to the federal government.\n\n(Reporting by Sam McKeith in Sydney; Editing by It's an issue for our entire society, whether it be violent extremism, misogyny and violence against women. It is an issue that of course I'm concerned about.\"\n\nWestern Australia Police Commissioner Col Blanch said the boy had phoned police late on Saturday saying he was about to commit \"acts of violence\" but did not say where. Minutes later, a member of the public reported to police seeing the boy with a knife in a hardware store car park.\n\nThree police officers responded, one armed with a gun and two with stun guns. Police deployed both stun guns but they failed to incapacitate the boy before he was killed by a single gunshot, Mr Blanch said.\n\nThe stabbing victim is a man in his 30s who was wounded in the back. He was in serious but stable condition at a Perth hospital, police said.\n\nMr Blanch said members of the local Muslim community had raised concerns with police about the boy's behaviour before he was killed on Saturday.\n\nThe boy had said in a text message to associates, \"I am going on the path of jihad tonight for the sake of Allah,\" Australian Associated Press reported, prompting several to alert police.\n\nPolice said the stabbing had the hallmarks of a terrorist attack but have not declared it as such.\n\nFactors that can influence that decision include whether state police need federal resources, including the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation domestic spy agency.\n\n\"We are dealing with complex issues, both mental health issues but also online radicalization issues,\" Mr Blanch said on Sunday.\n\n\"But we believe he very much is acting alone and we do not have concerns at this time that there is an ongoing network or other concerns that might have been
