{"uri": "2024-05-346146433", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "07:43:36", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T07:43:36Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T06:02:11Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6627451181411743, "url": "https://www.newsmax.com/world/globaltalk/australia-stabbing-perth-police-shooting/2024/05/06/id/1163574/", "title": "Boy Shot Dead after Perth Stabbing Was in Deradicalization Program, but No Ties Seen to Sydney Teens", "body": "MELBOURNE, Australia (AP) -- A 16-year-old boy who was shot dead by police after stabbing a man in the Australian west coast city of Perth had been in a deradicalization program but had no links to an alleged network of teen extremists in the east coast city of Sydney, authorities said.\n\nThe boy had participated in the federally funded Countering Violent Extremism program for two years but had no criminal record, Western Australia Police Minister Paul Papalia said Monday.\n\n\"The challenge we confront with people like the 16-year-old in this incident is that he's known to hold views that are dangerous and potentially he could be radicalized,\" Papalia said. \"But the problem with individuals like this is they can act at short notice without warning and be very dangerous.\"\n\nOn the potential for the boy to have been radicalized, Prime Minister Anthony Albanese said he was concerned by social media pushing extreme positions.\n\n\"It's a dynamic that isn't just an issue for government. It's an issue for our entire society, whether it be violent extremism, misogyny and violence against women. It is an issue that of course I'm concerned about,\" Albanese told reporters.\n\nWestern Australia Police Commissioner Col Blanch said the boy had phoned police late Saturday saying he was about to commit \"acts of violence\" but did not say where. Minutes later, a member of the public reported to police seeing the boy with a knife in a hardware store parking lot.\n\nThree police officers responded, one armed with a gun and two with stun guns. Police deployed both stun guns but they failed to incapacitate the boy before he was killed by a single gunshot, Blanch said.\n\nThe stabbing victim is a man in his 30s who was wounded in his back. He was in serious but stable condition at a Perth hospital, police said.\n\nBlanch said members of the local Muslim community had raised concerns with police about the boy's behavior before he was killed on Saturday.\n\nThe boy had said in a text message to associates, \"I am going on the path of jihad tonight for the sake of Allah,\" Australian Associated Press reported, prompting several to alert police.\n\nPolice said the stabbing had the hallmarks of a terrorist attack but have not declared it as such. Factors that can influence that decision include whether state police need federal resources, including the Australian Security Intelligence Organization domestic spy agency.\n\nBlanch said the Western Australia Police Force investigation did not need additional federal resources and he was confidence the situation was different from the one in Sydney.\n\n\"We are dealing with complex issues, both mental health issues but also online radicalization issues,\" Blanch said Sunday. \"But we believe he very much is acting alone and we do not have concerns at this time that there is an ongoing network or other concerns that might have been seen over in Sydney.\"\n\nWestern Australia Premier Roger Cook said his government and the state education department had been aware of concerns at the boy's school about his behavior. Cook didn't directly respond to reports that several boys at Rossmoyne Senior High School, the prestigious government school he attended, were attempting to radicalize classmates.\n\n\"I'll leave that up the the Education Department to clarify,\" Cook told reporters. \"This young man was harboring some extremist thoughts, which is the reason why he was part of the Countering Violent Extremism program.\"\n\nAmanda Spencer-Teo, a parent of a Rossmoyne student, said multiple \"red flags\" had been raised about the behavior of some students.\n\n\"Parents have been raising this with the school for some time,\" Spencer-Teo, who will be an opposition party candidate at state elections next year, told The Australian newspaper. \"The school and the department have failed to provide information to those concerned parents.\"\n\nIn the stabbings at a Sydney church on April 15, New South Wales Police Commissioner Karen Webb declared the stabbings of an Assyrian Orthodox bishop and priest as a terrorist act within hours. The boy arrested was later charged with committing a terrorist act. In the subsequent investigation, six more teenagers were charged with terror-related offenses.\n\nPolice alleged all seven were part of a network that \"adhered to a religiously motivated, violent extremist ideology.\"\n\nSome Muslim leaders have criticized Australian police for declaring the church stabbing a terrorist act but not a rampage two days earlier in a Sydney shopping mall in which six people were killed and a dozen wounded.\n\nThe 40-year-old attacker, who was shot dead by police, had a history of schizophrenia and most of the victims he targeted were women. "sim": 0.6627451181411743, "url": "https://expressdigest.com/willetton-stabbing-radicalised-teenager-is-shot-dead-by-police-after-knife-rampage/", "title": "Willetton stabbing: 'Radicalised' teenager is shot dead by police after knife rampage", "body": "A 'radicalised' 16-year-old boy was shot dead by officers after stabbing a man in the back in a shopping centre car park.\n\nMore than 30 police vehicles rushed to Bunnings car park on High Street in Willetton, south Perth, about 10pm on Saturday following reports of a stabbing.\n\nThere officers found a 16-year-old brandishing a large kitchen knife and a man with serious back injuries.\n\nThe teenager was fatally shot by police after he 'rushed the attending officers'.\n\n'There are indications [the teenager] had been radicalised online,' Western Australia Premier Roger Cook told reporters in a press conference on Sunday morning.\n\n'Members of the WA Muslim community who were concerned by his behaviour contacted police prior to the incident and I thank them for their help.\n\n'Our police responded within minutes, they encountered a very confronting situation but their rapid and professional response kept our community safe.'\n\nA 16-year-old boy was shot dead by police in Perth on Saturday after stabbing a man in the back (pictured, emergency services at the scene)\n\nWA Police Commissioner Col Blanch clarified several concerned community members called triple-0 after the teenager indicated he was going to hurt people.\n\nThe teenager also phoned police and told operators he was planning a violent attack but did not reveal who or where he was.\n\nOfficers arrived at the Bunnings car park three minutes after the first triple-0 call.\n\nThe injured man, aged in his 30s and a stranger to the teenager, was taken to hospital in a serious but stable condition.\n\nIt's understood he was attacked he left a nearby 24-hour gym.\n\nTwo officers armed with Tasers and a third armed with a firearm ordered the teenager to drop the kitchen knife.\n\nThe 16-year-old lunged at two of the officers, who both deployed their Tasers.\n\nHowever, the teenager was wearing baggy clothing and was not deterred.\n\nHe was shot as he attempted to lunge at the third officer.\n\nCommissioner Blanch said the teenager had been taking part in a rehabilitation program for people who had been radicalised online since he was 14 years old.\n\n'We believe he was very much acting alone. We do not believe there was a network involved,' he said.\n\nCommissioner Blanch would not declare the stabbing as terrorism.\n\nPrime Minister Anthony Albanese released a statement about the incident on Sunday morning.\n\n'My thoughts are with those who have been affected by the incident in the Perth suburb of Willetton overnight,' he said.\n\n'I have spoken with WA Premier Roger Cook this morning, and I thank the WA Police for acting swiftly to contain the incident.'\n\nMore than 30 police vehicles rushed to Bunnings car park (pictured) on High Street in Willetton, south Perth , about 10pm on Saturday following reports of a stabbing\n\nMore to come.", "source": {"uri": "expressdigest.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "expressdigest.com"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "8113003617", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "02:03:15", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T02:03:15Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T02:01:52Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.658823549747467, "url": "https://wtop.com/world/2024/05/boy-shot-dead-after-perth-stabbing-was-in-deradicalization-program-but-no-ties-seen-to-sydney-teens/", "title": "Boy shot dead after Perth stabbing was in deradicalization program, but no ties seen to Sydney teens - WTOP News", "body": "MELBOURNE, Australia (AP) -- A 16-year-old boy who was shot dead by police after stabbing a man in the Australian west coast city of Perth had been in a deradicalization program but had no links to an alleged network of teen extremists in the east coast city of Sydney, authorities said.\n\nThe boy had participated in the federally funded Countering Violent Extremism program for two years but had no criminal record, Western Australia Police Minister Paul Papalia said Monday.\n\n\"The challenge we confront with people like the 16-year-old in this incident is that he's known to hold views that are dangerous and potentially he could be radicalized,\" Papalia told Australian Broadcasting Corp. \"... but the problem with individuals like this is they can act at short notice without warning and be very dangerous.\"\n\nOn the potential for the boy to have been radicalized, Prime Minister Anthony Albanese said he was concerned by social media pushing extreme positions.\n\n\"It's a dynamic that isn't just an issue for government. It's an issue for our entire society, whether it be violent extremism, misogyny and violence against women. It is an issue that of course I'm concerned about,\" Albanese told reporters.\n\nWestern Australia Police Commissioner Col Blanch said the boy had phoned police late Saturday saying he was about to commit \"acts of violence\" but did not say where. Minutes later, a member of the public reported to police seeing the boy with a knife in a hardware store parking lot.\n\nThree police officers responded, one armed with a gun and two with stun guns. Police deployed both stun guns but they failed to incapacitate the boy before he was killed by a single gunshot, Blanch said.\n\nThe stabbing victim is a man in his 30s who was wounded in his back. He was in serious but stable condition at a Perth hospital, police said.\n\nBlanch said members of the local Muslim community had raised concerns with police about the boy's behavior before he was killed on Saturday.\n\nPolice said the stabbing had the hallmarks of a terrorist attack but have not declared it as such. Factors that can influence that decision include whether state police need federal resources, including the Australian Security Intelligence Organization domestic spy agency.\n\nBlanch said the Western Australia Police Force investigation did not need additional federal resources and he was confidence the situation was different from the one in Sydney.\n\n\"We are dealing with complex issues, both mental health issues but also online radicalization issues,\" Blanch said Sunday. \"But we believe he very much is acting alone and we do not have concerns at this time that there is an ongoing network or other concerns that might have been seen over in Sydney.\"\n\nNew South Wales Police Commissioner Karen Webb had declared the stabbings of an Assyrian Orthodox bishop and priest in a Sydney church on April 15 as a terrorist act within hours. The boy arrested was later charged with committing a terrorist act. In the subsequent investigation, six more teenagers were charged with terror-related offenses.\n\nPolice alleged all seven were part of a network that \"adhered to a religiously motivated, violent extremist ideology.\"\n\nSome Muslim leaders have criticized Australian police for declaring last month's church stabbing a terrorist act but not a rampage two days earlier in a Sydney shopping mall in which six people were killed and a dozen wounded. The 40-year-old attacker was shot dead by police.\n\nThe man had a history of schizophrenia and most of the victims he targeted were women. Police have yet to reveal the man's motive.\n\nThe church attack is only the third to be classified by Australian authorities as a terrorist act since 2018.\n\nIn December 2022, three Christian fundamentalists shot dead two police officers and a bystander in an ambush near the community of Wieambilla in Queensland state. The shooters were later killed by police.\n\nIn November 2018, a Somalia-born Muslim stabbed three pedestrians in downtown Melbourne, killing one, before police shot him dead.\n\nCopyright \u00a9 2024 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. "news", "sim": 0.6549019813537598, "url": "https://7news.com.au/news/teen-shot-dead-by-police-outside-wa-bunnings-after-stabbing-attack-at-willetton-perth-c-14552382", "title": "Teen shot dead by police outside WA Bunnings after stabbing", "body": "The teenage boy had been radicalised online, but is understood to have acted alone, police said.\n\nA 16-year-old Caucasian boy has been fatally shot by police outside Bunnings at Willetton after he stabbed a man in his 30s with a 30cm kitchen knife that he had taken from his house, on Saturday night.\n\nIt is understood the boy had been radicalised online, WA Premier Roger Cook said at a press conference on Sunday.\n\nWATCH THE VIDEO ABOVE: Police provide update on Willetton incident.\n\n\"The teen made a triple-0 call at 10.10pm and said he was \"going to commit acts of violence,\" WA Police Commissioner Col Blanch said.\n\n\"He didn't provide his name, or a location, and the phone call was then terminated.\"\n\nPolice then received a second call from someone at the scene shortly after stating \"a male with a knife was running around a car park,\" Blanch said.\n\nThree officers arrived minutes later and asked the teen to put down the knife, but he did not comply and rushed at two of the officers who deployed their tasers.\n\nThe tasers did not stop the teen, Blanch said, and he continued to advance at the third officer who discharged his firearm, killing the boy.\n\nBlanch added that he had viewed the body camera footage and that the officers acted professionally and within their training.\n\n\"I know that that officer and his extended colleagues are hurting this morning as a result of that outcome,\" Blanch said.\n\nHe called the incident \"extremely confronting\".\n\nAn independent review into the police shooting will be conducted and an investigation into the incident is ongoing.\n\nThe stabbing victim sustained a single stab wound in the back -- which Blanch said was about 2cm deep and may have punctured a lung -- and is currently in a serious but stable condition.\n\nCook said members of the Muslim community had flagged the teen's behaviour to authorities before the incident.\n\n\"Members of the WA Muslim community who were concerned by his behaviour contacted police prior to the incident, and I thank them for their help,\" Cook said.\n\nCook and Blanch both said that while it appears the boy was radicalised, it's understood he acted alone and not as part of a network.\n\nThe boy had been part of the state's Countering Violent Extremism program, focussing on radicalisation, for two years.\n\n\"There are indications he had been radicalised online, but I want to reassure the public that at this stage it appears he acted solely and alone,\" Cook said.\n\nThe Prime Minister Anthony Albanese released a statement on the incident after a briefing with ASIO and the AFP.\n\n\"My thoughts are with those who have been affected by the incident in the Perth suburb of Willetton overnight. {"uri": "8113227126", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "06:07:17", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T06:07:17Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T06:06:22Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6549019813537598, "url": "https://www.indiandefensenews.in/2024/05/australian-police-gun-down-radicalised.html", "title": "Australian Police Gun Down Radicalised Teenager Who Stabbed Man In Perth", "body": "Australian Police Gun Down Radicalised Teenager Who Stabbed Man In Perth Monday, May 06, 2024 by Indian Defence News\n\nPerth: Australian Police on Sunday gunned down a teenage boy after he attacked a man with a knife in a suburb of Perth, CNN reported.\n\nCNN reported citing Western Australia (WA) Premier Roger Cook that a 16-year-old Caucasian male was armed with a knife when he carried out the attack in a suburb of Perth.\n\nWA police commissioner Col Blanch said that the attack \"has the hallmarks\" of a terrorist act, adding that it \"meets the criteria or at least the definition\" of this type of crime.\n\nBlanch said that on Saturday night, local police received a call from a male indicating that \"he was going to commit acts of violence.\"\n\nPolice received another call from a person minutes later stating that a man with a knife was running around, Blanch continued. Police immediately responded to that call, he said, and three officers were dispatched.\n\nWhen the officers arrived at the scene, they were confronted by the teen, who was alone and holding a \"large kitchen knife,\" Blanch said.\n\nThe officers ordered him to put down the knife, but the suspect refused, instead rushing the police. Two tasers were deployed and when they failed to subdue him, the third officer \"fired a single shot and fatally wounded the male,\" Blanch continued, CNN reported.\n\nPolice discovered after the shooting that the teen had stabbed and injured a middle-aged man prior to his confrontation with the police.\n\nThe victim is currently in hospital in a serious but stable condition with a wound in his back, Blanch said.\n\nCNN reported that the teen was known to the police prior to the incident, Blanch said, as \"he was part of a program about online radicalization for the last couple of years.\"\n\n\"We are dealing with complex issues with this 16-year-old male, both mental health issues but also online radicalization issues,\" Blanch said.\n\nThe program focused on covering violent extremism for those that are exhibiting concerning behaviour, Blanch said.\n\nBlanch said police received multiple calls both before and after the incident from members of Western Australia's Muslim community who had concerns about the individual.\n\n\"I do want to thank members of the Muslim community who did that because that enabled us to identify rapidly who this individual was and respond as [quickly] as we did,\" Blanch said.\n\nCNN reported that in a statement released Sunday regarding the incident, Australian Prime Minister Anthony Albanese said: \"We are a peace-loving nation and there is no place for violent extremism in Australia.\"\n\nThe incident comes after last month's stabbing of a priest and bishop at a church in Sydney. Police have arrested a 16-year-old over the attack, which they described as a terrorist act.\n\nThis report is auto-generated from a syndicated feed\n\nComments", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "8111783087", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "02:42:12", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T02:42:12Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T02:41:08Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6549019813537598, "url": "https://ca.news.yahoo.com/perth-stabbing-police-shoot-dead-020940574.html", "title": "Perth stabbing: police shoot dead boy, 16, after alleged attack that has 'hallmarks' of terror incident", "body": "Western Australian police say they have shot and killed a teenager who allegedly attacked a man in a Perth car park on Saturday night.\n\nDetectives on Sunday said there was no ongoing threat to the public and the 16-year-old was believed to have been acting alone in Willetton.\n\nThe WA police commissioner, Col Blanch, said the incident \"certainly has all the hallmarks\" of a terrorism-related incident, but he was not prepared to declare it as such \"at this stage.\"\n\n\"It would be too early for me to act now because I don't have the concerns of a broader network that might be involved at this stage,\" Blanch said.\n\nThe premier, Roger Cook, said there were indications the 16-year-old \"had been radicalised online\".\n\nRelated: 'A complete 180': how a trial treatment in Sydney for heroin addiction is changing lives\n\nBlanch said police received a call on Saturday night from a person who told the operator they were \"going to commit acts of violence\".\n\nThat person hung up without giving their name or location. But the call was followed by another alerting police to someone \"running around a car park\" with a large kitchen knife.\n\nThree police officers responded within minutes and were immediately confronted by the teenager holding a large knife, Blanch said.\n\nThe commissioner said two officers drew their Tasers and a third officer drew their firearm. When asked to put down the knife, the 16-year-old did not respond and, according to body-camera footage, allegedly ran at the officers, Blanch said.\n\nThe first two officers fired their tasers but when the teenager allegedly continued to approach, the third officer fired a single shot which fatally wounded the 16-year-old, police said.\n\nBlanch said the teenager acted alone in what appeared to be a \"a very sad and tragic outcome\". He said what triggered the incident was currently unknown.\n\nThe 18-year-old who was stabbed was in a serious but stable condition in hospital and \"doing well\", authorities said on Sunday.\n\nThe prime minister, Anthony Albanese, said he had spoken to Cook and received briefings from police and domestic spy agency Asio.\n\n\"My thoughts are with those who have been affected by the incident,\" he said. \"We are a peace-loving nation and there is no place for violent extremism in Australia.\"\n\nCook, who has called a meeting with multi-faith community leaders, described the incident as a \"very tragic set of circumstances\" and thanked police for their swift action saying the community was \"indebted to them\".\n\n\"Our police responded within minutes. They encountered a very confronting situation but their rapid and professional response kept our community safe,\" the premier said.\n\n\"These cases are never straightforward. There's always a complex set of circumstances, cases and conditions which sit in the background.\"\n\nThe police commissioner described the alleged attacker as a \"Caucasian male\". He thanked members of the Muslim community who \"had the courage to respond and express their concerns that this person was exhibiting concerning behaviours\".\n\nBlanch said community members had {"uri": "8112996108", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "01:51:31", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T01:51:31Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T01:50:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6509804129600525, "url": "https://www.sandiegouniontribune.com/news/nation-world/story/2024-05-05/boy-shot-dead-after-perth-stabbing-was-in-deradicalization-program-but-no-ties-seen-to-sydney-teens", "title": "Boy shot dead after Perth stabbing was in deradicalization program, but no ties seen to Sydney teens", "body": "A 16-year-old boy who was shot dead by police after stabbing a man in the Australian west coast city of Perth had been in a deradicalization program but had no links to an alleged network of teen extremists in the east coast city of Sydney, authorities said.\n\nThe boy had participated in the federally funded Countering Violent Extremism program for two years but had no criminal record, Western Australia Police Minister Paul Papalia said Monday.\n\n\"The challenge we confront with people like the 16-year-old in this incident is that he's known to hold views that are dangerous and potentially he could be radicalized,\" Papalia told Australian Broadcasting Corp. \"... but the problem with individuals like this is they can act at short notice without warning and be very dangerous.\"\n\nOn the potential for the boy to have been radicalized, Prime Minister Anthony Albanese said he was concerned by social media pushing extreme positions.\n\n\"It's a dynamic that isn't just an issue for government. It's an issue for our entire society, whether it be violent extremism, misogyny and violence against women. It is an issue that of course I'm concerned about,\" Albanese told reporters.\n\nWestern Australia Police Commissioner Col Blanch said the boy had phoned police late Saturday saying he was about to commit \"acts of violence\" but did not say where. Minutes later, a member of the public reported to police seeing the boy with a knife in a hardware store parking lot.\n\nThree police officers responded, one armed with a gun and two with stun guns. Police deployed both stun guns but they failed to incapacitate the boy before he was killed by a single gunshot, Blanch said.\n\nThe stabbing victim is a man in his 30s who was wounded in his back. He was in serious but stable condition at a Perth hospital, police said.\n\nBlanch said members of the local Muslim community had raised concerns with police about the boy's behavior before he was killed on Saturday.\n\nPolice said the stabbing had the hallmarks of a terrorist attack but have not declared it as such. Factors that can influence that decision include whether state police need federal resources, including the Australian Security Intelligence Organization domestic spy agency.\n\nBlanch said the Western Australia Police Force investigation did not need additional federal resources and he was confidence the situation was different from the one in Sydney.\n\n\"We are dealing with complex issues, both mental health issues but also online radicalization issues,\" Blanch said Sunday. \"But we believe he very much is acting alone and we do not have concerns at this time that there is an ongoing network or other concerns that might have been seen over in Sydney.\"\n\nNew South Wales Police Commissioner Karen Webb had declared the stabbings of an Assyrian Orthodox bishop and priest in a Sydney church on April 15 as a terrorist act within hours. The boy arrested was later charged with committing a terrorist act. In the subsequent investigation, six more teenagers were charged with terror-related offenses.\n\nPolice alleged all seven were part of a network that \"adhered to a religiously motivated, violent extremist ideology.\"\n\nSome Muslim leaders have criticized Australian police for declaring last month's church stabbing a terrorist act but not a rampage two days earlier in a Sydney shopping mall in which six people were killed and a dozen wounded. The 40-year-old attacker was shot dead by police.\n\nThe man had a history of schizophrenia and most of the victims he targeted were women. Police have yet to reveal the man's motive.\n\nThe church attack is only the third to be classified by Australian authorities as a terrorist act since 2018.\n\nIn December 2022, three Christian fundamentalists shot dead two police officers and a bystander in an ambush near the community of Wieambilla in Queensland state. The shooters were later killed by police.\n\nIn November 2018, a Somalia-born Muslim stabbed three pedestrians in downtown Melbourne, killing one, before police shot him dead.", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "2024-05-346009313", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "07:06:42", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T07:06:42Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T01:47:38Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6470588445663452, "url": "https://www.aol.com/boy-shot-dead-perth-stabbing-014738230.html", "title": "Boy shot dead after Perth stabbing was in deradicalization program, but no ties seen to Sydney teens", "body": "Boy shot dead after Perth stabbing was in deradicalization program, but no ties seen to Sydney teensROD McGUIRKMay 6, 2024 at 7:37 AM\n\nMELBOURNE, Australia (AP) -- A 16-year-old boy who was shot dead by police after stabbing a man in the Australian west coast city of Perth had been in a deradicalization program but had no links to an alleged network of teen extremists in the east coast city of Sydney, authorities said.\n\nThe boy had participated in the federally funded Countering Violent Extremism program for two years but had no criminal record, Western Australia Police Minister Paul Papalia said Monday.\n\n\"The challenge we confront with people like the 16-year-old in this incident is that he's known to hold views that are dangerous and potentially he could be radicalized,\" Papalia said. \"But the problem with individuals like this is they can act at short notice without warning and be very dangerous.\"\n\nOn the potential for the boy to have been radicalized, Prime Minister Anthony Albanese said he was concerned by social media pushing extreme positions.\n\n\"It's a dynamic that isn't just an issue for government. It's an issue for our entire society, whether it be violent extremism, misogyny and violence against women. It is an issue that of course I'm concerned about,\" Albanese told reporters.\n\nWestern Australia Police Commissioner Col Blanch said the boy had phoned police late Saturday saying he was about to commit \"acts of violence\" but did not say where. Minutes later, a member of the public reported to police seeing the boy with a knife in a hardware store parking lot.\n\nThree police officers responded, one armed with a gun and two with stun guns. Police deployed both stun guns but they failed to incapacitate the boy before he was killed by a single gunshot, Blanch said.\n\nThe stabbing victim is a man in his 30s who was wounded in his back. He was in serious but stable condition at a Perth hospital, police said.\n\nBlanch said members of the local Muslim community had raised concerns with police about the boy's behavior before he was killed on Saturday.\n\nThe boy had said in a text message to associates, \"I am going on the path of jihad tonight for the sake of Allah,\" Australian Associated Press reported, prompting several to alert police.\n\nPolice said the stabbing had the hallmarks of a terrorist attack but have not declared it as such. Factors that can influence that decision include whether state police need federal resources, including the Australian Security Intelligence Organization domestic spy agency.\n\nBlanch said the Western Australia Police Force investigation did not need additional federal resources and he was confidence the situation was different from the one in Sydney.\n\n\"We are dealing with complex issues, both mental health issues but also online radicalization issues,\" Blanch said Sunday. \"But we believe he very much is acting alone and we do not have concerns at this time that there is an ongoing network or other concerns that might have been seen over in Sydney.\"\n\nWestern Australia Premier Roger Cook said his government and the state education department had been aware of concerns at the boy's school about his behavior. Cook didn't directly respond to reports that several boys at Rossmoyne Senior High School, the prestigious government school he attended, were attempting to radicalize classmates.\n\n\"I'll leave that up the the Education Department to clarify,\" Cook told reporters. \"This young man was harboring some extremist thoughts, which is the reason why he was part of the Countering Violent Extremism program.\"\n\nAmanda Spencer-Teo, a parent of a Rossmoyne student, said multiple \"red flags\" had been raised about the behavior of some students.\n\n\"Parents have been raising this with the school for some time,\" Spencer-Teo, who will be an opposition party candidate at state elections next year, told The Australian newspaper. \"The school and the department have failed to provide information to those concerned parents.\"\n\nIn the stabbings at a Sydney church on April 15, New South Wales Police Commissioner Karen Webb declared the stabbings of an Assyrian Orthodox bishop and priest as a terrorist act within hours. The boy arrested was later charged with committing a terrorist act. In the subsequent investigation, six more teenagers were charged with terror-related offenses.\n\nPolice alleged all seven were part of a network that \"adhered to a religiously motivated, violent extremist ideology.\"\n\nSome Muslim leaders have criticized Australian police for declaring the church stabbing a terrorist act but not a rampage two days earlier in a Sydney shopping mall in which six people were killed and a dozen wounded.\n\nThe 40-year-old attacker, who was shot dead by police, had a history of schizophrenia and most of the victims he targeted were women. with a knife was running around the car park\" in Willetton, a southern suburb of Perth, he said.\n\nPolice body camera images showed the teenager refused officers' demands that he put down the knife, the police chief said.\n\nThe weapon was a 30-centimeter kitchen knife, believed to be from the attacker's home, he said.\n\nOfficers fired two Tasers at him but \"both of them did not have the full desired effect,\" he said.\n\n\"The male continued to advance on the third officer with a firearm who fired a single shot and fatally wounded the male.\"\n\nThe teenager died in hospital later in the It's an issue for our entire society, whether it be violent extremism, misogyny and violence against women. It is an issue that of course I'm concerned about.\"\n\nWestern Australia Police Commissioner Col Blanch said the boy had phoned police late on Saturday saying he was about to commit \"acts of violence\" but did not say where. Police deployed both stun guns but they failed to incapacitate the boy before he was killed by a single gunshot, Mr Blanch said.\n\nThe stabbing victim is a man in his 30s who was wounded in the back. He was in serious but stable condition at a Perth hospital, police said.\n\nMr Blanch said members of the local Muslim community had raised concerns with police about the boy's behaviour before he was killed on Saturday.\n\nThe boy had said in a text message to associates, \"I am going on the path of jihad tonight for the sake of Allah,\" Australian Associated Press reported, prompting several to alert police.\n\nPolice said the stabbing had the hallmarks of a terrorist attack but have not declared it as such.\n\nFactors that can influence that decision include whether state police need federal resources, including the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation domestic spy agency.\n\n\"We are dealing with complex issues, both mental health issues but also online radicalization issues,\" Mr Blanch said on Sunday.\n\n\"But we believe he very much is acting alone and we do not have concerns at this time that there is an ongoing network or other concerns that might have been {"uri": "8111865903", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "04:41:40", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T04:41:40Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T04:40:37Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6431372761726379, "url": "https://uk.news.yahoo.com/perth-stabbing-police-shoot-dead-020940574.html", "title": "Perth stabbing: police shoot dead boy, 16, after alleged attack that has 'hallmarks' of terror incident", "body": "Western Australian police say they have shot and killed a teenager who allegedly attacked a man in a Perth car park on Saturday night.\n\nDetectives on Sunday said there was no ongoing threat to the public and the 16-year-old was believed to have been acting alone in Willetton.\n\nThe WA police commissioner, Col Blanch, said the incident \"certainly has all the hallmarks\" of a terrorism-related incident, but he was not prepared to declare it as such \"at this stage\".\n\n\"It's about timing,\" Blanch said. \"It would be too early for me to act now because I don't have the concerns of a broader network that might be involved.\"\n\nThe premier, Roger Cook, said there were indications the 16-year-old \"had been radicalised online\".\n\nThe 18-year-old who was stabbed was in a serious but stable condition in hospital and \"doing well\", authorities said on Sunday.\n\nRelated: 'A complete 180': how a trial treatment in Sydney for heroin addiction is changing lives\n\nBlanch said police received a call on Saturday night from a person who told the operator they were \"going to commit acts of violence\".\n\nThat person hung up without giving their name or location. But the call was followed by another alerting police to someone \"running around a car park\" with a large kitchen knife.\n\nThree police officers responded within minutes and were immediately confronted by the teenager holding a large knife, Blanch said.\n\nThe commissioner said two officers drew their Tasers and a third officer drew their firearm. When asked to put down the knife, the 16-year-old did not respond and, according to body-camera footage, allegedly ran at the officers, Blanch said.\n\nThe first two officers fired their Tasers but when the teenager allegedly continued to approach, the third officer fired a single shot which fatally wounded the 16-year-old, police said.\n\nBlanch said the teenager acted alone in what appeared to be a \"a very sad and tragic outcome\". He said what triggered the incident was unknown.\n\nThe teenager was allegedly known to police and had been involved in a countering violent extremism (CVE) program since 2022 when he was 13.\n\nThe program provides support from psychologists, the education department and, where appropriate, faith leaders.\n\nWA's CVE was based on work undertaken by Anne Aly - who is now the federal youth minister - and programs used to deradicalise neo-Nazis overseas. It was not limited to those convicted of crimes.\n\nRelated: Western Australia's eucalypt forests fade to brown as century-old giant jarrahs die in heat and drought\n\nThe WA police minister, Paul Papalia, said the program aimed to de-escalate situations and avoid violence.\n\nThe prime minister, Anthony Albanese, said he had spoken to Cook and received briefings from police and the Australian intelligence agency, Asio.\n\n\"My thoughts are with those who have been affected by the incident,\" he said. \"We are a peace-loving nation and there is no place for violent extremism in Australia.\"\n\nCook, who has called a meeting with multi-faith community leaders, described the incident as a \"very tragic set of circumstances\" and thanked police for their swift action saying the community was \"indebted to them\".\n\n\"Our police responded within minutes. They encountered a very confronting situation but their rapid and professional response kept our community safe,\" the premier said.\n\n\"These cases are never straightforward. terms\".\n\n\"We are once again saddened to learn of another knife attack in which innocent civilians were harmed, this time in Perth,\" Tahir said. \"It should be made very clear that there is no {"uri": "8112365317", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "13:08:07", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T13:08:07Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T13:06:53Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6352941393852234, "url": "https://www.rocketnews.com/2024/05/radicalised-16-year-old-shot-dead-by-australia-police-after-stabbing-man/", "title": "'Radicalised' 16-year-old shot dead by Australia police after stabbing man - RocketNews", "body": "Police kill the boy after he stabbed a man in Perth in an attack authorities say indicated 'terrorism'.Police in Australia say they have shot dead a boy after he stabbed a man in the western city of Perth, in an attack authorities said had \"hallmarks of terrorism\".\n\nThere were signs the 16-year-old, armed with a kitchen knife, had been \"radicalised online\", Western Australia province's Premier Roger Cook told reporters on Sunday.\n\nThe victim in his 30s was stabbed in the back on Saturday night in the parking lot of a hardware store in the city's suburban Willetton area. Authorities said they received calls from concerned members of the local Muslim community before the attack. The man was stable in a hospital, authorities said.\n\n\"At this stage it appears that he acted solely and alone,\" Cook told a televised news conference in Perth.\n\nPrime Minister Anthony Albanese said he had been briefed on the incident by police and intelligence agencies, which advised there was no ongoing threat.\n\n\"We are a peace-loving nation and there is no place for violent extremism in Australia,\" Albanese said on X.\n\nMy thoughts are with those who have been affected by the incident in the Perth suburb of Willetton overnight.\n\nI have spoken with WA Premier Roger Cook this {"uri": "8113326921", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "07:25:18", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T07:25:18Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T07:24:13Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6352941393852234, "url": "https://www.nzherald.co.nz/world/boy-shot-dead-after-perth-stabbing-was-in-deradicalization-program-but-no-ties-seen-to-sydney-teens/4VVFCFUIJJGBFIDEPTR4YK75LI/", "title": "Boy shot dead after Perth stabbing was in deradicalization program", "body": "A 16-year-old boy shot dead by police after stabbing a man in Perth, Western Australia had been in a deradicalisation program but had no links to an alleged network of teen extremists in Sydney, authorities said.\n\nThe boy had participated in the federally funded Countering Violent Extremism program for two years but had no criminal record, Western Australia Police Minister Paul Papalia said on Monday.\n\n\"The challenge we confront with people like the 16-year-old in this incident is that he's known to hold views that are dangerous and potentially he could be radicalised,\" Papalia said. \"But the problem with individuals like this is they can act at short notice without warning and be very dangerous.\"\n\nOn the potential for the boy to have been radicalised, Prime Minister Anthony Albanese was concerned by social media pushing extreme positions.\n\n\"It's a dynamic that isn't just an issue for Government. It's an issue for our entire society, whether it be violent extremism, misogyny and violence against women. It is an issue that of course I'm concerned about.\"\n\nWestern Australia Police Commissioner Col Blanch said the boy had phoned police late Saturday saying he was about to commit \"acts of violence\" but did not say where. Minutes later, a member of the public reported to police seeing the boy with a knife in a hardware store carpark.\n\nThree police officers responded, one armed with a gun and two with stun guns. Police used both stun guns but they failed to incapacitate the boy before he was killed by a single gunshot, Blanch said.\n\nThe stabbing victim is a man in his 30s who was wounded in his back. He was in serious but stable condition at a Perth hospital, police said.\n\nBlanch said members of the Muslim community had raised concerns with police about the boy's behaviour before his death.\n\nThe boy had said in a text message to associates, \"I am going on the path of jihad tonight for the sake of Allah,\" Australian Associated Press reported, prompting several to alert police.\n\nPolice said the stabbing had the hallmarks of a terrorist attack but have not declared it as such. Factors that can influence that decision include whether state police need federal resources, including the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation domestic spy agency.\n\nBlanch said the Western Australia Police investigation did not need additional federal resources and he was confident the situation was different from the one in Sydney.\n\n\"We are dealing with complex issues, both mental health issues but also online radicalisation issues,\" Blanch said on Sunday. \"But we believe he very much is acting alone and we do not have concerns at this time that there is an ongoing network or other concerns that might have been seen over in Sydney.\"\n\nWestern Australia Premier Roger Cook said his Government and the state education department had been aware of concerns at the boy's school about his behaviour. Cook didn't directly respond to reports that several boys at Rossmoyne Senior High School, the prestigious school he attended, were attempting to radicalise classmates.\n\n\"I'll leave that up the Education Department to clarify,\" Cook told reporters. \"This young man was harbouring some extremist thoughts, which is the reason why he was part of the Countering Violent Extremism program.\"\n\nAmanda Spencer-Teo, a parent of a Rossmoyne student, said multiple \"red flags\" had been raised about the behaviour of some students.\n\n\"Parents have been raising this with the school for some time,\" Spencer-Teo, who will be an opposition party candidate at state elections next year, told The Australian newspaper. \"The school and the department have failed to provide information to those concerned parents.\"\n\nIn the stabbings at a Sydney church on April 15, New South Wales Police Commissioner Karen Webb declared the stabbings of an Assyrian Orthodox bishop and priest as a terrorist act within hours. The boy arrested was later charged with committing a terrorist act. In the subsequent investigation, six more teenagers were charged with terror-related offences.\n\nPolice alleged all seven were part of a network that \"adhered to a religiously motivated, violent extremist ideology\".\n\nSome Muslim leaders have criticised Australian police for declaring the church stabbing a terrorist act but not a rampage two days earlier in a Sydney shopping mall in which six people were killed and a dozen wounded.\n\nThe 40-year-old attacker, who was shot dead by police, had a history of schizophrenia and most of the victims he targeted were women. Police have yet to reveal the man's motive.", "source": {"uri": "nzherald.co.nz", "dataType": "news", "title": "NZ Herald"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "body": "SYDNEY (Reuters) - Australian police said on Sunday they shot dead a boy after he stabbed a man in Western Australia's capital Perth, in an attack authorities said indicated terrorism.\n\nThere were signs the 16-year-old, armed with a kitchen knife, had been radicalised online, state authorities said, adding they received calls from concerned members of the local Muslim community before the attack, which occurred late on Saturday night.\n\nThe attack, in the suburb of Willetton, had \"hallmarks\" of terrorism but was yet to be declared a terrorist act, police said.\n\n\"At this stage it appears that he acted solely and alone,\" Western Australia Premier Roger Cook said in a televised news conference in Perth, regarding the attacker.\n\nThe victim, stabbed in the back, was stable in hospital, authorities said.\n\nThe incident comes after New South Wales police last month charged several boys with terrorism-related offences in investigations following the stabbing of an Assyrian Christian bishop while he was giving a live-streamed sermon in Sydney, on April 15.\n\nThe attack on the bishop came only days after a deadly mass stabbing in the Sydney beachside suburb of Bondi that claimed the lives of six people.\n\nGun and knife crime is rare in Australia, which consistently ranks among the safest countries in the world, according to the federal government.\n\n(Reporting by Sam McKeith in Sydney; Editing by Christian Schmollinger)", "source": {"uri": "ca.news.yahoo.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Yahoo"}, "authors": [], "concepts": Police immediately responded to that call, he said, and three officers were dispatched.\n\nWhen the officers arrived at the scene, they were confronted by the teen, who was alone and holding a \"large kitchen knife,\" Blanch said.\n\nThe officers ordered him to put down the knife, but the suspect refused, instead rushing the police. Two tasers were deployed and when they failed to subdue him, the third officer \"fired a single shot and fatally wounded the male,\" Blanch continued.\n\nPolice discovered after the shooting that the teen had stabbed and injured a middle aged man prior to his confrontation with the police.\n\nThe victim is currently in hospital in a serious but stable condition with a wound in his back, Blanch said.\n\nThe teen was known to the police prior to the incident, Blanch said, as \"he was part of a program about online radicalization for the last couple of years.\"\n\n\"We are dealing with complex issues with this 16 year old male, both mental health issues but also online radicalization issues,\" Blanch said.\n\nThe program focused on covering violent extremism for those that are exhibiting concerning behavior, Blanch said.\n\nBlanch said police received multiple calls both before and after the incident from members of Western Australia's Muslim community who had concerns about the individual.\n\n\"I do want to thank members of the Muslim community who did that because that enabled us to identify rapidly who this individual was and respond as [quickly] as we did,\" Blanch said.\n\nIn a statement released Sunday regarding the incident, Australian Prime Minister Anthony Albanese said: \"We are a peace-loving nation and there is no place for violent extremism in Australia.\"\n\nThe incident comes after last month's stabbing of a priest and bishop at a church in Sydney. It's an issue for our entire society, whether it be violent extremism, misogyny and violence against women. It is an issue that of course I'm concerned about.\"\n\nWestern Australia Police Commissioner Col Blanch said the boy had phoned police late on Saturday saying he was about to commit \"acts of violence\" but did not say where. Minutes later, a member of the public reported to police seeing the boy with a knife in a hardware store car park.\n\nThree police officers responded, one armed with a gun and two with stun guns. Police deployed both stun guns but they failed to incapacitate the boy before he was killed by a single gunshot, Mr Blanch said.\n\nMr Blanch said members of the local Muslim community had raised concerns with police about the boy's behaviour before he was killed on Saturday.\n\nThe boy had said in a text message to associates, \"I am going on the path of jihad tonight for the sake of Allah,\" Australian Associated Press reported, prompting several to alert police.\n\nPolice said the stabbing had the hallmarks of a terrorist attack but have not declared it as such.\n\nFactors that can {"uri": "8111842566", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "04:09:36", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T04:09:36Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T04:09:05Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6235294342041016, "url": "https://www.thestar.com/news/world/australia/australian-police-shoot-dead-a-boy-16-armed-with-a-knife-after-he-stabbed-a/article_16db0428-b861-5e22-9b93-a7a1e926cfba.html", "title": "Australian police shoot dead a boy, 16, armed with a knife after he stabbed a man in Perth", "body": "MELBOURNE, Australia (AP) -- A 16-year-old boy armed with a knife was shot dead by police after he stabbed a man in the Australian west coast city of Perth, officials said Sunday.\n\nThe incident occurred in the parking lot of a hardware store in suburban Willetton on Saturday night.\n\n\u00d7\n\nAlready a Subscriber? Sign in You are logged in Switch accounts\n\nThe teen attacked the man and then rushed at police officers before he was shot, Western Australian Premier Roger Cook told reporters on Sunday.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\n\"There are indications he had been radicalized online,\" Cook told a news conference.\n\n\"But I want to reassure the community at this stage it appears that he acted solely and alone,\" Cook added.\n\nA man was found at the scene with stab wounds to his back. He was taken to a hospital in serious but stable condition, Australian Broadcasting Corp. reported.\n\nPolice and Australian Security Intelligence Organization agents have been conducting a counterterrorism investigation in the east coast city of Sydney since another 16-year-old boy stabbed an Assyrian Orthodox bishop and priest in a church on April 15.\n\nThat boy has been charged with committing a terrorist act. Six of his alleged associates have also been charged with a range of offenses, including conspiring to engage in or planning a terrorist act. All remain in custody.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nPrime Minister Anthony Albanese said he had been briefed on the latest stabbing in Perth by Australian Federal Police Commissioner Reece Kershaw and ASIO Director-General Mike Burgess, who heads the nation's main domestic spy agency.\n\n\"I'm advised there is no ongoing threat to the community on the information available,\" Albanese said.\n\n\"We are a peace-loving nation and there is no place for violent extremism in Australia,\" he added.\n\nPolice received an emergency phone call after 10 p.m. from a teenager saying he was going to commit acts of violence, Western Australian Police Commissioner Col Blanch said.\n\nThe boy had been participating in a program for young people at risk of radicalization, Blanch added.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\n\"I don't want to say he has been radicalized or is radicalized because I think that forms part of the investigation,\" he said.\n\nPolice said they were later alerted by a phone call from a member of the public that a knife attack was underway in the parking lot. Three police officers responded, one armed with a gun and two with conducted energy devices.\n\nPolice deployed both conducted energy devices but they failed to incapacitate the boy before he was killed by a single gunshot, Blanch said.\n\nSome Muslim leaders have criticized Australian police for declaring last month's church stabbing a terrorist act but not a rampage two days earlier in a Sydney shopping mall in which six people were killed and a dozen wounded. The 40-year-old attacker in the mall attack was shot dead by police. Police have yet to reveal the man's motive.\n\nThe church attack is only the third to be classified by Australian authorities as a terrorist act since 2018.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nIn December 2022, three Christian fundamentalists shot dead two police officers and a bystander in an ambush near the community of Wieambilla in Queensland state. {"uri": "8112544231", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "16:05:57", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T16:05:57Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T16:05:12Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6235294342041016, "url": "https://www.aninews.in/news/world/others/australian-police-gun-down-teenager-who-stabbed-man-in-perth20240505213305/", "title": "Australian Police gun down teenager who stabbed man in Perth", "body": "Perth [Australia], May 5 (ANI): Australian Police on Sunday gunned down a teenage boy after he attacked a man with a knife in a suburb of Perth, CNN reported.\n\nCNN reported citing Western Australia (WA) Premier Roger Cook that a 16-year-old Caucasian male was armed with a knife when he carried out the attack in a suburb of Perth.\n\nWA police commissioner Col Blanch said that the attack \"has the hallmarks\" of a terrorist act, adding that it \"meets the criteria or at least the definition\" of this type of crime.\n\nBlanch said that on Saturday night, local police received a call from a male indicating that \"he was going to commit acts of violence.\"\n\nPolice received another call from a person minutes later stating that a man with a knife was running around, Blanch continued. Police immediately responded to that call, he said, and three officers were dispatched.\n\nWhen the officers arrived at the scene, they were confronted by the teen, who was alone and holding a \"large kitchen knife,\" Blanch said.\n\nThe officers ordered him to put down the knife, but the suspect refused, instead rushing the police. Two tasers were deployed and when they failed to subdue him, the third officer \"fired a single shot and fatally wounded the male,\" Blanch continued, CNN reported.\n\nPolice discovered after the shooting that the teen had stabbed and injured a middle-aged man prior to his confrontation with the police.\n\nThe victim is currently in hospital in a serious but stable condition with a wound in his back, Blanch said.\n\nCNN reported that the teen was known to the police prior to the incident, Blanch said, as \"he was part of a program about online radicalization for the last couple of years.\"\n\n\"We are dealing with complex issues with this 16-year-old male, both mental health issues but also online radicalization issues,\" Blanch said.\n\nThe program focused on covering violent extremism for those that are exhibiting concerning behaviour, Blanch said.\n\nBlanch said police received multiple calls both before and after the incident from members of Western Australia's Muslim community who had concerns about the individual.\n\n\"I do want to thank members of the Muslim community who did that because that enabled us to identify rapidly who this individual was and respond as [quickly] as we did,\" Blanch said.\n\nCNN reported that in a statement released Sunday regarding the incident, Australian Prime Minister Anthony Albanese said: \"We are a peace-loving nation and there is no place for violent extremism in Australia.\"\n\nThe incident comes after last month's stabbing of a priest and bishop at a church in Sydney. Police have arrested a 16-year-old over the attack, which they described as a terrorist act. {"uri": "2024-05-345652524", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "13:50:06", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T13:50:06Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T09:07:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.615686297416687, "url": "https://www.channel3000.com/news/australian-police-shoot-dead-armed-teen-after-stabbing-attack-that-had-hallmarks-of-terror/article_a9915d30-7810-52c4-ba2e-41e5b2761eb0.html", "title": "Australian police shoot dead armed teen after stabbing attack that had 'hallmarks' of terror", "body": "(CNN) -- Australian police shot dead a teenage boy after he stabbed an injured a man in an attack that had the \"hallmarks\" of terror, authorities said.\n\nThe teenager, described as a 16-year-old Caucasian male, was armed with a knife when he carried out the attack in a suburb of Perth, Western Australia (WA) Premier Roger Cook said.\n\nWA police commissioner Col Blanch said that the attack \"has the hallmarks\" of a terrorist act, adding that it \"meets the criteria or at least the definition\" of this type of crime.\n\nBlanch said that on Saturday night, local police received a call from a male indicating that \"he was going to commit acts of violence.\"\n\nPolice received another call from a person minutes later stating that a man with a knife was running around, Blanch continued. Police immediately responded to that call, he said, and three officers were dispatched.\n\nWhen the officers arrived at the scene, they were confronted by the teen, who was alone and holding a \"large kitchen knife,\" Blanch said.\n\nThe officers ordered him to put down the knife, but the suspect refused, instead rushing the police. Two tasers were deployed and when they failed to subdue him, the third officer \"fired a single shot and fatally wounded the male,\" Blanch continued.\n\nPolice discovered after the shooting that the teen had stabbed and injured a middle aged man prior to his confrontation with the police.\n\nThe victim is currently in hospital in a serious but stable condition with a wound in his back, Blanch said.\n\nThe teen was known to the police prior to the incident, Blanch said, as \"he was part of a program about online radicalization for the last couple of years.\"\n\n\"We are dealing with complex issues with this 16 year old male, both mental health issues but also online radicalization issues,\" Blanch said.\n\nThe program focused on covering violent extremism for those that are exhibiting concerning behavior, Blanch said.\n\nBlanch said police received multiple calls both before and after the incident from members of Western Australia's Muslim community who had concerns about the individual.\n\n\"I do want to thank members of the Muslim community who did that because that enabled us to identify rapidly who this individual was and respond as [quickly] as we did,\" Blanch said.\n\nIn a statement released Sunday regarding the incident, Australian Prime Minister Anthony Albanese said: \"We are a peace-loving nation and there is no place for violent extremism in Australia.\"\n\nThe incident comes after last month's stabbing of a priest and bishop at a church in Sydney. CNN reported citing Western Australia (WA) Premier Roger Cook that a 16-year-old Caucasian male was armed with a knife when he carried out the attack in a suburb of Perth.\n\nWA police commissioner Col Blanch said that the attack \"has the hallmarks\" of a terrorist act, adding that it \"meets the criteria or at least the definition\" of this type of crime. Blanch said that on Saturday night, local police received a call from a male indicating that \"he was going to commit acts of violence.\" Australia Shocker: Bishop Mar Mari Emmanuel Stabbed Multiple Times During Mass at Wakeley Church in Sydney, Disturbing Video Surfaces.\n\nPolice received another call from a person minutes later stating that a man with a knife was running around, Blanch continued. Police immediately responded to that call, he said, and three officers were dispatched. When the officers arrived at the scene, they were confronted by the teen, who was alone and holding a \"large kitchen knife,\" Blanch said.\n\nThe officers ordered him to put down the knife, but the suspect refused, instead rushing the police. Two tasers were deployed and when they failed to subdue him, the third officer \"fired a single shot and fatally wounded the male,\" Blanch continued, CNN reported. Police discovered after the shooting that the teen had stabbed and injured a middle-aged man prior to his confrontation with the police. The victim is currently in hospital in a serious but stable condition with a wound in his back, Blanch said. Sydney Mall Attack: Australian Police Probe Why Joel Cauchi, Who Stabbed Six People to Death in Westfield Bondi Junction Mall Targeted Women.\n\nCNN reported that the teen was known to the police prior to the incident, Blanch said, as \"he was part of a program about online radicalization for the last couple of years.\" \"We are dealing with complex issues with this 16-year-old male, both mental health issues but also online radicalization issues,\" Blanch said. The program focused on covering violent extremism for those that are exhibiting concerning behaviour, Blanch said.\n\nBlanch said police received multiple calls both before and after the incident from members of Western Australia's Muslim community who had concerns about the individual. \"I do want to thank members of the Muslim community who did that because that enabled us to identify rapidly who this individual was and respond as [quickly] as we did,\" Blanch said.\n\nCNN reported that in a statement released Sunday regarding the incident, Australian Prime Minister Anthony Albanese said: \"We are a peace-loving nation and there is no place for violent extremism in Australia.\" The incident comes after last month's stabbing of a priest and bishop at a church in Sydney. {"uri": "8111968966", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "06:42:31", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T06:42:31Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T06:42:05Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6078431606292725, "url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2024/05/05/world/australia/perth-stabbing-teen-shot.html", "title": "Teenager Fatally Shot by Australian Police After He Stabbed a Man", "body": "The episode occurred just weeks after two major stabbing attacks in the country. The teen had been under monitoring for having extremist tendencies.\n\nThe police in Perth, Australia, fatally shot a 16-year-old boy who had stabbed a man in a parking lot and who officials said had been on their radar for suspicion of having extremist tendencies.\n\nThe shooting happened shortly after 10 p.m. Saturday, and occurred after the police in Western Australia state received a call from a male saying he was going to commit acts of violence, Police Commissioner Col Blanch said at a news conference on Sunday morning. Members of the public had also alerted the police that the teenager was wielding a knife, and officers were dispatched to the scene.\n\nThe episode comes just weeks after two stabbing attacks alarmed Australia. A mass stabbing in a shopping mall in Sydney killed six people and injured at least a dozen on April 13. Days later, a 15-year-old boy was arrested in the stabbing of an Assyrian Orthodox bishop and several other people during a mass that the police said was an act of terrorism.\n\nOn Saturday in Perth, the two officers who arrived to confront the teenager drew their tasers and a firearm, Commissioner Blanch said. They tried to convince him to drop his knife, but he did not comply and rushed at one of the officers.\n\nAfter the officers fired their tasers, the suspect continued to advance toward the officer carrying the firearm, who then fatally shot him. The teen died an hour later at the hospital.\n\nBefore his confrontation with the police, the suspect had stabbed a middle-age male in the parking lot. The victim, who suffered a stab wound to the back, was in serious but stable condition, the authorities said.\n\nThe police said the suspect, a white male whose identity was not released, had been known to the police for the last few years for having potentially violent extremist tendencies, officials said. But they concluded that in Saturday's attack \"it appears he acted solely and alone,\" according to Roger Cook, the premier of Western Australia.\n\n\"It's a very tragic event in Western Australia,\" Commissioner Blanch said at the news conference Sunday.\n\n\"We are a peace-loving nation and there is no place for violent extremism in Australia.\" Australia's prime minister, Anthony Albanese, said at cops before he was shot dead", "body": "Confronting footage has emerged of a 'radicalised' teen lunging at police with a knife before he was shot dead- as the boy's final message to friends is revealed.\n\nCCTV from a nearby Korean restaurant, shows the 16-year-old boy chasing after a police car as it entered a car park in Willetton in Perth on Saturday night.\n\nWA Police were called to the carpark outside Bunnings just after 10pm after reports the teen had stabbed a man not known to him in the back.\n\nCCTV showed police confronting and surrounding the teen as they begged him to drop the weapon.\n\nThe teen was seen standing a short distance away from about four police as blue and red lights flash off the rain-soaked carpark.\n\nHe was unsuccessfully tasered by two officers, before he lunged at a third, who fatally shot him.\n\nTerrifying footage has emerged of a 'radicalised' teen lunging at police with a knife before he was shot dead\n\nPolice were called to the car park shortly after 10pm on Saturday night\n\nREAD MORE: 'Radicalised' teenager is shot dead by police after knife rampage\n\nA man in his 30s, who was not known to the teenager, was taken to hospital in a serious condition with back injuries\n\nAdvertisement\n\nEarlier in the night, the teen had warned friends that he was 'going on the path of jihad'.\n\nThe message, sent to several people on social media, prompted a wave of calls to police about the boy's actions, The West Australian reported.\n\n'Brothers please forgive me for any time I have wronged you, I am going on the path of jihad tonight for the sake of Allah,' the boy wrote.\n\n'I am a soldier of the mujahideen of Al-Qaeda and take responsibility for the actions that will ... take place tonight.'\n\nThe message is littered with praise for Allah.\n\n'If you have any illegal on jihadi things online or in real life please make sure to hide them well and clear your technology such as laptops and phones including search history in ... as the police will likely look into my contacts,' he wrote.\n\n'I love you all.\n\n'Please don't forget me and the mujahideen in your duat (afterlife).'\n\nThe message ended with There is no need to reply to this text'.\n\nThe principal of the teen's former high school warned parents to be aware of 'misinformation or inappropriate comments'.\n\nAn email was sent to parents on Sunday afternoon offering support after the news broke that a student from the school was shot dead by police.\n\nThe principal also urged parents should be cautious of letting their children gather to discuss the ordeal and express their feelings without a responsible adult present.\n\nWA Police Commissioner Col Blanch said the teen did not comply and rushed at officers prompting them to deploy their tasers before third officer discharged a single shot.\n\nCCTV from a nearby restaurant showed the moments before teen shot by police\n\nThe teen had called police at 10.10pm without identifying himself to say he was 'going to commit acts of violence' before hanging up the phone.\n\nPolice said the teen was among 'three of four' participants of an official deradicalisation program for those exhibiting behaviours that might be religious or issues motivated since 2022.\n\nCommissioner Blanch said the boy was known to police, had mental health issues, and appeared to have been radicalised online.\n\n'Members of the WA Muslim community contacted police, also calling triple-0, just prior to the incident with their concerns,' he said.\n\n'I do want to thank members of the Muslim community who did that because that enabled us to identify rapidly who this individual was and respond as quick as we did,' he said.\n\nThe Imam of Perth's largest mosque, the Nasir Mosque, Imam Syed Wadood Janud condemned the attack in the strongest terms.\n\n'The whole community is shook, and we are all concerned regarding the perpetrators' online radicalisation that early reports are hinting towards,' he said.\n\n'There is no place for violence in Islam. We appreciate the effort of the police to keep our communities safe. I also want to commend the local Muslim community who had flagged the individual prior with the police.'\n\nThe teen had reportedly converted to Islam.\n\nCommissioner Blanch said the incident had the 'hallmarks' of a terrorist incident, but would not label it as such 'at this stage'.\n\n'I believe this is a person acting alone. I don't need additional capability at this time whilst it meets the criteria, or at least the definition,' Commissioner Blanch said.\n\n'It would be too early for me to act now, because I don't have the concerns of a broader network that might be involved at this stage.'\n\nWA Police were called to the carpark outside Bunnings Willetton on just after 10pm, where they found a teen armed with a 30cm kitchen knife\n\nWA Premier Roger Cook said there were indications the boy had been radicalised online.\n\nThe 16-year-old boy had previously been involved in a countering violent extremism program since 2022, with support from psychologists and faith leaders.\n\nPrime Minister Anthony Albanese said intelligence and security officers did not believe there was an ongoing threat.\n\n'I have received a briefing on the situation by the ASIO Director-General and the AFP Commissioner, and I'm advised there is no ongoing threat to the community on the information available,' he said.\n\n'We are a peace-loving nation and there is no place for violent extremism in Australia.'\n\nA man aged in his 30s, who was found close by with a stab wound and a punctured lung, had reportedly been leaving a 24-hour gym in the complex at the time of the attack.\n\nHe was treated at the scene by St John Ambulance WA and transported to Royal Perth Hospital where he remains in a serious but stable condition.\n\nMore than 30 police vehicles rushed to Bunnings (pictured) car park on High Street in Willetton, south Perth , about 10pm on Saturday following reports of a stabbing", But he didn't provide his name or a location.\n\nSome minutes later, police received another call from a person stating that a male with a knife was running around a car park. Police immediately responded to that call, and three officers attended that location. When they exited their vehicle, the officers were confronted by a male alone, with a large kitchen knife.\n\nBlanch said that the officers challenged the male to put down the knife, but he did not comply and rushed one of the officers. Two officers deployed their tasers but both of them didn't have the full desired effect. The male continued to advance on the third officer with a firearm, who fired a single shot and fatally wounded the male.\n\nThe deceased male was a 16-year-old Caucasian man. He was taken to hospital and declared deceased at approximately 11:00 p.m., the police commissioner added.\n\n\"There was a report and we didn't know that until after the shooting, that a male had been stabbed in the back in the car park where police did respond,\" Blanch said. \"That male is currently in hospital with a stab wound to the back. He's in a serious but stable condition.\"\n\nState media Australian Broadcasting Corporation quoted WA Premier Roger Cook as saying that there were indications that the boy had been radicalized {"uri": "8111777968", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "02:33:29", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T02:33:29Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T02:32:31Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5803921818733215, "url": "https://www.rnz.co.nz/news/world/516022/perth-police-shoot-16yo-dead-after-stabbing-in-bunnings-car-park", "title": "Perth police shoot 16yo dead after stabbing in Bunnings car park", "body": "A major investigation is underway in Perth after police shot dead a teenager who stabbed a member of the public.\n\nThe 16-year-old boy had been known to police and was part of a programme designed to help individuals at risk of being radicalised, the ABC reported.\n\nThe incident unfolded in a Bunnings car park in Willetton, in the city's south, overnight.\n\nAt a press conference on Sunday, Police Commissioner Col Blanch said police received an emergency call just after 10pm on Saturday, from a teen who said he was going to commit \"acts of violence\".\n\nMembers of Western Australia's Muslim community, who had received messages from the teen and were \"concerned\" by his behaviour, also contacted police prior to the shooting, the ABC reported.\n\n\"Our police responded within minutes,\" Blanch said.\n\nThe teen was shot by an officer after he rushed at police with a kitchen knife.\n\nA man was found later with stab wounds to his back. It was believed one could have punctured a lung, the ABC reported.\n\nThe man was recovering in hospital and was in a serious but stable condition on Sunday.\n\nBlanch said the teenager had \"complex issues, both mental but also online radicalisation issues\".\n\nHe was known to police, but it was believed that he acted alone.\n\nBlanch said the teen was part of a support programme for people with concerning ideologies, who \"may not be committing any crimes\".\n\nThe stabbing was not being labelled a terror attack at this time, the ABC reported.\n\nPolice were working with the boy's family, who were being \"very forthcoming\", Blanch said.\n\n\"You know, I think this is a very challenged individual who was there on the night.\n\n\"I think the family really do understand the situation that police were in.\"\n\nPolice Minister Paul Papalia said the fact that the teenager was in the Countering Violent Extremism programme showed how challenging it was to \"de-radicalise\" people.\n\n\"It is a really tough task and none of the programs that have been attempted anywhere have been universally successful,\" he told the ABC.\n\n\"[It is] a really serious challenge in changing someone who's been radicalised and attempting them to get back into a more reasonable pathway.\n\n\"This individual may not have done anything that would have enabled police to do anything The attack reportedly took place along High Street before 11.30pm local time on May 4.\n\nAccording to reports from WAMN News on May 5, a police operation was mobilised following the incident. Witnesses described a chaotic scene where a man wielding a long knife chased individuals on the street. The police have yet to release the total number of casualties involved in the attack.\n\nWestern Australia Premier Roger Cook said a 16-year-old male armed with a knife, was fatally wounded by a police officer who had discharged his firearm, ABC news reported.\n\n\"There are indications he had been radicalised online,\" Mr Cook said.\n\n\"But I want to reassure the community at this stage it appears that he acted solely and alone,\" he added.\n\n\"Members of the WA Muslim community, who were concerned by his behaviour, contacted police prior to the incident and I thank them for their help. Our police responded within minutes.\"\n\nAt about 10pm on May 4, the police received a triple-0 call from a male who said he was going to commit \"acts of violence\", ABC News reported.\n\nA family member of a witness, who was not named, recounted the harrowing experience to WAMN News. Her brother-in-law was chased by a man with a long knife, she said.\n\n\"After working out, he waited at the door for his friends, and then a man approached him with a knife,\" she said. The attacker reportedly shouted religious phrases before pursuing her brother-in-law, who managed to escape. The assailant then turned his attention to another group of people, attacking one of them.\n\nAs the investigation continues, High Road Westbound in Willetton remains closed between Yampi Way and Leach Highway. Authorities are expected to provide further updates as they gather more information on the circumstances surrounding the attack.\n\nThe Perth attack comes weeks after a stabbing spree in a Sydney mall on April 13 which left six people dead and a knife attack in a church two days later which left at least four people, including a bishop, wounded.", "source": {"uri": "straitstimes.com", "dataType":
