{"uri": "8113226965", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "06:06:35", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T06:06:35Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T06:06:15Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5529412031173706, "url": "https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/article/2024/may/06/perth-stabbing-teenager-shot-dead-police-willetton-bunnings-car-park-ntwnfb", "title": "Perth teenager shot dead in Bunnings car park warned police he would 'commit acts of violence'", "body": "The Perth teenager shot dead by police in a suburban car park after he stabbed a man rang police before the assault, warning he was going to \"commit acts of violence\" and told friends he was going \"in the path of jihad\".\n\nThe 16-year-old teenager, who cannot be named, was shot dead in the car park of Bunnings Warehouse in Willetton, in Perth's south, on Saturday night, after he stabbed a man in the back and then refused police orders to put down his knife.\n\nImmediately before the attack, police received a triple-zero call from a person, believed to be the teenager, who told the operator they were \"going to commit acts of violence\", before hanging up.\n\nThe boy also messaged multiple people before the assault saying: \"Brothers please forgive me for any time I have wronged you, I am going in the path of jihad tonight for the sake of allah azzawajal, I am a soldier of the mujahideen of al-qaeda and take responsibility for the actions that will in sha allah ta'ala take place tonight [sic].\"\n\nSeveral of those who received the message called police. Police also received reports of a person \"running around a car park\" carrying a large knife.\n\nThree police officers confronted the teenager in the car park. Two officers drew their Tasers and a third drew a firearm. When asked to put down the knife, the 16-year-old did not respond and, according to body-camera footage, ran at the officers.\n\nThe first two officers fired their Tasers but when the teenager allegedly continued to approach, the third officer fired a single shot, fatally wounding the 16-year-old, police said.\n\nIt was only after the teenager was shot that police discovered the man he had stabbed in the back. The man, aged in his 30s, was taken to hospital in a serious but stable condition.\n\nWA police commissioner, Col Blanch, said the teenager acted alone in what appeared to be a \"a very sad and tragic outcome\". He said any triggerfor the incident was unknown.\n\nThe teenager was not known to be involved at any local mosques. He had suffered mental health issues, was known to police and had been involved in a countering violent extremism (CVE) program since 2022 when he was 13, the commissioner said.\n\nBlanch said the teenager was one of \"three or four\" under-18s in the deradicalisation program.\n\n\"All police around the country have what is called the countering violent extremism program for those ... exhibiting behaviours that might be religious or issues-motivated concerns,\" he said.\n\n\"We do have young people in those programs that have exhibited those behaviours. This 16-year-old caucasian male was part of that program.\"\n\nThe WA premier, Roger Cook, said on Monday that the attack had \"all the hallmarks of a terrorist incident\".\n\n\"This young man was harbouring some extremist thoughts, which is the reason why he was part of the countering violent extremism program,\" he said.\n\nThe state's police minister, Paul Papalia, said no deradicalisation program could guarantee success.\n\n\"It is a really tough task and none of the programs that have been attempted anywhere have been universally successful,\" he said. \"They are confronting a serious challenge in changing someone who's been radicalised and attempting to get them back on to a more reasonable pathway.\n\n\"What it demonstrates is just how tough a task it is. Individuals acting alone in isolation from other people can easily be influenced online and we would not necessarily know about it, and they can act with little warning.\"\n\nThe teenager attended nearby Rossmoyne Senior high school. Parents at the school had previously raised concerns about an allaged cohort of radicalised boys at the school, with at least one parent having flagged concerns to the WA education department and to the Australian Federal Police that the group had tried to \"indoctrinate\" their son.\n\nAt the school on Monday a parent, Niranji Wickranasinghe, said it was understood the teenager converted to Islam a few years ago.\n\n\"He was a very kind-hearted, helpful child. My son, who is in year 9, has said he was very friendly and he has helped him before as a friend and he's a good child,\" she said.\n\n\"I think they said he was watching some videos online. . . he's not a bad kind of child. ... but because of these online issues, I think he has gone mad.\"\n\nThe imam of Perth's largest mosque, Nasir Mosque, said the city's Islamic community feared a wave of Islamophobic backlash in the aftermath of the attack.\n\n\"We're extremely concerned about Islamophobia,\" the iman, Syed Wadood Janud, said.\n\n\"Sometimes the backlash can be very harsh, and that's why we want to reach out to the wider community.\n\n\"We condemn any act of violence which is committed in our name, in the name of our religion. Our religion literally means peace.\"\n\nThe prime minister, Anthony Albanese, said he had received a briefing from the Asio director general, Mike Burgess, and AFP commissioner, Reece Kershaw, and said there was \"no ongoing threat\" to the community.\n\n\"We are a peace-loving nation and there is no place for violent extremism in Australia,\" he said.", "source": {"uri": "theguardian.com", [It is] a really serious challenge in changing someone who's been radicalised and attempting them to get back into a more reasonable pathway.\n\n\"It is a good program in that regard, because in the absence of it, there's no response to that sort of thing, but also to be part of it, you're not necessarily a criminal. You haven't engaged necessarily in any criminal activity.\n\n\"This individual may not have done anything that would have enabled police to do anything other than get him into this program.\"\n\nWA Premier Roger Cook said that, while the alleged offender was radicalised online by extremist ideology, he acted alone and it was not being declared a terrorist event. He has called a meeting with leaders of various faiths, which he will attend later today.\n\n\"It certainly has the hallmarks of one, and the reason why I would declare it as a terrorist act going forward, it's about timing,\" he said.\n\n\"If I need extra capability, particularly from the Commonwealth, sometimes you'll see terrorist acts being claimed very early or declared very early.\n\n\"I believe this is a person acting alone ... I don't need additional capability at this time whilst it meets the criteria, or at least the definition.\n\n\"That's something that we can work towards as we find out more information from the motivations behind this.\"\n\nThe victim is currently in hospital with a stab wound to the back, in a serious but stable condition. {"uri": "8112037633", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "07:54:04", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T07:54:04Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T07:53:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5411764979362488, "url": "https://theprint.in/world/australian-police-shoot-boy-dead-after-stabbing-with-hallmarks-of-terrorism/2070468/", "title": "Australian police shoot boy dead after stabbing with 'hallmarks' of terrorism", "body": "The attack, in the suburb of Willetton, had \"hallmarks\" of terrorism but was yet to be declared a terrorist act, police said.\n\n\"At this stage it appears that he acted solely and alone,\" Western Australia Premier Roger Cook told a televised press conference in the state capital Perth, regarding the attacker.\n\nThe victim, stabbed in the back, was stable in hospital, authorities said.\n\nPrime Minister Anthony Albanese said he had been briefed on the incident by police and intelligence agencies, which advised there was no ongoing threat.\n\n\"We are a peace-loving nation and there is no place for violent extremism in Australia,\" Albanese said on social media platform X.\n\nThe incident comes after New South Wales police last month charged several boys with terrorism-related offences in investigations following the stabbing of an Assyrian Christian bishop while he was giving a live-streamed sermon in Sydney, on April 15.\n\nThe attack on the bishop came only days after a stabbing spree killed six in the Sydney beachside suburb of Bondi.\n\nGun and knife crime is rare in Australia, which consistently ranks among "body": "Prime Minister Anthony Albanese has reiterated there is \"no place for violent extremism\" in Australia after the Willetton stabbing attack.\n\nMr Albanese has spoken with WA Premier Roger Cook about the incident on Saturday night, in which a 16-year-old boy wielding a knife was shot dead by a police officer after stabbing a man.\n\nWA Police Commissioner Col Blanch said the boy, who was known to police, had mental health issues, and may have been radicalised online.\n\nHe was also one of a handful of teenagers in WA participating in a police deradicalisation program.\n\nMr Albanese thanked WA Police for \"acting swiftly to contain the incident\".\n\n\"My thoughts are with those who have been affected by the incident in the Perth suburb of Willetton overnight,\" Mr Albanese said in a statement.\n\n\"I have also received a briefing on the situation by the ASIO Director-General and the AFP Commissioner, and I'm advised there is no ongoing threat to the community on the information available.\"\n\nMr Albanese said Australia was a \"peace-loving nation\" and there was no \"no place for violent extremism in Australia\".\n\nThe prime minister made similar comments last month after a 16-year-old boy allegedly stabbed Bishop Mar Mari Emmanuel while he delivering a sermon inside a Sydney church.\n\nThe alleged stabbing was quickly declared a terrorist incident with a joint Federal-NSW counterterrorism taskforce stood up to investigate.\n\nSix teenagers associated with the alleged attacker were charged after authorities descended on properties across western Sydney and southern NSW.\n\nCommissioner Blanch said while the Willetton attack had all the \"hallmarks\" of a terrorist incident, he wouldn't declare it one at this stage because he believed the 16-year-old was acting alone and WA didn't require extra Commonwealth resources.\n\nSpeaking last month at the National Press Club, ASIO boss Mike Burgess said the radicalisation of minors was firmly on the agency's radar.\n\n\"There's been a growing number of minors in our counter-terrorism caseload,\" Mr Burgess said.\n\n\"That did peak a couple of years ago to 50 per cent of It is understood he had been leaving a 24-hour gym in the complex.\n\nHe was treated at the scene by St John Ambulance WA and transported to Royal Perth Hospital where he remains in a serious but stable condition.\n\nCommissioner Blanch said the boy was known to police, had mental health issues, and appeared to have been radicalised online.\n\n\"Members of the local Muslim community contacted police, also calling triple-0, just prior to the incident with their concerns,\" he said.\n\nPolice have said the incident has all the \"hallmarks\" of a terrorist incident, but have not to declare it as one.\n\nThe Imam of Perth's largest mosque, the Nasir Mosque, Imam Syed Wadood Janud condemned the attack in the strongest terms.\n\n\"The whole community is shook, and we are all concerned regarding the perpetrators' online radicalisation that early reports are hinting towards,\" he said.\n\n\"There is no place for violence in Islam. It is understood he had been leaving a 24-hour gym in the complex.\n\nHe was treated at the scene by St John Ambulance WA and transported to Royal Perth Hospital where he remains in a serious but stable condition.\n\nCommissioner Blanch said the boy was known to police, had mental health issues, and appeared to have been radicalised online.\n\n\"Members of the local Muslim community contacted police, also calling triple-0, just prior to the incident with their concerns,\" he said.\n\nPolice have said the incident has all the \"hallmarks\" of a terrorist incident, but have not to declare it as one.\n\nThe Imam of Perth's largest mosque, the Nasir Mosque, Imam Syed Wadood Janud condemned the attack in the strongest terms.\n\n\"The whole community is shook, and we are all concerned regarding the perpetrators' online radicalisation that early reports are hinting towards,\" he said.\n\n\"There is no place for violence in Islam. We appreciate the effort of the police to keep our communities safe. I also want to commend the local Muslim community who had flagged the individual prior with the police.\"\n\nThe Australian National Imams Council described the incident as \"tragic\".\n\n\"The young He didn't provide his name nor location and the phone call was terminated. Some minutes later, police received another triple zero call from a person ... stating that a male with a knife was running around the car park.\"\n\nHe said three officers attended within three minutes of the call and were confronted by the youth, who was wielding a large kitchen knife. Police tasered him but he continued to threaten them with the knife, and he was shot dead.\n\nIn Sydney three weeks ago an Assyrian Orthodox bishop was stabbed by another teenager who the authorities believe had been radicalised.\n\nThat attack unearthed a network of extremist teenagers whose messages online revealed their intentions to maim Jewish people. Seven were arrested in police raids on their homes in the days after the attack.\n\nAustralia's domestic intelligence agency warned of the online radicalisation of teenagers in its annual threat assessment in February.\n\nMike Burgess, director-general of Australian Security Intelligence Organisation, said the numbers had \"increased dramatically\" and teenagers were now the focus of more than half of its highest priority investigations each week.\n\nThe increase involved children as young as 13, a trend Burgess described as \"deeply concerning\".\n\nAnthony Albanese, the prime minister, said he had been briefed on the latest attack. The teenager allegedly \"rushed\" towards police officers after attacking the aforementioned individual and was subsequently shot dead by an officer, Premier Roger Cook said.\n\n\"There are indicators he had been radicalised online. But I want to reassure the community at this stage it appears he acted solely and alone,\" Cook said, as reported by AFP.\n\nPolice were alerted late on Saturday by a caller who issued a warning regarding his intention to commit \"acts of violence\", but refrained from disclosing his identity and whereabouts, the AFP report said, citing the state police commissioner's statements to reporters.\n\nWithin moments of the initial call, another emergency call notified authorities of a \"male with a knife running around the car park\" in Willetton, a southern suburb of Perth, the commissioner said.\n\nBody camera footage from police officers depicted the teenager refusing commands to disarm. Despite officers deploying two tasers, both attempts failed to fully subdue the teenager.\n\n\"The male continued to advance on the third officer with a firearm who fired a single shot and wounded the male,\" the commissioner was quoted as saying by AFP.\n\nREAD | Australia: Multiple People Injured In Church Stabbing Incident Near Sydney, Second Attack In 3 Days\n\nIn a separate incident last week, at Christ The Good Shepherd Church, Sydney, a 16-year-old boy allegedly attacked Bishop Mar Mari Emmanuel and Father Issac Royal during a church service. reiterated there is \"no place for violent extremism\" in Australia after the Willetton stabbing attack.\n\nMr Albanese has spoken with WA Premier Roger Cook about the incident on Saturday night, in which a 16-year-old boy wielding a knife was shot dead by a police officer after stabbing a man.\n\nWA Police Commissioner Col Blanch said the boy, who was known to police, had mental health issues, and may have been radicalised online.\n\nHe was also one of a handful of teenagers in WA participating in a police deradicalisation program.\n\nTheNightlyGet in front of tomorrow's news for FREE\n\nJournalism for the curious Australian across politics, business, culture and opinion.\n\nREAD NOW\n\nMr Albanese thanked WA Police for \"acting swiftly to contain the incident\".\n\n\"My thoughts are with those who have been affected by the incident in the Perth suburb of Willetton overnight,\" Mr Albanese said in a statement.\n\n\"I have also received a briefing on the situation by the ASIO Director-General and the AFP Commissioner, and I'm advised there is no ongoing threat to the community on the information available.\"\n\nMr Albanese said Australia was a \"peace-loving nation\" and there was no \"no place for violent extremism in Australia\".\n\nYour cookie settings are preventing this third party content from displaying.\n\nIf you'd like to view this content, taskforce stood up to investigate.\n\nSix teenagers associated with the alleged attacker were charged after authorities descended on properties across western Sydney and southern NSW.\n\nCommissioner Blanch said while the Willetton attack had all the \"hallmarks\" of a terrorist incident, he wouldn't declare it one at this stage because he believed the 16-year-old was acting alone and WA didn't require extra Commonwealth resources.\n\nSpeaking last month at the National Press Club, ASIO boss Mike Burgess said the radicalisation of minors was firmly on the agency's radar.\n\n\"There's been a "title": "Albo's swipe after 'radicalised' teen killed", "body": "Anthony Albanese has taken a swipe at social media giants and the power of algorithms \"pushing people toward extremes\" after a teenager was shot dead by police when he stabbed a man while \"on the path of jihad\".\n\nSocial media giants have again been put on notice by the Prime Minister, who dialled up his language on the algorithms in the wake of the attack in a Perth Bunnings carpark.\n\nThe 16-year-old unleashed his attack at the Willetton Bunnings carpark about 10.15pm on Saturday, with police shooting the boy after they were unable to stop him with police Tasers.\n\nThe teenager stabbed one man, who remains at Royal Perth Hospital in a stable condition.\n\nPrior to his attack, the teenager sent a message to several people on social media saying he was going \"on the path of jihad\", with The West Australian reporting that members of Perth's concerned Islamic community alerted police to the messages.\n\n\"Brothers please forgive me for any time I have wronged you, I am going on the path of jihad tonight for the sake of Allah,\" the boy, who had reportedly converted to Islam, wrote.\n\n\"I am a soldier of the mujahideen of al-Qa'ida and take responsibility for the actions that will ... take place tonight.\"\n\nHe also warned his contacts to \"clear\" incriminating evidence from devices like laptops and phones.\n\n\"If you have any illegal or jihadi things online or in real life please make sure to hide them well and clear your technology such as laptops and phones including search history ... as the police will likely look into my contacts,\" he wrote.\n\nMr Albanese on Monday slammed social media, telling reporters that people were often pushed towards \"more extreme positions\" through the use of algorithms.\n\nHe said the influence on young people was \"concerning\".\n\n\"It is a dynamic that isn't just an issue for government. It is an issue for our entire society, whether it be violent extremism, misogyny and violence against women,\" he said.\n\n\"It is an issue that of course I am concerned about, it is something that authorities are concerned about, but it is something that parents are concerned about as well in schools and on the sidelines of footy games or netball games or whatever sport is played on the weekend.\"\n\nMr Albanese acknowledged the actions of the Muslim community in alerting police to the incident.\n\nHe said it was the \"right time\" to back the police and the processes they undertake.\n\n\"My first thoughts are with the victim of this incident but also to applaud the very swift action of WA Police in acting here, to also acknowledge the very important work that the Muslim community did to alert police to the messages that had been sent out by this young man,\" Mr Albanese said.\n\nIt has since been revealed the teenager reportedly attempted to indoctrinate peers at his school and had spent more than two years in a \"deradicalisation\" program after he was radicalised online.\n\nHe'd been known to police since the age of 14 and had mental health issues.\n\nThe teenager had attended Perth's prestigious Rossmoyne Senior High School, with one parent telling The West Australian that a \"group of boys\" attempted to \"indoctrinate\" her son.\n\nThe state's Department of Education was alerted, with parents also sharing concerns with the Australian Federal Police.\n\nOn Sunday, WA Police Force Assistant Commissioner Col Blanch didn't go as far to call the incident a terrorist attack despite carrying all the \"hallmarks\" of one.\n\n\"I believe this is a person acting alone. I don't need additional capability at this time whilst it meets the criteria or at least the definition,\" Mr Blanch said.\n\n\"It would be too early for me to act now because I don't have the concerns of a broader network that might be involved at this stage.\"", "source": {"uri": "news.com.au", "dataType": "news", "title": "News.com.au"}, "authors": [{"uri": "jessica_wang@news.com.au", "sim": 0.4901960790157318, "url": "https://www.abc.net.au/news/2024-05-05/willetton-knife-attack-perth-police-shooting-what-happened/103806882", "title": "This camera captured the horror that unfolded when a knife-wielding teen was shot dead by police", "body": "A brief late-night triple-0 phone call was the first crucial clue that WA police were about to have a major incident on their hands.\n\nThe young caller did not share his name, age or location before hanging up -- but he made it clear he was going to commit \"acts of violence\", according to authorities.\n\nMinutes later, another phone call to police confirmed he meant it.\n\nThe second call was from someone in the vicinity of a group of shops on a major arterial road in Perth's south, saying someone was running around a car park with a knife.\n\nUpon hearing that, three officers raced to the otherwise empty Bunnings car park in Willetton.\n\nIt was there at 10:15pm last night, the WA Police commissioner said, that a teenage boy confronted them with a large kitchen knife.\n\nCCTV footage recorded from a camera fixed under the front verandah of a nearby business shows the boy jogging through the car park, as a police car circles.\n\nA brief stand-off ensues, after which the boy falls to the ground.\n\nAt a press conference almost 12 hours later, police revealed they had shot the boy dead after tasering attempts failed to subdue him.\n\nThe footage shows police surrounding the boy before the camera cuts black.\n\nWhat police didn't know at the time, but learned shortly after, was that the boy had also just stabbed a man in his back before they'd arrived.\n\nThat man in his 30s is now in hospital with serious injuries, but he is said to be recovering.\n\nHe was not known to his attacker.\n\nPolice have yet to release the 16-year-old's identity.\n\nBut did they did paint a picture of his behaviour that was extremely alarming.\n\nIn fact, sometime in that flurry to respond to the attack, and afterwards, several triple-0 calls were fielded by police from concerned members of the WA Muslim community.\n\nWA Premier Roger Cook said there were indications the boy had been \"radicalised\" by extreme ideologies online.\n\nPolice Commissioner Col Blanch said the boy sent messages to some of those people who then immediately called police.\n\n\"I do want to thank members of the Muslim community who did that because that enabled us to identify rapidly who this individual was, and respond as quick as we did,\" he said.\n\n\"We are dealing with complex issues with a 16-year-old male. Both mental health issues but also online radicalisation issues. He is known to police, but we believe he very much is acting alone.\"\n\nIn fact, the boy was known to more authorities than just local police.\n\nCommissioner Blanch said the boy was one of \"three or four\" young people in WA actively participating in a national support program aimed at countering violent extremism online.\n\nDespite that, it was unfortunately not enough to stop what transpired in the car park on Saturday might.\n\nFor the few in that area at the time, it was a confronting scene to witness.\n\nJust a few restaurants and a 24-hour gym were open at the time.\n\nJohn Chi was on shift last night at the Korean BBQ restaurant Hancookwan when the incident unfolded.\n\n\"There was a guy wielding a knife, or an object from what I was understanding at the time, just in the Bunnings car park area,\" he said.\n\n\"The guy chased the police car up all the way into the no entry sign towards the Bunnings car park area and then ... the police moved away and called for backup.\"\n\nMr Chi said a police car then pulled up on a grassy patch by a nearby bus stop.\n\n\"What happened from there was a stand-off with police,\" he said.\n\n\"Two tasers were shot at the person and then the gunshot was fired promptly afterwards, however, there was a bit of distance before all of those were happening -- everyone in my restaurant was able to hear the gunshot as well.\"\n\nThe restaurant supervisor said it was not until this morning that he found out the teenager's declared intention of committing acts of violence.\n\n\"When he was chasing the police car around, he was holding it [the knife] like around his waist area and then when he was running towards the police car, obviously he was holding it up in the air so that's why the police pulled away,\" he said.\n\n\"I'm just a little bit shocked the person has died, he's 16 years-old, which is quite unfortunate.\"\n\nMr Chi said the police presence in the area was huge by the time he finished his shift.\n\n\"To start off with about I think one police car or patrol car and then it went to maybe two very soon afterwards and then in the span of 10 minutes we had about over another five to six police cars,\" he said.\n\n\"That would escalate over 10 to 20 through the course of 10:10pm to about 11pm.\n\n\"By the time I got out of work there was a police car at every intersection up all the way to IGA.\"\n\nA major {"uri": "8112998918", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "01:55:13", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T01:55:13Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T01:54:18Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4745098054409027, "url": "https://thewest.com.au/news/anthony-albanese-slams-social-media-giants-for-pushing-young-people-towards-extreme-content-after-teen-killed-by-police-c-14562907", "title": "Albo's swipe after 'radicalised' teen killed", "body": "Anthony Albanese slams social media giants for pushing young people towards extreme content after teen killed by policeLauren Ferri and Jessica WangNCA NewsWireMon, 6 May 2024 9:53AM\n\nAnthony Albanese has taken a swipe at social media giants and the power of algorithms \"pushing people toward extremes\" after a teenager was shot dead by police when he stabbed a man while \"on the path of jihad\".\n\nSocial media giants have again been put on notice by the Prime Minister, who dialled up his language on the algorithms in the wake of the attack in a Perth Bunnings carpark.\n\nThe 16-year-old unleashed his attack at the Willetton Bunnings carpark about 10.15pm on Saturday, with police shooting the boy after they were unable to stop him with police Tasers.\n\nThe teenager stabbed one man, who remains at Royal Perth Hospital in a stable condition.\n\nTheNightlyGet in front of tomorrow's news for FREE\n\nJournalism for the curious Australian across politics, business, culture and opinion.\n\nREAD NOW\n\nPrior to his attack, the teenager sent a message to several people on social media saying he was going \"on the path of jihad\", with The West Australian reporting that members of Perth's concerned Islamic community alerted police to the messages.\n\n\"Brothers please forgive me for any time I have wronged you, I am going on the path of jihad tonight for the sake of Allah,\" the boy, who had reportedly converted to Islam, wrote.\n\n\"I am a soldier of the mujahideen of al-Qa'ida and take responsibility for the actions that will ... take place tonight.\"\n\nHe also warned his contacts to \"clear\" incriminating evidence from devices like laptops and phones.\n\n\"If you have any illegal or jihadi things online or in real life please make sure to hide them well and clear your technology such as laptops and phones including search history ... as the police will likely look into my contacts,\" he wrote.\n\nMr Albanese on Monday slammed social media, telling reporters that people were often pushed towards \"more extreme positions\" through the use of algorithms.\n\nHe said the influence on young people was \"concerning\".\n\n\"It is a dynamic that isn't just an issue for government. It is an issue for our entire society, whether it be violent extremism, misogyny and violence against women,\" he said.\n\n\"It is an issue that of course I am concerned about, it is something that authorities are concerned about, but it is something that parents are concerned about as well in schools and on the sidelines of footy games or netball games or whatever sport is played on the weekend.\"\n\nMr Albanese acknowledged the actions of the Muslim community in alerting police to the incident.\n\nHe said it was the \"right time\" to back the police and the processes they undertake.\n\n\"My first thoughts are with the victim of this incident but also to applaud the very swift action of WA Police in acting here, to also acknowledge the very important work that the Muslim community did to alert police to the messages that had been sent out by this young man,\" Mr Albanese said.\n\nIt has since been revealed the teenager reportedly attempted to indoctrinate peers at his school and had spent more than two years in a \"deradicalisation\" program after he was radicalised online.\n\nHe'd been known to police since the age of 14 and had mental health issues.\n\nThe teenager had attended Perth's prestigious Rossmoyne Senior High School, with one parent telling The West Australian that a \"group of boys\" attempted to \"indoctrinate\" her son.\n\nThe state's Department of Education was alerted, with parents also sharing concerns with the Australian Federal Police.\n\nOn Sunday, WA Police Force Assistant Commissioner Col Blanch didn't go as far to call the incident a terrorist attack despite carrying all the \"hallmarks\" of one.\n\n\"I believe this is a person acting alone. I don't need additional capability at this time whilst it meets the criteria or at least the definition,\" Mr Blanch said.\n\n\"It would be too early for me to act now because I don't have the concerns of a broader network that might be involved at this stage.\"\n\nOriginally published as Anthony Albanese slams social media giants for pushing young people towards extreme content after teen {"uri": "8113006859", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "02:06:29", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T02:06:29Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T02:05:33Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4588235318660736, "url": "https://www.theepochtimes.com/world/perth-knife-attacker-spent-time-in-de-radicalisation-program-5644195", "title": "Perth Knife Attacker Spent Time in 'De-Radicalisation Program'", "body": "Police have yet to declare the incident a 'terrorist incident.'\n\nA 16-year-old male shot by police after stabbing a stranger in Perth, Western Australia (WA) spent years in a de-radicalisation program to prevent violent extremism.\n\nThe boy committed the attack in a Bunnings car park in Willetton, a southern suburb of Perth, and allegedly stabbed a stranger in the back with a 30-centimetre kitchen knife.\n\nHe was tasered twice by police, but when he advanced on an officer brandishing the weapon, he was fatally shot.\n\nAt around 10 p.m. on Saturday (May 4), he telephoned the police hotline, 000, and said he was planning to commit \"acts of violence.\"\n\nThe boy attended Rossmoyne Senior High School and had been in the program since 2022.\n\nWA Police Commissioner Col Blanch said the boy was Caucasian, had converted to Islam, and had \"mental health issues and radicalisation issues.\"\n\nHe was part of a program designed to combat violent extremist tendencies, which was monitoring seven youths and almost a dozen adults.\n\nWA Premier Roger Cook revealed members of the Muslim community had contacted police and raised concerns over his behaviour prior to the attack. He said there were indications the 16-year-old \"had been radicalised online.\"\n\n\"It is a tough gig to try and change people's beliefs once they've become obsessed and radicalised in this way,\" he said. \"These are people who haven't necessarily committed a crime and you can't lock people up for holding a belief ... That's part of democracy.\n\n\"The de-radicalisation effort was being thrown at him -- every effort was being made -- unfortunately, in this case, it didn't prevent him from doing what he did.\"\n\nThe Countering Violent Extremism (CVE) program provides support from psychologists, the education department and, where appropriate, faith leaders.\n\nWA's CVE is based on the work of Anne Aly, who is now the federal youth minister, as well as programs used to deradicalise neo-Nazis overseas. It was not limited to those convicted of crimes.\n\nMs. Aly said in a statement that de-radicalisation programs \"are an important community safety measure. They are often successful but no program can guarantee success. It's the sensitive nature of these programs that we often only hear about them when they don't succeed.\n\n\"I commend and thank the WA Police for the positive way they have worked with the Muslim community on this matter.\"\n\nDetectives working on the case said the 16-year-old was believed to be acting alone.\n\nMr. Blanch said the incident \"certainly has all the hallmarks\" of a terrorism-related incident, but he was not prepared to declare it as such \"at this stage.\"\n\n\"It would be too early for me to act now because I don't have the concerns of a broader network that might be involved,\" he explained.\n\n\"We would also like to mention that Islam has nothing to do with any acts of violence that are committed in its name. Islam is a religion that literally means peace,\" he said at a press conference.\n\n\"This was so close to home -- any one of us could have been at Bunnings,\" he said.\n\nMr. Janud said Muslims were concerned about potential Islamophobia following the incident, as well as the rise of radicalisation across the country.\n\n\"Radicalisation of all forms, whether that is anti-Semitic, whether that is Islamophobic, whether that is right-wing Neo Nazis, we see this on the rise,\" he said. \"As Australians, we all need to come together and tackle these issues that may be prevalent in the {"uri": "8113080665", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "03:39:50", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T03:39:50Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T03:39:27Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4509803950786591, "url": "https://www.abc.net.au/news/2024-05-06/perth-teenager-shot-dead-by-police-extremist-views/103808070", "title": "Premier reveals letter had been sent to education minister about behaviour of WA teen shot dead by police", "body": "The behaviour of the 16-year-old Perth boy fatally shot by police on the weekend was so concerning, a letter had been written to the education minister about him, WA Premier Roger Cook confirmed today.\n\nThe teenager stabbed a man, aged in his 30s, in the car park of a Bunnings store in Willetton on Saturday night.\n\nThe boy was then fatally shot by police after lunging at officers with a large kitchen knife.\n\nAuthorities alleged the youth became radicalised online and is believed to have suffered mental health issues.\n\nPremier Roger Cook said a letter was sent to the Education Minister Tony Buti with concerns about the teen, who was a student at Rossmoyne Senior High School.\n\nIt is not clear who wrote the letter.\n\n\"The minister automatically referred the letter to the Education Department for actioning,\" Premer Cook told reporters.\n\n\"The Education Department took that information on board and continued to manage that young man.\"\n\nHe said several people had become sufficiently worried about the teen to report their concerns to police.\n\n\"[The boy] sent a text message to others in the community ... many of those people then subsequently contacted police to express their concerns about the elevation in his mood and intentions,\" Mr Cook said.\n\nHowever, the Premier said police were not able to interfere, as the boy had not committed any crimes.\n\n\"The police are responsible for enforcing the law. The law does not prohibit people from having extreme thoughts,\" he said.\n\nThe teenager was one of nine people in WA engaged in a state-run anti-extremist program.\n\nMr Cook said the boy was a voluntary participant in that program for the past two years.\n\n\"This young gentleman was part of our Countering Violent Extremism program, so we were obviously well aware of the thoughts that he was harbouring,\" he said.\n\nRossmoyne's principal, Alan Brown, penned a letter to parents on Sunday expressing \"great sadness\" over the incident.\n\n\"Within the school, we will have support staff available to assist students, staff and parents,\" the email read.\n\nMr Brown said the school would contact parents directly if staff were concerned about their child.\n\n\"Young people may want to meet in groups or turn to social media for support and to express their feelings,\" he said.\n\nThe premier said the government and police were providing extra support at the high school.\n\n\"We have people at Rossmoyne today and there is an increased police presence as a result of the anxieties the community must be feeling,\" Mr Cook said.\n\nMr Cook met with dozens of community and cultural leaders on Sunday afternoon, thanking them for their role in assisting police with their rapid response.\n\nMr Cook said the Islamic community attempted to redirect the boy's extremist views and gave police \"as much notice as possible,\" when they noticed a shift in his behaviour.\n\nThe incident has not been classified as a terrorist attack.\n\n\"We are confident that this was a single act by a single person acting alone. There is no further threat to the community,\" Mr Cook said.\n\nPrime Minister Anthony Albanese reiterated that sentiment and said WA Police were taking a considered approach.\n\nWhen questioned about whether the definition of terrorism should be changed to politically motivated rather than religiously motivated, Mr Albanese said \"it's the right time to back our police\".\n\n\"It's the right time to back in our processes that they undertake but my first thoughts are with the victim of this incident but also, to applaud the very swift action of WA Police,\" he said.\n\n\"But also, to also acknowledge the very important work that the Muslim community did to alert police to the messages that had been sent out by this young man.\"\n\nMr Albanese acknowledged concerns about the threat of extreme material being accessed on social media.\n\n\"Social media where people can be pushed through the use of algorithms of what occurs towards more extreme positions is of course a concern,\" he Perth stabbing", "body": "READ MORE: Father of suspected Sydney terrorist breaks his silence\n\nA teenage boy who was shot dead by police officers after stabbing a man in the back with a large kitchen knife had a long, dark descent into Islamic radicalisation.\n\nThe 16-year-old died in hospital shortly after he was shot while charging at three police officers at a Bunnings carpark in Willetton, south Perth, at 10pm on Saturday.\n\nA man, aged in his 30s, was stabbed in his back during the attack before he was rushed to hospital in a serious but stable condition.\n\nWestern Australia Police revealed in a press conference on Sunday the teenager had been part of a de-radicalisation program since he was 14.\n\nFurther details emerged about the history of the teenager on Monday, including revelations that he attended the well-respected Rossmoyne Senior High School.\n\nHe is understood to have been part of a group that attempted to 'indoctrinate' other students with some parents raising their concerns with the school, The West Australian reported.\n\nHis final messages reportedly revealed the boy had told his friends he was going 'on the path of jihad' before he carried out the knife attack.\n\nThe dark history appears worlds away from the innocent childhood photos that have emerged on social media showing the boy playing with a toy.\n\nA teenager who was shot dead by police on Saturday went from playing with building toys as a child (pictured) to 'indoctrinating' high school students after being affected by Islamic radicalisation\n\nOfficers attempted to Taser the boy before shooting him on Saturday (pictured, officers at the scene)\n\nOfficers initially tried to Taser the teenager after he charged at two officers on Saturday.\n\nHowever, the Taser didn't deliver the desired effect and he charged at a third officer, who fatally shot him.\n\nThe boy's high school Rossmoyne Senior High School is known in Perth for producing high academic results.\n\nParents at the school made complaints to Education Minister Tony Buti and the Australian Federal Police over concerns about the 'radical' teenage group.\n\n'Correspondence was recently received regarding a student at a public secondary school,' a WA government spokesman said.\n\n'As appropriate, this correspondence was referred to the Department of Education.'\n\nConcerned parents claimed the 16-year-old boy could be linked to a school toilet block which was damaged last year.\n\nThey also claimed another boy from the group had threatened to hurt attendees of an upcoming graduation.\n\nPosts shared online by the boy's mother showed he had a happy childhood.\n\nThe teenager had stabbed a stranger in the back before charging at three officers (pictured, a bloodstain left at the scene)\n\nHe enjoyed playing with Meccano, a building toy similar to Lego, and making his mother laugh with jokes about his homework.\n\nBy the time he turned 14 in 2022, his personality had taken a dark turn as he was influenced by Islamic radicalisation.\n\nIn the same year, he was instructed by police to participate in a de-radicalisation group.\n\n'(Programs) are confronting a really serious challenge in changing someone who's been radicalised and attempting to get them back into a more reasonable pathway,' WA police minister Paul Papalia said.\n\n'It is a good program in that regard, because in the absence of it, there's no response to that sort of thing.\n\n'But also to be part of it, you're not necessarily a criminal. You haven't engaged necessarily in any criminal activity. So that's something to understand.'\n\nThe final message sent by the teen has also been revealed, with the boy reportedly saying he was going 'on the path of jihad'.\n\nThe 16-year-old sent the message to several people on social media, with several members of Perth's concerned Islamic community alerting police of the boy's messages.\n\n'Brothers please forgive me for any time I have wronged you, I am going on the path of jihad tonight for the sake of Allah,' the boy, who had reportedly converted to Islam, wrote.\n\n'I am a soldier of the mujahideen of Al-Qaeda and take responsibility for the actions that will ... take place tonight.'\n\nHe also warned his contacts to 'clear' incriminating evidence from devices like laptops and phones.\n\nParents at an esteemed Perth high school claimed the boy was part of a radical group who attempted to 'indoctrinate' other students (pictured, officers at the scene)\n\n'If you have any illegal or jihadi things online or in real life please make sure to hide them well and clear your technology such as laptops and phones including search history ... as the police will likely look into my contacts,' he wrote.\n\nRossmoyne Principal Alan Brown sent an email to parents on Sunday afternoon offering support and advice.\n\n'Young people may want to meet in groups or turn to social media for support and to express their feelings. Whilst this may be helpful, please be aware of potential misinformation or inappropriate comments,' he said.\n\n'If you become aware of any such gatherings, it is important to make sure there are responsible adults present, and you may wish to accompany your child.'\n\nWA Police Commissioner Col Blanch said the deceased teenager who known to police for 'mental health issues and radicalisation issues' since he was 14.\n\nHe confirmed the teenager's family is working with police.\n\n'I think this is a very challenged individual who was there on the night and I think the family really do {"uri": "2024-05-346472496", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "12:28:51", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T12:28:51Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T08:10:59Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4470588266849518, "url": "https://www.skynews.com.au/australia-news/bombshell-development-revealed-after-16yearold-boy-radicalized-online-shot-dead-by-police-after-stabbing-a-man-in-wa/news-story/46054b8c04f4d8f3013ef7f0217e0411", "title": "Bombshell development after teen radicalised online shot dead by police", "body": "The 16-year-old who stabbed a man in his 30s in the carpark of a Bunnings in Willetton, Perth, before being shot dead by police, had assembled a bomb and set it off in a school toilet block.\n\nWestern Australia Premier Roger Cook confirmed on Monday the boy had been attending deradicalisation programs for two years prior to Saturday's stabbing.\n\nHowever, police have refrained from declaring the incident a terrorist act.\n\nWA Liberal leader Libby Mettam said there were a number of \"red flags\" raised by parents at the school who knew the 16-year-old, questioning the education system for allowing the risk of extreme violence to remain at the teenager's school.\n\n\"We have an incident where a 16-year-old who had been in a de-radicalisation program had been involved in creating a homemade bomb which had destroyed a toilet block,\" Ms Mettam said.\n\n\"He had plans to interrupt an assembly in the most devastating of ways and had been able to continue to learn in a public mainstream school.\n\n\"There were a number of red flags raised by parents in this community and the Minister for Education continued to fob off those very real concerns.\"\n\nDespite the WA Premier Roger Cook assuring journalists at a press conference on Monday morning there was \"no further threat to the community\", Ms Mettam said the government was \"failing\" to keep Australians safe.\n\n\"It is appalling to hear this government had repeatedly fobbed off this very real concerns of parents from this school community.\"\n\nOne parent at the school told The Australian the teenager had \"gone mad\" after watching online videos and was one of several students who had converted to Islam.\n\nThe final text messages sent by the teen and supplied to The West Australian pre-empted his plan to launch an attack.\n\n\"Brothers please forgive me for any time I have wronged you. I am going in the path of jihad tonight for the sake of Allah,\" he reportedly said.\n\n\"I am a soldier of the mujahideen of Al-Qaeda and take responsibility for the actions that will ... take place. Please don't forget me and the mujahideen in your duat (afterlife).\"\n\nMr Cook said the teenager was in the Countering violent extremism (CVE) program and the state government was \"obviously well aware\" of the thoughts he was harbouring.\n\n\"This young man was harbouring some extremist thoughts which is the reason why he was part of the countering violent extremism program,\" Mr Cook said.\n\n\"As the Police Commissioner said yesterday, this incident has all the hallmarks of a terrorist incident.\"\n\nMr Cook said the classifying of a terrorist act brought other measures, powers and agencies into the investigation, but said it would be done if there was an \"ongoing risk\" to the community and if there were other people involved.\n\nThe Premier moved to assuage fears of further incidents, reiterating the Police commissioner's earlier remarks that there was \"no further threat to the community and the situation is in hand\".\n\nCommissioner Blanch said the boy had been known to police since 2022 when he was enrolled in a deradicalisation program targeted at countering violent extremist ideologies.\n\nThe incident has not, however, been declared an act of terrorism with police arguing it is too soon to reach that conclusion before the motivations behind the attack are investigated.\n\n\"It certainly has the hallmarks of one (a terrorist attack) and the "news", "sim": 0.4313725531101227, "url": "https://thewest.com.au/news/crime/willetton-bunnings-gym-reopen-after-police-shoot-dead-teenager-in-perth-stabbing-attack-c-14552773", "title": "Bunnings shuttered after police shoot knife-wielding teen", "body": "updatedWilletton Bunnings reopens then abruptly closes after police shoot dead teenager in Perth stabbing attackRebecca Le MayThe West AustralianSun, 5 May 2024 10:36AM\n\nCustomers have been turned away from Bunnings in Willetton where a police shooting unfolded on Saturday night.\n\nThe store reopened for a few hours on Sunday morning before shutting again as the investigation into why a 16-year-old boy stabbed a man before being shot by police continued.\n\nA blood stain could still be seen in the car park on High Road, despite being washed down by officers.\n\nThe teenager allegedly stabbed a man aged in his 30s, who remains in Royal Perth Hospital in a serious but stable condition, just after 10pm on Saturday night.\n\nTheNightly\n\nGet in front of tomorrow's news for FREE\n\nJournalism for the curious Australian across politics, business, culture and opinion.\n\nREAD NOW\n\nOfficers were called to the car park after a call from the teenager himself and found the boy holding the knife.\n\nPolice Commissioner Col Blanch said two officers withdrew their Tasers, while a third took out their firearm, confronting the lone teenager.\n\nAfter officers called for the teenager to put down his weapon, understood to be a 30cm kitchen knife, the teen rushed the officers, who deployed both their Tasers, Commissioner Blanch said.\n\nWhen the boy turned on the third police officer, he discharged his firearm, fatally wounding the teenager.\n\nPolice at the scene worked through the night and wrapped up their initial investigations on Sunday around 7.30am as volunteers from a sporting group set up a sausage sizzle.\n\nBut around 10.30am, the fundraising tent had been dismantled and customers were being turned away from the usually jam-packed hardware store, with a security guard telling would-be shoppers that there had been an incident overnight.\n\nThree detectives went inside, emerging some 20 minutes later.\n\nBunnings confirmed the store was temporarily closed as staff continued to assist police with enquiries and worked to re-open as soon as possible.\n\nA sausage sizzle volunteer, who did not want to be identified, said police told him the incident involved two people yelling at each other.\n\nThe teen and his victim had apparently emerged from the nearby Zap gym - which is unstaffed, with entry only available to members via swiper card - and argued as they moved through the Bunnings carpark, he said.\n\n\"They were yelling out at each other then next minute there's a stabbing,\" the volunteer said.\n\n\"It's not the place for something like that to happen here. Willetton's very quiet -- there's no pubs here.\n\n\"So there's obviously something happened in the gym, then to have an argument then spilling out here.\"\n\nBy sunrise, the huge police presence had reduced to a forensics van and three officers peering into bins with their torches, the man said.\n\nThe incident delayed staff at the round-the-clock Sai Vet Hospital from going home at the end of their shift on Saturday night.\n\nHigh Road residents Ameya and Gouri Khandekar, who have lived near the Bunnings for the past three years, heard sirens but thought nothing of it in the otherwise quiet suburb.\n\n\"It's scary,' Ms Khandekar told reporters.\n\n\"I have two boys and my older one's 12 who's just started to go to high school and you have to be careful with what they watch ... watching things online.\n\n\"Because of the school zones, it's a very family-oriented suburb. Quiet, friendly - the reason we're here.\"\n\nMr Khandekar said it was \"quite shocking\" to have such a crime on his doorstep following a recent spate of knife attacks including the Bondi Junction stabbings.\n\n\"It's always been a good place. Qualified, educated people,\" he said.\n\n\"You have a home open and it's usually, within a couple of days, under offer.\"\n\nGet the latest news from thewest.com.au in your inbox.\n\nSign up for our
